reviews.review:
Very Interesting. . Visited here on the hop on hop off bus which drops you right outside the museum.
The museum is compact with lots of storys about the people being forced out of there homes and locate to other areas.
Apartheid was evil how could humans be treated like this.
Absolutely brilliant. Well laid out and incredible stories are told here. Ask for a guide by the name of Joe. He experienced the forced removal and life on the Cape Flats. I was dumb struck.
Avery interesting experience. The visit was interesting and informative. We loved the walk around the Bo kaap. We felt very safe. The guides were very knowledgable.

Personal and interesting. This museum in most cases tells very personal stories: people who had to leave everything behind due aggressive power full of hate. Very impressive and interesting.
On common level, you can see what Cape Town lost - and the area is still quiet and without buildings.

An Historical Must. At this small venue one can find a wealth of history of the old Cape. Also one becomes accutely aware of that period in history which should never be forgotten. The injustices of the past are high lighted with documentation, artifacts and even a display of old street name plates which reminds one of what was once.a vibrant colourful area. Walk over the old street map on the floor and see what the original layout of District 6 was like. Spend at least a full moring there. Guides are available
our Heritage. A lunch time of 1hour is not enough as there is so much to read up on as I was born in Cape Town and part of my heritage

Small but very interesting. I loved all the old photographs, and I think this was by far the most interesting section of the museum. There are a lot of words in their exhibits and I found myself a little confused when I managed to miss out sections in the timeline. Worry not, there is an excellent little cafe at the back when a quick cup of tea and cake is required!

Hire a guide - Ruth's story was heartbreaking. For a few rand you can hire a rand to take you around and bring this museum to life. We all spent the hour or so we were here with tears in our eyes. Ruth told her story with dignity and passion. It was the best thing we did all holiday. It moved us, inspired us, made us laugh, made us cry but most importantly made us think. Thank you Ruth and district 6 for keeping the memories, good and bad, alive. We should never forget what has happened in SA.

A must see!. A small, tastefully done museum that will educate and move you. To paraphrase one of the District 6 people who submitted statements, many museums are about rich, successful people, this museum is about just people and their lives.
Not what I expected. The museum is small and mostly photos with a few information boards and some items from past businesses and homes.However, it was still interesting.
Worthwhile visit. Even though it is a small museum, it is definitely worth a visit. The curators have treated the affected people and brutal history with such respect.

Well presented. A bit more of a memorial than a museum, I found the venue to be well presented with many first hand accounts of the events that lead to the demolition of District 6. The historical photographs depicting Cape Town in that era we very cool.
Tip - No parking so take a cab over.

Very interesting small museum. A delightful insight into what it was like for the inhabitants of District 6 during apartheid. I particularly liked the use of suitcases with bits and pieces iluustrating what they had been able to take from their homes when removed. Lovely individual statements from those who had been moved out. The museum is clearly very special to those whose lives it depicts.

a must see for all interested in the evils of apartheid. a great museum that really brings home how evil apartheid was. the museum is guided by former residents of district 6 , all of whom wwere dispossesed and saw their homes destroyed in the warped demand for racial purity of the apartheid regime. the story is told throughout the museum in a sympathetic and objective way.
Great piece of history. This small museum is worth a stop in. There is a lot of information to read, so if you want to really process it all you will need a few hours

Apartheid in one of it's worst forms. Seeing an entire neighborhood demolished, with all residents forced to relocate, brings home the horror of apartheid. Now virtually a wasteland in the middle of a modern, thriving city.

Sad Look of Apartheid. What a telling look at the failure of Apartheid. This is a wonderful place to view the simplistic view of man. So glad this museum is here to help people learn how corrupt power can be.
Interesting. Nice small museum of personal experiences. We came away understanding a little more of what apartheid did to the people.
Worth a visit!. Small museum that gives a face to the horror of apartheid. Many personal pictures and stories told by those who lived through those times.
September 2016. If you want to learn the culture of Cape Town, this is a must. Great museum. The pictures and history realy help you to understand the people of today.

A must see museum. It is a bit chaotic so allow plenty of time - our guide only allowed 20 minutes so we could not read all the displays. They do need to produce a good guide to the museum, but one of the people who lived there, Noor, is on hand to talk about it and has written his memoirs. It is a terrible reminder of the way in which Africans and Coloureds were treated - essential background to understanding the modern situation.

Extremely interesting. Definitely worth a visit. Local residents will explained a lot about the local deportation following the introduction of apartheid. Lots of pictures and stories to look and listen at. Guided visit lasts about 80 mins.

Moving experience very unique museum. If you want to understand better the suffering of people during Apartheid a visit to this museum is a must. Make sure to get a guided tour given by one of the people that were moved out of the District Six by the unjust white supremacist government of South Africa. Our guide walked us through his anecdotes what life was like at the District which was one of the few fully integrated neighborhoods where people lived in harmony. That all ended and people had to move far away from the city just because of their skin color. This museum along with visiting Robben Island are two must visits of anyone wanting to better understand history. This history must never repeat again. Love Trumps Hate

Humbling experience . We were fortunate to visit on Heritage Day. Many local people were there showing their children pictures of there relatives who experienced the atrocities of apartheid. It only takes a short visit to learn a lot, take the time and do it. The hop on/off bus has a stop in front of the museum, so it's easy to get to. Credit cards are accepted for entrance fee.

Combine the visit in the museum with the visit in a township.. This very valuable and necessary museum exposing brutalities and nonsense of Apartheid. Its ample collection of artifacts and photos on display is possibly a bit chaotic in general presentation but of course it is the contents that counts. The floor is covered with the map of the district and notes pointing to particular houses. We combined the visit to the museum with a visit in a township. We had a guide for both locations.
Important. Foreigners do not understand this history which is important. It is a very informal museum but worth visiting and supporting the efforts .

Could be better. Seing the Holocaust Musaum in Warshaw, it is very easy to say that they could have organized the District Six Museum much better. It is unfortunately a must see location but don't expect anything fancy; just a building surrounded by walls of pictures with lines of writings on the history.It could have been magnificient with more audio visual elements.
A must to see. I dont often write reviews but this museum deserves all the love it can get. Quite possibly one of the best places to really appreciate the true textures of South African history.

Good insight into CT history. This was a very moving experience and we learnt a lot about the forced removal of coloured people from this part of Cape Town. We didn't have a tour, but there were people talking to other groups which we overheard, and it was very interesting. There was a good audio visual on a tv in the back room which explained things well. Allow at least 40 mins and probably longer.

Disappointed . The museum is poorly laid out and the way the information is presented failed to tell this history very well. There just seemed to be no order to the displays, route to take and there was just too much text to read.

Thought provoking visit. Wasn't sure what to expect when visiting this museum within a group led by a wonderful gentleman from a township. He told us of the struggles his family went through and all people in South Africa . And seeing the photographs and ' bench' bought home how sad the whole regime had been.But now there is hope for these people

Important museum to visit . This museum is actually owned by the church that was turned into the museum. It gives you the background of the 1970s forced clearance of 60,000 black residents
And demolition of all their houses. A gentleman whose I.D card is shown on the board was at the museum to answer questions. Everyone should visit and try to understand what happened
fantastic place to learn about apartheid history. here you got a pretty correct insight to what coloured people have gone trough in the sixties in South Africa

Understanding Apartheid and Community. My family visited the museum and if you want to understand some of the challenges and tensions of people, of what makes a community and what holds it together (or can tear it apart) this museum will provide insight. While experienced in a different way than in my country Canada, there are similarities of dislocation, oppression and the challenges of people (from all backgrounds) who are seeking a way beyond these realities. This is worth the time visiting it. There is a small "cafe" there as well where one can get some refreshment.

Knowledge is Power. I was able to purchase a book from one of the founders of the Museum who shared his story with the group. The pictures and other material provided in the Museum touches my heart in a way that is difficult to explain in words. An extremely rewarding tour and experience. I was able to add to the history of the museum by writing and leaving my own words written on a scroll.

Nice for a historical perspective. Our tour guide explained about district 6 and took us to the physical location. We then headed over to the museum. I will admit this was not on my list of must sees - but I am so glad we saw both the site and the museum. I made me truly appreciate the history of Cape Town and South Africa in a way a simple article or verbal decription would not.Please do pay a visit - it can take as short as 45 minutes to gain a world of perspective.

Worth the detour. This is a fascinating museum telling the little known history of the restriction of this lively multi cultural area during the apartheid years. Its a 10 minute walk from company's gardens

Most informative and thought provoking. This museum tells you all you need to know about a very troubled time in South Africa's history. There are many informative displays and staff are available to provide personal insights.

Well worth a couple of hours.. Join a guided tour to hear about how a neighborhood of 50k people was removed from the face of the earth simply because of the colour of people`s skins. Good display and an excellent café.

A must do. So interesting and equally so sad to learn of the the families who went to work one day only to return home and find their houses bulldozed and their community evicted because of white supremecy. The injustice is crushing, the museum offers an accurate , factual account of the impact on real families and the subsequent impact and outcomes, communities ripped apart physically and emotionally . Ironically today District 6 remains bare apart from a few churcheswhich were not bulldozed.... why...Man's inhumanity to man

Not to be missed. I took a guided walking tour of the area formerly known as District Six, thus I wanted to follow-up with a visit to the Museum. I gave this attraction "an average" rating because the layout of the displays impacted my experience (I guess I am more traditional in this regard). However, piggy-backed upon the walking tour, I left the museum with a sound exposure to this slice of South African history, and I urge visitors to make time to see DSM.

Very informative little museum. I learnt about this place from the audioguide of the citysightseeing bus, and decided to visit it: glad I did, as it is very informative about the history that everyone needs to know. An hour is sufficient and a guided visit is recommended.

A very humbling experience. I had read a book by Noor Ibrahim called 'My Life in District 6'. It is an easy read but very insightful. Imagine how surprised I was to see him working at the bookshop inside the museum when I visited. He was a very unassuming man and happy to personalise his book when I purchased another copy. All around you in this museum (a converted Methodist church) are chilling reminders of the apartheid regime. Take the time to read people's accounts of what happened to them as it really beggars belief. You need to allow at least an hour here to read and understand what really went on during that period.
Great place to visit. I recommend the tour guide. It is not too expensive and you will get a personalized feel of what happened there during apartheid.

Interesting but no worries if you miss it. We enjoyed going here to learn about the history of District Six but the information is very spread out and a lot to take in. Still very interesting though to learn about all the heartache and hardships these people endured.

Lovely place. I enjoyed being here. It was however a bit small or limited but very special. The price is really worth it. Please have some of the koeksisters in the cafe the waiters there are just lovely! I enjoyed particularly Nomvuyo's room and the hairdresser or salon area upstairs. Beautiful memories and the stories and told well. Overall a stunning place to visit! Despite the weather too.

Harrowing but vibrant - they can go in the same sentence.. See it for yourself! That's all I can say. I knew very little about apartheid and it's true effects but when leaving the museum I felt enriched with information and emotion for the area.Was part of the Illios - "Walk to Freedom" tour.
So interesting!. We did the tour with one of 66.000 people who had to leave district six. It was so interesting. You can learn a lot from them.

Moving history recreated. This small museum on the outskirts of the city centre is a poignant testimony to the struggles of ordinary people during South Africa's brutal period of apartheid. But, however revolting the policy and actions of the government and its big business supporters, what shines through this exhibition is the humanity of the oppressed, through their tales of domestic and social life in a doomed part of the city. Well worth a visit.

Request a guided tour to make this a great experience . We visited the museum and thought it was nice but requested a guided tour. That was a good decision as it uplifted our visit from nice to spectacular. The guided tour was only about $1.50 US.

Small. I went on a quick round; it started with quite some reading and continued with several stories of people about what happened. If you are into history and a 'personal touch' on how it was, probably interesting. It just wan't something for me.

Moving but muddled. We visited this museum after seeing rave reviews and because my English boyfriend was interested in our political history. The entrance fee isn't a lot but it doesn't include any sort of guide or information leaflet.The major problem with the museum is the vast amount of tiny text which is overwhelming. It makes it impossible to follow a coherent timeline. Someone with poor vision would struggle.Half the museum is only by accessible by a staircase, wheelchair users beware!Guided tours are available by former residents of District 6 at an additional cost. Parking is difficult but look near Charley's Bakery and you might get lucky, it's close by. The museum could be greatly improved by trimming a lot of the text and making it more interactive. They have a lot of interesting facts but they're so hard to find in amongst all the text. The displays are also interesting and the floor map is a highlight.

Definitely worth a stop. My walking tour ended at this location and I decided to stop in to see what else I could learn about District Six. The museum is full of items from the people who were forcibly removed from their homes. I especially loved the time I spent with the ladies in the restaurant. They were very knowledgeable on Cape Coloured history

SA History. The museum tells you about the District 6 inhabitants who got displaced when Apartheid was implemented. It's a small museum but so full of history that it can easily take you several hours.

Woderful. We visited after the walking tour and enjoyed the detailed and personal exhibits and guided discussion. The photos, films and artefacts are fascinating. We also enjoyed a tasty sandwich wand drink in the small cafe. Recommended.

Important place to visit. This is a very special place. You likely have heard much about the history of apartheid in South Africa, but the particular application in this historic neighborhood gives a really important insight. Very inexpensive, you can also take a guided tour with a former resident of District 6. Give yourself an hour or so. (And then walk up to Charlie's Bakery which is visible from the corner!)
Good memorial of the start of apartheid. After the District 6 walking tour, the museum had more meaning. It's a good memorial to the beginning of apartheid.
A history that should not be forgotten!. This museum really conveys the tensions and shameful behavior that existed under apartheid. Should not be missed!

Learn more about Cape Town's history. District Six was declared a White-only area in 1966. The vibrant life was destroyed and more than 60.000 habitants were forcefully removed and placed to different townships far away from the city centre. The museum shows how the people lived together, the exciting music scene, and tells more about the different laws which regulated the life of the coloured and black communities during Apartheid.An absolute must for Capt Town visitors.
Educational. Museum set on two levels explaining black expulsion from Cape Town city. Staff very friendly. There is a great cafe with free WIFI.

A Must. Wow! This museum gives you a good dish of reality about the former days. Plan on spending time reading the various signs and articles. If you can't get to Johannesburg to see the Apartheid Museum, then this is a good second choice.

Good little museum . We really enjoyed our visit to District Six. The story is very sad and the museum manages to really bring the story to life through the people who used to live there and their personal experiences. However, the layout of the museum is a little confusing and we seemed to do everything in the wrong order. Well worth a visit though as it only takes about an hour to go around the museum. Distinct 6 is on the red route for the city sightseeing buses so a good place to stop off.
Small but nice. It's a small museum with basic information on urban policy during the apartheid era. You can spend about half an hour there. Entrence is cheap.
Very meaningful. We did not know much about this period and the museum does a very fine presentation and preservation of the period. It is very worthwhile, and advise to also have a Township Tour.
Sad part of SA history a must see. Wonderful collection of stories and photos of District six. Well put together. R30 admission. Friendly staff. Coffee shop

lots of learning. This is a very interesting museum detailing the displacement of the community that had grown up in District Six. The staff is knowledgeable. There is also a little cafe where you can relax.

Very interesting and educative . We arrived here by chance and we didn't regret it. We learned a lot about the apartheid time and how it was "practically" applied. The reception is kept by a man who used to live in district six so it really made us think through what South African went through. It is small but it is a must do in Cape Town. Also if you have time watch the video in the room at the back.

A glimpse of the injustices of Apartheid. The displays illustrate the lively nature of district six which reminded me of New Orleans. It shows how the area was bulldozed by the authorities and the people displaced.

Unusual museum - worth a visit!. This is a small museum designed to give visitors a feel for what happened to the people who lived in District Six and were displaced by the apartheid policies. We visited at the end our Free Walking Tour of District Six and we had learned the history of the District from our tour guide which helped us understand and appreciate the things we saw in the museum. We were there for an hour or so. I don't know if the museum offers guided tours, but that would be worth investigating. In any case, this is an important part of Cape Town and South Africa. Please visit.

Most emotionally moving site in Cape Town. This was the museum that made me cry--not Robbin Island. To see the life story in banners and a floor mapping all the streets and homes, lives and cultures destroyed by apartheid in South Africa--this small museum brought that home to me. Not just Blacks were forcably removed from District Six, but also Jews and other "Foreigners." and nothing has been rebuilt on the sight--no families returned. Only this church turned museum remains and the vacant space in the middle of the city.
Cultural must see. Great activity for a rainy day, interesting insight from Cape Towns history. Some really talented photos and artwork on display.
Brilliant museum. Take a couple of hours out, to watch videos and read real life accounts of what apartheid meant to real people. An emotional experience.

Very informative!. A must to visit if you want to learn about the history of South Africa. The museum is small, has lots of personal things like luggage full of clothes, shoes, pictures of family and friends of people who were taken by the apartheid government and taken to Langa, they were segregated. Very interesting and informative. I took a tour with Ellios travel, they first take you to the museum and then to Langa city so you can better understand what happened.

Dont' Miss This Museum and Tour. Listening to Noor, I was struck by the thought that whenever I take a tour with someone who experienced an historic event, I learn so much more than I would just reading about it (I've also been on a tour in Phnom Penh with a survivor of the Pol Pot years and at Robbin Island with a former inmate). The museum's exhibits are presented in an engaging format - not the typical glass-case and text format at all. Well worth a visit.
Very moving experience. Definitely gives one a batter understanding of the history of District Six and will take about an hour to go through the museum.

Interesting place. The tour is done by people who lived at District Six. The story of the guide was really interesting. You can see a lot of pictures of the District Six. I liked it because of the guide!

Interesting history. Nice museum full of artifacts and information about a dark period in Cape Town's history. There were very nice displays and you could even chat with former District 6 members (for a fee).

Rich with sources. This little museum is worth a visit. You will come back with a greater knowledge of what it was like living during the apartheid era. The museum is rich with excellent sources. I feel that the layout could have been better- in that, if you could make it obvious which end to start from etc. This would make it more visitor friendly. I highly reccomend reading the poem that are written on the floors at the back room- very tearjerking. Also watch a video on district six in the same room.

Small and compact but interesting. We happened upon this museum quite by accident although it was on our to do list. It is housed in a lovely old church. We are particularly interested in history so we enjoyed the exhibition. We declined to get a guide which I later regretted as I overheard one giving her presentation which sounded fascinating as the guides are ex residents of district six. Worth a visit if the subject interests you.

Nice little museum with lots interesting information. The District Six museum is small and slightly old fashioned. The tours are given by old inhabitants of district six which give the museum a unique touch. There is a treasure trove of information available on District Six and its former inhabitants. Worthwhile to go to with (older) kids to give them inside into one of the darker episodes of Cape Town’s history. Cheap and definitely worthwhile to visit.
Very Interesting. A really well thought out and mind provoking exhibition. Easy to find and in my mind the best history lesson in Cape Town

Interesting Apartheid history. A museum dedicated to the destruction of a large part of Cape Town back in the last days of Apartheid. The SA Police were tasked with tearing down the District 6 'ghetto' in order to split up the Jewish, Coloured, Black and White communities who were happily living together. The land itself has been left empty and derelict for decades while court case after court case has progressed through the South African Courts for recompense to the previous dwellers. The general view is that the Government have stretched out the legal arguments for decades so that the previous inhabitants will gradually die of old age, which is precisely what has happened. A fitting and lasting reminder of the bad old days of Apartheid.

Beautiful tribute to the spirit of a people. This is essential Cape Town. Do not leave without going here and to the even more informative Slave Lodge.This museum has considerable number of panels explaining the history of District 6, the displacement and the growth of townships and horrors of apartheid. This is also a beautiful museum that plays tribute to the original diversity of D6 and the strength of spirit of those displaced. Personal stories, recipes etc are colorfully displayed and there is usually one or two old-timers there willing to share their story of living in District 6.
Thought Provoking. I found this a wonderful opportunity to think about the history of Cape Town as an overseas visitor it was very thought provoking - so well organised

Fascinating. Poignant museum exploring the horror of apartheid in District Six. Although the exhibitions were a tad busy and crowded (with words, not people), it is well worth a visit. The cafe within is great too - lovely coffee with very friendly and fun staff.

Beautiful place of remembrance. I went to District Six not knowing much about apartheid in South Africa and feel as though I came a way with a deeper understanding than what a history book could have taught me. The District Six Museum does an incredible job of communicating both the history of the district as well as the human experience of that time period. A must do in Cape Town!

Very interesting. Stopped in here on a Big Bus Tour. Fascinating to glimpse the way of life and heart breaking to see the homes that were destroyed and lives that were displaced. I certainly hope we learn from the mistakes we make!!
Very interesting. . Read the book and always wanted to visit. Well worth a visit if history and heritage interests you. Great collection of pictures and artifacts.

Educational Must!. If you want to know anything about what is affecting South Africa today, you have to go to this museum and learn the true story of district six. It's a great addition to the South African perspective in understanding current issues.

A Museum that tells a story. The museum is small, but worth a visit. It vividly records the incident happened in the district during the apartheid era. The curator is a resident in the district at the time and his identity card was retained and displayed as evidence. The materials therein are abundant and informative. It definitely deserves a visit.
Understated and yet significant.. I did not know the story of district 6 and it was so moving to learn about it. They have docents who lived through it to tell the story. It was moving.

A touching tribute. If in Cape Town make sure you visit this museum. A touching yet entertaining tribute to an horrendous injustice in the history of many injustices to the black population of South Africa. With the guided tours conducted by previous occupants of District 6 you can feel the pain they suffered when they were bulldozered out of their homes.Thankfully Cape Town is a very different place today but museums like this play a crucial role in reminding people how human beings should not be treated.

Informative reminder of a dark history . This museum is a reminder of our dark history and is very informative. Also worth your while to visit the actual open fields of weeds where District Six used to be.
An real education. Such an eye opener - excellent guide who enlightened us so much on the history of District 6 - a must for everyone's itinerary.
Heartwrenching. You defiantly learn about the heinous treatment of citizens. We must never quit learning from our collective past.

Great guided tour of museum. Our guide was a former District 6 resident and her guided tour was very interesting and personal. I would highly recommend joining a guided tour since the stories are the biggest part of the experience.

A special exhibit of displacement that compliments the walking tour. . Visiting the museum after having done the walking tour really helped close the gaps on exactly what took place here. Printed accounts from those involved supported by photos along with first hand guided experiences from district 6 residents (an additional $15 R) all capture the realism of what happens here.
historic and informative. This is a great place to stat to know what exactly went on in SA. Its important to know true history so mistakes aren't repeated. Take your time and read and soak it all in.

Sobering but important to see!. Definitely a must see! A good amount of history, though ensure you read up on the history before hand if you don't know - there isn't a lot of information especially if you don't hire a guide, so know the basic history about what it is, etc., before you come! Otherwise you will be lost!
Steeped in history. Another must do in Cape Town. Very interesting museum with great artifacts. small but perfectly formed.

Extremely Informative. We had a guided tour by a past and current District Six resident. He was so informative! The museum is small, but very nicely done. Don't miss this essential stop while visiting Cape Town!

Interesting and Historic. The District Six Museum has quite a large number of street signs from the area that was bulldozed and pictures of what District Six looked like prior to the forced relocation of its population.

Taken back to walk in D6. This is my 2nd visit to this lovely museum. You walk through recreated rooms of houses in District 6. You get a good glimpse of how the people lived before D6 was demolished.
Well worth a visit. We were very interested in learning about the social history of South Africa. This museum whilst small was very emotive and informative

Better understanding . I went to the museum before continuing on to a township tour and it was good to get more of an understanding about what had happened and the timeline of it. For someone who didn't have much knowledge it was an intense but easy to understand display of information.

Sobering day. My son and I had a little African adventure. We finished up in Cape Town and took a one day tour. As background, In the 1960s there was formalized relocation of tens of thousands of people and formalized stratification of non-whites ending in the lowest category, black African. We started a tour in District 6 in which the government of 1966 decided should be a "white" neighborhood, so demolished the whole district and moved the people to the "townships" where they had to apply to get passes to be allowed to come to town; they were not allowed to own property, and had to pay for the trains that brought them in to work in the city. The museum was one of the buildings that was not destroyed and was full of pictures and artefacts of the area and is staffed by residents who lived there before it the area was demolished. I wish I had known more before I went there. The guide we had was a bit dry and not too engaging although talking to the actual museum guides was interesting. Not too much "fun" but worth the time.

Historic and Personal. This wonderful little gem gives the story of apartheid and its effects on the ordinary people through a look through their eyes. A lot is crammed into this building and it would be SO much better if their was an audio tour. Do yourself a favor and go.
Well worth a visit. We had a guide which really helped us navigate the various displays - more personal than the apartheid museum in Joburg.

Well worth a visit. Quite a moving place to see. I did the open top bus tour which is how I found out about District Six, so thought I would follow it up with a trip to the Museum. Nothing fancy, but well worth going to if you are interested in finding out a bit more about it.Some of the stories are quite moving, and given that it is not that long ago it seems all the more real, rather than some museums which have artefacts from several hundred years ago.

Great Insight into the Experience and Destructiveness of Apartheid. The District Six Museum was a good afternoon activity that provided information about the experience of minorities under Apartheid and the unjust destruction of a cultural treasure in Cape Town.

A wealth of information. This small museum is jam-packed with fascinating historical information but is unfortunately a little overwhelming and not easy to take in. I would recommend getting a guided tour to get the most out of your visit.

Important visit. This is a 'must do' on your visit to Cape Town. The history here is important and the employees will answer any questions you may have. Take your time to really understand what happened to this area.

What is this place?. This museum is not run very well. Other reviews state that you need to get a guide and I guess that's true. My family and I entered the museum and we could not figure out how to get such a guide. The person at the front desk didn't look up from her phone and just told us to look around on our own. My kids couldn't figure out what the museum was about. OK, I concede that you can figure out what the museum is about if you are willing to read -- A LOT, but my teenagers don't fall into that category. I knew some things about District Six because I read about it online before coming, the museum didn't teach me anything I didn't already know from reading Wikipedia.

Heart-rending. The best way to have an excellent tour in this museum is to get a local guide. Otherwise, you'll be overwhelm with all the displays or information. Our guide was Ruth. She's very lovely and has good sense of humor. She shared us what her family did experience during the apartheid. It was so sad that these people did experience all of these. When she started telling us the story of what her family has experience. I can help but feel remorse to the people who did these and to all the family that were removed from their homes.I can't even comprehend why people can be so cruel because of someone's color. As they say, their history is still being written and they have a long way to go but they make sure that the history will not repeat itself. Ruth even said that "She need to forget the past to have a brighter future" What I love about this place, the people remain so positive despite of what had happen to them. I highly recommend everyone to visit this place. you'll have more appreciation of the place. It can even change yourself for the better.
History Lession. The District Six Museum is a great way to learn about the Apartheid era and to see photography from the old townships. Well worth a visit.

oh, the history. Our tour guide shared his family story of how they were displaced from District Six how this affected so many families. this was a great place to start our stay in Cape Town learning the brutality of apartheid. There is a lot of history in this place. This is a must visit place on a trip to Cape Town.

A must see. Very emotional and moving little museum. The older gents that work there can give you a few personal insights into their real life experiences of Apartheid and the regimes they had to endure.

Very well presented museum. We are delighted that we chose to include the District Six Museum in our visit to Cape Town. The displays were clear, informative and well done. The photos and descriptions provided a clear understanding of this tragic time. I highly recommend making time to visit.

Wonderful museum. I visited with a university group and we were able to get a tour from a man who experienced this hard times first hand. The museum is small but really gives great insight to what took place in dstrict six.
Small, but excellent. There are some powerful history lessons inside this little museum, brought to life with effective displays. Definitely worth a visit.
charming cafe and informative museum. The staff of the cafe is so sweet, and the museum has an amazing, tragic history to tell. Please visit.
Worth the time. Provides a much needed historical context. Would be great if you are lucky enough to have a good tour guide.

Good Museum. To understand the horror and the history of the apartheid era you must visit this museum. I suggest that hire the guided visit, which are led by real survivors. Additionally, they will answer all the questions in a kind way.

Made a Point to Visit Twice. I again appreciated immersing myself in the sad history that's captured for posterity at the District Six Museum. I had first visited in 2006, when it was newly opened, and found not many of the exhibits changed this time but it was still as moving and heartbreaking to read the stories of those removed from this colored neighborhood not all that long ago. I was fortunate to have a friend who lives in Noordhoek inform me of the museum earlier, as it's not that well-known to tourists. I highly recommend District Six Museum to international visitors who want to broaden their understanding of brutal, modern-day South African history.

Wonderful tour - a must-see. My trip to Cape Town would have been incomplete without a wonderful guided tour of district 6. This great, quirky, informative museum should be on everyone's list of to-dos in Cape Town.

Something I will never forget. This museum is not highly publicised and given its location and size can easily be overlooked. We were asked if we wanted a guide, normally something I would avoid, but this is different. Our guide had lived in district six and gave us a personal account of his experiences. It was a harrowing, funny, beautiful, unique experience that makes you question what you think you might know.
Must see. Cape Town is one of our favourite cities in the world and a stop at this museum is a must-do to fully understand the complex history of the city and South Africa.
good history. interesting museum about forced removal of non-whites. There is a lot of detail about the removal and retribution of properties. Come ready to read.

Insight into important history. This small museum is a true living testimony to the people of South Africa. Although only two floors, the stories tell and thousand tales and are so moving. Excellent value and well worth a visit

Opened my eyes..... This wonderful museum is a tribute to the 60,000 men, women & children of District 6 who were forcibly removed from their homes, their social networks, their livelihoods, their culture. For the many visitors, like myself, unaware of this dark episode in relatively recent SA history it is a real eye-opener. Still, it is a story being repeated around the world today, not the least in my own backyard when this visit made me think about the forced relocation of the aged and long time residents in Millers Point in the historic Rocks area of Sydney. Different in scale on all levels to D6, but the same in our loss of such an important part of our historic fabric but never even to be remembered in a museum. But back to the D6 museum: to read the history of the area, to read the personal stories, to view the wonderful photographs of the residents at work, at school, at play, in their family groups and to meet some of the former residents is to start to realise what has been lost. The bulldozing of the homes and businesses and the dispersion of it's families has effectively been a cultural and social genocide. I only hope that the move to have D6 developed into a Memorial Park is successful. And no, I'm not your typical bleeding heart, but I found my visit to the Museum extremely moving.
Powerful experience. A powerful experience detailing some of the horrors of the apartheid regime. A must for all tourists; inexpensive, and well-presented.

Interesting history not much to see. The museum does depict the history but displays are limited. I would not recommend a special trip to visit the museum unless you are already in the area. Do by all means pop in.

Powerful experience, but wanted more. Pay the extra 15 Rand and get the guided tour by a former resident. Their personal stories are powerful. It's worth it because most of the museum is photos and placards. Budget about an hour to tour the museum.

Small but powerful. The District 6 museum is a small but powerful introduction and reminder of man's cruelty to man. The story of District 6 was brought to life by our docent - a resident who lived through that horror. It is well worth the small fee to have a genuine resident tell the District 6 story. There were tears in her and then our eyes as she shared some of her personal stories. Very sobering.

Something a bit different. As a family we found this small, yet powerful museum to be very interesting. The walls are covered in history, personal accounts, documents and lots of photography so you can spend as little or as much time as you like exploring.Visitors also have the option to join a tour by a former resident of the destroyed District Six, regrettably we did not have time however we overheard a tour that was being conducted and it sounded fascinating.

Excellent Tour. We were given a tour by Rosa. It was amazing She had lived in district 6 with her mother,father and siblings and explained the personal effects of apartheid on all citizens. It is a must see to learn about the history of cape town and very well done museum.

Well Done Museum--I learned a lot!. Prior to my trip to Cape Town, I only had surface level information on apartheid. I feel I learned more from this museum then I ever could in school. It was really fascinating as well as, disturbing how an entire neighborhood was demolished with people/families uprooted against their will-placed in segregated areas, their property destroyed without compensation and not that there needs to be an excuse but it was all for nothing. I really had no idea how badly the people of District Six were treated. I was touched by this museum and their history. I learned more here than Robben Island or any other museum in Cape Town. I also was able to meet a nice man in the gift shop whom was a former resident and wrote a book about his life. I was very impressed by this museum and will never forget! Thank you.
District Six Museum. A small museum but very informative and very powerful stories. I would recommend it but it does not take a great deal of time to go through.

Wonderful!. The museum is well laid out, and small enough that it feels intimate and won't take a long time to go through. We spoke to an old resident of District Six which was both moving and informative
Definite must when in Cape Town. It was awe inspiring the learn of the people who lived, loved and worked in District 6 and what apartheid did to them and their culture, really touching.

Cape Town History of the people.. This museum tells of the trials and tribulations the locals had to go thru to live in the downtown area of Cape Town. Take a good a lot of time to read and learn of the trouble these people had to go through to live close to their jobs.

Amazing and sad story. The museum did an excellent job of explaining what happened...then when we drove by the leveled area which had been District Six, we understood the loss the former residents felt. We then took a tour of one of the Townships and visited their Community Center and felt a little better. The children, the art and the warm feelings.... There were many nice small houses with solar power, some fancier ones with grass lawns for the professionals who have stayed in the Township in order to provide guidance and inspiration to the youth. We also saw the shacks of the new arrivals.
Put it on your list!. It's impressive and emotionally touching! The guide - an ex-prisoner - is so simple & nice! Please do it for your own culture and to known what happened there..

A small but important place.. It is a very good thing that this place has a museum, to explain how the apartheid government ripped it up. I saw a wonderful musical play/opera and being in the museum, which celebrates survival, was inspiring.

Experience of recent history. Why is the area of District Six so under-developed near the centre of Cape Town? We found out why here, the former church now turned into a museum. Inside, former residents relate their own stories about the forced relocations starting in the 1960s and their subsequent experiences from 1994 trying to get restitution. The floor is a map of the district before the bulldozers moved in, detailing street names, the houses and who lived in them: a rich mix of many racial types. Living history: a serious afternoon, with much to think about. Not really for very young children, as for most museums.

great setting, bad execution. we wanted a good understanding and over view of the history of district six. this did not happen. the guide was not good. he rambled on about matters not pertaining to the museum. lay-out of presentation was good.
Moving. We visited this wonderful little Museum before heading out to Langa Township. It set the scene well and was a peaceful place to sit and contemplate mans inhumanity to other men.

A lively experience.. Set in an old church hall, this place is well worth a visit. It's on the Yellow Tour Bus route. When we visited it was buzzing with tourists while locals from District 6 were telling their stories. The hall is bedecked with memorabilia from the area. It also tells a true story that is hard to believe really happened. Make sure you go!
Watch your Date. Disappointed to find it closed on a Saturday, the last day of our holiday.My fault - be warned - check out the opening times

Embarassing history. We did not have much time here due to circumstances beyong our control. We visited as part of a full day tour called The Walk to Freedom. It was harrowing to read how the white people decided to move 60k black, coloured and Jewish people from homes they had lived in for years and then demolish the homes so that houses for the white elite could be built. The stories of heart wrenching proportion and the sheer brutality on how it all took place made me ashamed to be white. Even now a lot of the land still stands empty covered to scrub and shadows where homes once were.

Hard to believe they really did that. I really enjoyed out visit. I do wish we had more time. The guide who spoke to our group was great. We left with a real sense of what it was like to be completely uprooted from your home and displaced. Wow.
Obligatory. Try to sign up for a tour with a private company which includes a tour of the museum and a visit to one of the nearby townships.

Small but insightful. This museum gives an insight into what happened in District 6. Although small, it leaves a lasting impression of the devastating effects Apatheid has had on the people of South Africa and of the country itself.

A Walk through History. This museum is very eye opening into the troubled past of South Africa. It really makes you think about all the hardship people of Cape Town went through. HIghly recommend if you enjoy museums and history.

Great for history buffs. This is a small museum but it tells the story about the forced government removal of residents in the District Six region through newspaper articles and first person narratives. You can take a guided tour with someone who experienced this removal if you like. District Six was a vibrant and multicultural district with a strong community spirit. It's unbelievable that the government chose to ruin such a great community.
Ok. A museum that teach you about the history of district 6 and how the white man take over the area. Give it 45 minutes, and your are full...

Sad reminder of cape town's past. Incredibly accurate and honest records of the apartheid days. Even more lively when explained by ex-residents of the area who have been ruthlessly moved out by a regime that did not care for them despite the evident hardship caused

A "must-do" to better appreciate Capetonians. My first visit. At first was a little surprised--and disaapoointed--with its size. But that soon changed upon being welcome by a gentleman who lived the annihilation of District Six. Seeing the artifacts and representations made me appreciate even more how horrific this displacement of Coloureds and Blacks during Apartheid.
Fascinating!. Everyone should go here, we really don't know much about South African history and it's not till you go to places such as this we learn the truth.
Eye opener. Although i have visited cape town more than 10 times, this was my first visit to district six museum. Lots of history and also explains the tolerance level of true cape tonians

So Sad. The District Six Museum tells the story of apartheid from the people and families that were affected. It was such a tragic period in history, but the victims showed their determination to rise above it. Their stories are very touching.
Interesting . Very insightful look at the history of the area through the tales of those directly affected by the forced relocation in South Africa.
Learn About Recent Cape Town History. This is especially useful for foreigners who might not be so familiar with what happened in District 6. The exhibits are well done, informative, and personal.

A tiny museum packed with lots of gems. The museum occupies two floors with its exhibits, hence, it should not take more than an hour to read through all the exhibits. Interesting layout of exhibits as every space is well utilised. Very information about the apartheid movement that took place in South Africa. I think this is one of the piece of puzzle that explains about the whole apartheid history to anyone who has no or little knowledge about the dark period in South Africa.

highly ecational and informative. I popped in for a quick visit before they shut- a fabulous museum with fascinating displays and very obviously knowledgable staff and fabulous local history and engagement informs the museum exhibits and displays- great to see such an emotional story told of these displaced communities, definitely a must see museum

an unfinished story. The apartheid city moved an entire vibrant community of mixed races out of the way so they could have more space for whites. In 1994 they reconsidered this, after they had destroyed all of the buildings, and allowed former residents to claim their properties back. But little has been done 20 years later, and the story does not complete this circle.

Recommend this as a must visit. Great place to read stories and learn about district six. The cafe attached does tasty snacks too. Recommend spending some time walking around and remembering those affected. Easy to get there using the hop on hop off bus

Very interesting. This is a must for visitors to Cape Town. It gives important insight to recent history and incredible politics. The exhibitions put things into prespective and speeks to both heart and mind.

Brings the South African struggle to life. The District Six Museum is a must! It bring apartheid to a more personal level. You can really see what happened to neighbors in District Six when apartheid became a reality.

Small but filled with intense history. The museum is small but a must see in Cape Town for all history buffs or for anyone really. The racial legacy of apartheid very much still hunts South Africa and this museum does a great job allowing visitors to experience this history.
History at District Six. It was a nice place to soak up a lot of history as it relates to Apartheid and how it affected the residents of that neighborhood at that time

Heartwrenching, but beautiful and VERY interesting. Different and specific!. Yep. They had a good thing going on. Cultural diversity, hipness, arty stuff. It all got plundered, but those voices still resonate. What I like about this place is that it's walkable from central Cape Town, and it doesn't reach past its own boundaries. It's the story of everyone, really, but they limit the story to what happened in this small neighborhood. The displays and presentation were extremely good. Relevant today, and the content would appeal to cross generational / cross-cultural audiences. I even bought the small book and READ it (I'm astounded, even). Finally ... it wasn't a total bummer. I couldn't live through hearing about Steven Biko's final hours over and over. It's just too much and too hard. This is sad, but not devastating. I got a lot out of how diverse District Six was and ... was lifted up by that.
A must for some background history. Really informative and not pushy. A great opportunity to chat with residents who were 'displaced'. A must for those who are interested in the history or Cape Town.

This is a must!. You really cant appreciate the struggles of apartheid until you see this exhibit at District six. Get a guide to explain the important features or you may miss things. Cape Town Tour Guides were great!

Insightful trip into CT and apartheid history. The museum gives much more than only the District 6 history, It gives a very good overview of the history and development of Cape Town, a illustrative insight of the way people lived and worked in that period, and a confrontation with the "apartheid" regime of the government, which is quite unbelievable in the passive and active cruelty.
School outing to museum for learners studying Bucking Palace District Six. Very helpful and interesting. More than just a museum. Found the map of the District with signatures very poignant.

Great History. Please go and take a look. You will get a good overview of South Africa's apartheid system and the heartbreak of our beautiful land - but we cannot escape it. So, as much as I personally don't like looking as some of the displays (because it hurts my heart that people were treated so appallingly), it is a good place to get an authentic look at our history.Let's educate ourselves and our youth and not do this kind of thing again. Apartheid is wrong.

Insightful. This museum gives one a glimpse of the joys and heartaches of the people who used to live in District Six. The museum guide is usually someone who lived in District Six prior to the evictions. A visit to this museum is at the same time sad, thought-provoking and enlighting. Go see for yourself :-)

Allow at least 2 hrs to go round. There is a floor map of District Six in the middle of the ground floor. Spend some time reading the handwritten notes from the people who lived there telling where their homes had been. The museum has original street signs from District Six and all around the walls are the stories of the families who lived there. Be sure to go into the little side rooms where you can see how people had furnished their homes and how they were proud of what they had and how sad it was taken from them. Go up to the second floor for yet more in depth stories of people's lives Very poignant and amazingly colourful. The photos are wonderful. There is a very good cafe which does fresh juices, sandwiches, samosas etc.

History of South Africa.. Very informative. Very well presented and a must to understand part of the history of South Africa. Decide to spend some time there and also a good idea is to buy a copy of District Six by Richard Rive

Best museum in Cape Town. The enforced ethnic cleansing of District 6 in 1966 is graphically displayed and leaves some visitors in tears. An indictment of apartheid and best combined with a tour of one of the townships perhaps before going to Robbin Island.

Make Sure To Get A Guide / Former Resident. Perhaps the highlight of our trip. When you go, absolutely pay the extra $1/$2 to have a former resident give you a tour and tell their stories of the district. Absolute must do. Can't recommend it enough

A must.... ...if you want to understand what has been and (hopefully) gone...touching and upsetting, but helps you admire the people who fought for their rights until the country woke up to human rights

Thought provoking and humbling. Visited on a tour. Was not sure how I would find it and it is upsetting to see just how badly people can treat other human beings but presented with a spit it of learning and looking forwards. Worth a visit.

Step back in the era of D6's hay days. Amazing museum, which feels as if you are walking in the streets of D6, and get a glimpse in the houses & work areas of the locals of 50 years ago. Colourful displays, very informative.

What an education.... I never really knew that much about apartheid and specific instances of how it imprisoned the local population. This well designed and deeply personal museum is a detailed overview of how one lively and close knit multicultural neighbourhood was destroyed and dispersed due to apartheid and Cape Town municipality's plan to build a physical 'buffer' between the white urban areas and the coloured areas. The tragedy is that the great plans the city had for this 'vacated' land never came to be. All was for not. Now former neighbours of District 6 are seeking compensation. This museum tells the fascinating stories of these neighbours who created this unique community. One story I remembered reading about was those people who created local hair salons. Some of the items like homemade curlers and brushes were so inventively created. The overall design of the museum feels like a cross between a regular museum and a personal homemade community potpourri of household items and memories. Loved the recreation of a real family's district 6 home.

A Must Visit. Thought provoking, upsetting, telling, emotional and essential. The story of District Six is central to the story of Cape town and the wider history of South Africa. I was humbled by the visit which was fascinating. This place really is a must visit if you are in Cape town. If you can, visit as part of a tour and you get the added information that easily puts everything into context. Plenty of pics up already so none from me.

Emotional center of continuing hope for resettling. It was interesting and quite impressive to see the amount of personal efforts and feeling that has gone into creating this museum. It is not big, but filled with all sorts of memorabilia of the old coloured district, furnished rooms, time-line of events, photos, maps and hand-written accounts. This is very much a museum by the people for the same people.

A lot to take in. There is indeed a lot to learn at this museum, even though I have quite a bit of knowledge on the Apartheid era. Well worth a visit, for people of all ages, but be aware it is a lot of reading (on billboard type things) as opposed to objects / artefacts. The café was lovely, the lady serving very friendly and funny! They even had soya milk which made my day - I did not expect to find it there! Highly recommend visiting the museum and then taking a walk up to Bo-Kaap (about 15 min walk) to view the colourful streets (also a very important era during Apartheid).And then if you're feeling peckish go to PLANT café (also within walking distance) - a completely vegan café.

Very moving. Well worth a visit to learn of the terrible fate of District Six. Lots of very moving stories which were interesting and thought provoking, however some more structure to the museum would have been helpful.

Educational Visit. We just walked around this smallish museum on our own without taking the tour and found the District Six story to be very enlightening. Definitely worth an hour or two to read about the tales and experiences of those who were displaced.

Sobering. It is worth spending time in this small museum which gives a thoughtful insight into the apartheid regime. As with much we found in South Africa, a history of inexcusable wickedness is told without bitterness.

Very enlightening. A really good combination of first a visit to Slave Lodge on the corner of Adderley & Wale St. followed by District 6 Musuem will give you a complete overview of the history of Cape Town. It's not only fascinating but thought provoking.. Lots of wonderful photos and room recreations and original text from the residents of District 6 and the importance of music, which played such an important part of the heritage of CT's inhabitants.

A DARK PART OF THE CAPE TOWN HISTORY. Even tough the museum is veru small. It needs several hours in order to grasp all the important messages and garsp the dark history of modern Cape Town. This is a must in Cape Town!

Waste of time. Although the story behind it was sad, its all about the interest and this place is completetly out of my interest. Learn more about here before you decide to go so you can plan your Cape Town visit more efficient.
A must see and very informative museum. We had a great tour of the museum given by a former resident of District 6, Noor who amazed us with his in-depth knowledge and passion.

history of aparthid. We visited this museum as part of the walk to freedom tour. It was a big eye opener and makes you see how the real africans were treated back in the day. It makes you realise how the brits and dutch dominated. For history buffs a great place to start.

Making History Come Alive. For anyone who wants to understand apartheid and how the majority population was kept back this museum is a must see. Like other museums in other parts of the world the District Six Museum brings the story into focus with personal tales

This is kind of a must visit while in Cape Town. In downtown. Small and interesting if want to learn about the apartheid.You can park on the street. Great coffee accross the street in TRUTH Restaurant.
Great!. Enjoyed getting the story of this historic place and seeing how it was -"back in the day". Lots of history and written articles to read.-Not a place to rush through!

A truly moving piece of history.. Small museum which was filled with moving memories. You could not stop reading the stories and thinking "mans inhumanity to man!" At just when you are in need of a pick me up, they have a superb cafe run by the most wonderful staff.
A human tragedy beautifully explained - and a great café. The title says it all, go and visit if you can and the ladies in the lovely café are simply wonderful and fun.
Very good overview of apartheid effects. This small museum shows concise snippets of how people lived and managed to work around the limits that apartheid created for the people.

Community Life History. It was a great experience. The exhibits give you a sense of the lives of the community and the people who lived in District Six. I loved that the exhibit space was in a church that had been part of the community.

Go before taking the Blue Line City Bus Tour. Visiting this museum before taking the Blue city tour bus is best as you will then understand the significance of the District 6 flats. The museum is quietly shocking, making us all understand the terrible events of the late twentieth century. There are so many personal stories confronting us with stories of loss and dislocation which for many if us from Europe, are pretty unthinkable.

Fantastic mueseum. I don't normally go to museums but this one is very cool. It tells the story of district 6 in a very personal and interesting way. Doesn't take very long and is a big event in SA history.

Unique museum with fascinating history. Small museum, not easily distinguishable from the outside. Inside it's probably worth paying for the tour guide for their anecdotes and information. Making your way around the museum by yourself might be a bit confusing. Just stories and relics from the old District 6, gives you an insight into how things were back then. Good for those interested in history.
Disappointing. I thought this museum was poorly put together for what is an interesting subject. I acknowledge however that they had a limited budget.

Emotional Day. You don't quite understand the history of South Africa, and the impact of apartheid affecting the different races until you visit this museum; get ready for an emotional day !!You are greeted by a huge map on the floor of the museum of the district as you walk in, and a narration of the life histories of the District Six residents on the walls.
Thought provoking. Very interesting visit. Many photos.So sad that such a vibrant, diverse and harmonic community was ripped apart.

Tragic history told by an interesting little museum. District Six has a tragic history that I was unaware of before coming here. But this informative little museum is very well put together. You won't find any state of the art interactive exhibits. Instead there are a collection of pictures, possessions and stories of the people who lived it. Just a couple of stops on the HOHO yellow line bus from Long Street will bring you straight here. A very reasonable 28 rand each (2 rand off for having a HOHO bus ticket). Good cake too in a cute little cafe too.Iain, London

A real eye opener. This place reduced us to tears. Very sad but a must see when in Cape Town if only to get Reference as to why you drive past the Cape Flats townships on your way in from the airport. And it all happened so recently. Frightening.
Worth a stop on bus tour. Interesting to get a better understanding of apartheid.History buffs will enjoy. It was amazing the diversity of people who lived there
Very interesting. I enjoyed my visit here to read about the history of the area and the details of some of the things that happened during apartheid. The coffee shop is a must visit!

Fascinating insight into the history of District six. Enjoyed looking at all the photos and information on the history of district six. History of Cape Town going back hundreds of years and notable dates

Wonderful Cultural Experience. Visiting the museum gave us a wonderful view point of what is was like living in district six and being from Cape Town we were able to relate to a few of the items displayed.
District 6. A very interesting place. We took our 3 young kids, to help them understand a little about apartheid. Definitely worth a look around.

Small, but very informative. We walked past this place and decided to have a look inside. Didn't regret that, as this tells the sad story about District 6 in Cape Town. I was not so familiar with what happened in this specific neighbourhood, but this small museum gives a good insight on what happened. Sad stories, but very interesting to read. There is almost to much information inside to go through.We arrived very close to closing time and therefore were asked to make a donation instead of paying the entrance fee. This was very kind and service minded.

Sad but real. Coming to Cape Town and South Africa is a complicated venture. This is a country with a past and of course it needs to be addressed. District Six Museum is one such place. It is well done and an important part of Cape Town's history.

Sad !!!. Did not really understand why Cape Town had an area called District Six..but now we know. How badly and shameful the people in this area were treated.The documentation and pictures really bring home the problems the people suffered and made us wonder had those problems really disappeared.... quite heartbreaking.

Lots of information to read. The museum is very informative, and, as a history lover, I wanted to read everything, but there was simply too much. I wish I could have digested everyone's story. Make sure you take some time to read the embroidered canvas--you can't miss it. The cafe inside is also a must. At least get a coffee. I had the best veggie wrap of my life there.

Very interesting. We have visited this museum on three different occasions and our best guide was someone who was personally affected by the problems. Much of the museum is self explanatory, but a good guide makes it VERY much more meaningful and interesting.
Great recount of what happened . The museum showed numerous historical recounts of people that used to live in District 6 before being moved. There are a ton of pictures and a lot of reading.

Tiny but thought provoking. Really interesting very small, but definitely worth 30 minutes if you are in the vicinity, tells the story of the forced evictions, and has a great map to show the street plan

Great detail on the history and impact of District 6. We dud not have long to visit but were very impressed by the variety of exhibits and detail in the form of real life stories shared. It us possible to book tours with an experienced guide.
What a history lesson. My group was honored to have Mr. Schaffer (one if the original inhabitants of district six) give us his account of such a painful and traumatic experience.

Moving and painful. A must see. Painful to see what happened to a once vibrant and diverse community, but also lovely to see the memories preserved in photos and testimonies of former residents pushed out by apartheid and economic greed. A tribute to a past when all different kinds of people lived and flourished together.

Very thought provoking visit. I wanted to visit this for a long time. We paid R45 per person to have a tour with a former resident of District 6 which was worth it, as we received insight and heard stories that brought fact to life.It is very hard to hear some stories as they are hard to hear and all in our life time - yet I knew nothing of what happened hear. This is an important visit to do alongside Robbin Island. A must do visit whilst in Cape Town. Lots of well displayed boards and the building set out in an interactive way. Do though go one step further and get a guide.

Excellent tour of the museum highly recommended.. This museum is only small yet contains and displays so much information. As it has been said before, if you want to avoid getting a little dizzy with all that is on display in the museum, then we strongly recommend doing the tour conducted by one of the former residents of District Six. We had a lovely lady called Ruth as our tour guide, wow it was both so informative and moving. Her passion for the area shone through and Ruth's own story was very touching and emotional, made it more real to us. It exceeded our expectation and we strongly recommend visiting this little gem when in Cape Town!

pause for reflection. An educational experience as we learned of the hardship and injustice brought upon so many by the oppressive apartheid regime. Difficult to imagine the reality of being comprehensively uprooted. Reminded me of scenes of the holocaust during WW2.

Too much. This museum had so much information and it was so out of context, all the time.I felt lost from the beginning. I didn't know where to start so I started where it felt logical. But it wasn't logical because the info there didn't make sense - it was like jumping into the middle of a dramatic movie. Then I realized there weren't any start, beginning, finish or middle at all. There were small pieces of everything in every part of the museum.If you don't feel like spending three hours just reading your way through facts you don't know where to put, I wouldn't recommend it. However, the way this museum has encourages and interacts with ex-residents of District Six is great.

Very Insightful!. Excellent set up! The floor map, right at the entrance was very impressive. Plenty of facts, educating one about the history of Capetown and South Africa as a whole, well documented and easily accessible to patrons. Would've loved to spend more time taking in all the information made available. Will definitely visit this museum again!

Rewards some patience!. Not quite waht I was expecting - but possibly because it's not that well signposted in terms of which route to take around the museum. The stories and information boards are very dense and repetitive at times, and I could understand some people (especially children) giving up after a while, but some of the personal domestic stories, expecially those upstairs, reward the effort! Probably worth spending the extra to hear from an ex-resident, or even a walking tour of the District as it is now. I would have liked to know what is being done now, or what is planned, in terms of regneration.

Could have been much better. We had high expectations when visiting District Six Museum. We had heard a lot about the museum and our guide book even recommended this museum before going to Robben island. It was, however, a disappointment! Much to much information, very unstructured, even hard to follow the time line that was depicted on the ground floor. A guided tour might have been better.
New Year 16. Very informative staff and well presented history of the events relating to District 6 Take your time, there is alot to absorb. Small snack bar at rear with wi-fi and friendly staff.
Very Interesting!. This museum was hot when we went with one, little fan for the whole former church building. I didn't stay as long because it was so hot.

Great experience!. Really enjoyed our visit to District Six Museum especially the personal tour hosted by individual who lived the experiences of being relocated from District Six. Make sure you pay a little extra for this personalized tour - well worth it!

Worn. Needs support from the citty.. District 6 disappeared due to studied municipal discrimination and avoidance. This museum seems to be headed the same way. Nevertheless, you can learn all about District 6 here -- it's still an issue as a drive-by will show. Not be be missed. Needs air-conditioning.

An eye opener !. Firstly, this is a exhibit showing the worst side of South Africas past, but once you get past that this place is humbling, informative and one you have to visit when in Cape Town.Firstly the exhibits take you through the history of District 6 with fantastic graphics boards photos and films.The highlight is to meet the presenter of the museum in person and you meet a man who lived in District 6 before being repatriated and he will tell you all about his childhood , his experiences and most importantly it is all done with no bitterness but a humbling description of how life was for him and his family and his hope for the future.Finally you MUST visit the coffee shop to find the 2 ladies who run it, as its a real treat as again they have lived the horrors, but they are filled with laughter and humility and make the trip thoroughly worthwhile.
Interesting. Easy to get to, good cafe, lots of information and pictures. Museum is about a district being destroyed and residents relocated.

Interesting Museum: skip the guided tour. This museum porvides an excellent glimpse at the workings of apartheid in the old South Africa. The exhibits are well displayed and numerous pictures and a collection of original road signs bring the events of the previously known area of District Six to life.It is well worth a visit. Unfortunately we opted for a guided tour of " District Six" which was a waste of time. There is no " District Six remaining so there is nothing to see on the tour except new buildings.Save your time for the museum itself....its worth it.

An indictment of apartheid. It is one thing to be removed from your home because it is unfit for human habitation and relocated in superior accommodation, but the tragedy of District Six is on another plane. The museum is full of moving stories of those who were removed from their homes so that the area could be zoned for whites only.It is then compounded when you go to look at the heart of the area and realise that nothing followed the demolition of the houses. What a waste of resources in the name of apartheid.In my view, visitors should try to include this venue in any Cape Town visit.

A required stop in Cape Town. This museum honors those whose homes were destroyed during the Apartheid era, and does so beautifully and respectfully. A tour from Noor Ephriam, whose house was one of those torn down, shows the power of resilience and forgiveness.

A necessary part of a visit to Capetown. I felt embarrassed as a white man by what I saw and heard at this museum - but it is the reality of what apartheid was - and I'm glad I went and learned what I did.

Depressing. What it honours was beyond stupid, pointless and evil. I'm not sure there's a way to recognize such idiocy but the exhibit is low key, not very informative but as there is no charge, might be worth a look

Historical Events of Apartheid Told From Personal Stories. The District Six Museum is well advertised as an activity to be seen in Cape Town. Historical events of Apartheid are told through personal stories and pictures documenting the years of culture and eventual eviction. There are guides available to expand on the written and pictorial displays.

A living museum telling a moving story. . Very moving tribute to the memory of those affected by the relocations. The museum tells the story in a very personal way, using people's own words and experiences combined with contemporary accounts through newspapers etc.A living museum that continues to collect real life stories.

Must visit for history of apartheid in Cape Town. Excellent museum giving history and insight into how apartheid affected non whites in Cape Town. Local people who were affected gives guided talks throughout the day.
Interesting.. It was very moving to read the stories of people and see the pictures. You can be shown round by a resident or walk round yourself.
Opens the mind. This certainly opened my eyes to the atrocity of the event. I would recommend that every south african visit this museum to get a real perspective of what occurred.

A must do when visiting Capetown. District 6 museum allows you an insight into the terrible past of Cape Town, but it also leaves you with hope for the future. People were once very integrated and district 6 was a hub for many different nationalities, religions etc giving rise to a vibrantly diverse community.
