This place feels like a healing place. What's nice is that you have one of the rare, dwindling opportunities to talk to someone who really lived through the tragedy. You rarely get the chance to sit down and talk to someone about what it was like. At this museum, one of the people whose house was actually razed sits down with you and tells you the story and you can ask questions. It was a very moving experience.
Small but well worth a visit. The details in this museum bring home the dreadful reality of apartheid and the inhumane treatment of people simply because of the colour of their skin.
Numbing experience. A visit to this museum is a must to see how bad recent history was in Cape Town. If it does not give a lump in the throat I would be surprised.

Understanding apartheid. OK - in all honesty, I was concerned visiting South Africa because of its history. Those concerns did not disappear at all as we drove around the country noting rather horrifically the differences between Afrikaner and African housing, employment and other signs of inequality. The District Six Museum not only provides so many answers to questions about apartheid, its past and the lingering problems of the present, but does so from the position of victims, not the powerful. They say only the winners get to write history. This museum shows you what it looks like from the other side. Be prepared to listed to personal stories, cry, hold hands with strangers, hug and kiss them as they tell their stories of violent removal, displacement, fear, loss, and pain. It helped me to deal with my personal concerns as there were very few opportunities to talk about SA's past with locals. This is a MUST see for all visitors to SA.
Essential part of any visit to Cape Town. The museum is small but packed with fascinating insights into the lives of those who were forcibly removed from the area.

Good Experience, unstructured though - recommend outsiders read up before. This is a potent memorial, but as an outsider/foreigner, I was very grateful to have read even the wikipedia page before heading in. There's little structure to the method of information dissemination, and without a framework for what happened in the sixties, the museum can definitely lose its impact. It seems to be a museum designed more as a memorial and for South Africans than tourists, though I think even with a summary board or intro info panel, it could be a great destination for all. Still, very worth seeing, especially if you are staying in District Six as a tourist.

Well Done Small But Impactful Museum. This was well worth the visit and was included on my half day township tour with African Eagle day Tours. There is a lot in this small but well thought out museum. It gives the visitor a very informative and impactful vision of District 6 and the affect apartheid had on the community and it's people.

Great insight. Smallish museum but packed with the history of the "cleansing" of the district six area fifty years ago .Met Joe Schaffers at the door who gave us a good insight as to how it was when he lived there.TipHave a sandwich or snack in cafe at the back, the lady in charge there is worth the visit alone, she is an absolute hoot!

A unique view into the city's recent history. This museum is worth a visit since it offers a community-based presentation of the impact of South Africa's recent history on the District Six neighborhood of Cape Town. It is located in a beautiful space full of what feel like very personal displays. The museum's cafe is also lovely.
Informative, moving. We visited this museum today and found it both fascinating and powerfully moving as well. Would highly recommend a visit.

Should be seen. This museum is a place that should be visited. It gives you a better understanding of the history of the city. You can understand better the current day tensions and the devastating effect of the rules and actions of the then government.
A very recent history . An important place to visit to get a stark reminder of how recent events in South Africa have shaped what you currently experience. Well worth a visit.

Revelation of history. Do not miss. Excellent museum to visit if you want to learn more about the forced removals from District Six in the apartheid years. Make use of a tour guide who will be an ex resident of District Six. Great informative personal stories

Emotional and informative. The District Six Museum was established in 1994 and focused on telling people the stories of forced removals. It also tells the story of assisting in the reconstitution of the community of District Six. The museum offers a glimpse into the lives of the residents and gives you a sense of the history of the place. Guided tours are done by people who have lived in District Six in those trying times. Personal stories make the tour especially emotional and special. Guided tours of District Six are offered and they are also conducted by ex-residents. I recommend that you buy tickets at the door. If you plan on doing the walking tour through District six I highly suggest u take sunblock, a hat and some water. Ask your guide for an umbrella
Enlightening and emotional. A great museum,better experience as the tour guide is an ex resident of district six,heartwarming experience, P.S. Ruth is a great tour guide

Great place to learn apartheid history. We hadn't planned on seeing this museum but our guide suggested it. I am so glad he did! Very interesting exhibits that really bring history to life. Amazing stories that tug on your heartstrings and help you understand what the residents of District 6 went through. Don't miss this if you're in Cape Town.
Meeting Mr. Noor. Mr. Noor was relocated from his home in District 6 through Apartheid. He gives tours of District Six Museum and shares his personal experiences with you.

Emotional, Informative, Thorough. The curators of this museum have done a wonderful job of piecing together the history of a small town that had been razed to the ground. This would have been an enormous task and I credit them for their sense of history. A memorial to the suffering of those residents of the original District Six, the museum provides insight into the landscape, families, artefacts, and politics at work at the time. No doubt, there are many who would like this part of South African history to be erased. But stay, it should, as a reminder that our greatest enemy can be ourselves.We were fortunate to enjoy a guided tour by Ruth, an original resident of District Six, whose personal account was both emotional and empowering. The scars of the recent past are not hidden in this museum and, if you've done your research before attending, it will hit home how brutal apartheid really was. If you are attending as a casual observer, most of the significance may be lost on you. Go. Be ready to ask questions. Think long and hard about the answers.

Well worth the visit. District Six Museum is quite small but well worth the admission fee. The exhibition is a brilliant way to get to understand the ramifications of the apartheid policy that forced thousands of people to be removed from their homes and relocated. A very moving and poignant tribute.

Informative and emotional. Learning more about how heartless we can be to our fellow human beings is so sad. I keep hoping that by learning more we can not make the same mistakes over and over again, The museum informs you about the viable though poor neighborhood that was totally destroyed because of the policies of Apartheid. It teaches who were affected and who were spared and makes parallels with some of Hitler's policies during the beginning of the Nazi era.
Small but impactful. I really enjoyed this museum as it was so effective at conveying it message in a small space. If only every museum could be so well curated.

A Sobering Experience. I visited this museum recently after hearing about it from a Hop-On Hop-Off Bus tour, It is an interesting museum in that its exhibits are largely based on the artifacts and stories of individual families who used to live in District 6. It is not a big museum. It is set up in a former church and has two narrow balconies on the second floor and a large open space below. The focus is on the many individuals who made District Six such a rich multicultural community and the heart-ache caused when people had to leave there homes and be transported miles away from the areas and people they had always known. Many of the artifacts have been donated by families or made up by members of the community eg banner and paintings. I found it very moving and enlightening.

A glimpse at the past. Mark Twain once said: History doesn't repeat itself - it rhymes. One of the things history endows us with is humanity - the power to look at ourselves and learn from our mistakes and correct them for a better tomorrow. The District 6 Museum is one of those museums that not only educate and give us a lesson in the past but most importantly it helps us learn to better ourselves as a human race by teaching us about the infractions of the past and we can transcend these.
A real insight into the history of south africa. Came here in 2007 and again now in 2015, very interesting to see how the post apartheid era has treated these people so little progress

Recent Cape Town history, well reflected. When visiting Cape Town, it is significant to reflect on our country's recent history and current progress towards an inclusive, progressive society. The District Six Museum has helpful staff, poignant illustrations and is easy to access.

Good museum, excellent tour. The district six museum is a good museum, but what made our visit exceptional was the tour guide we had. She was very knowledgeable, kind and shared her personal horrible experience of being evicted from district six. It was a memorable visit. We would definitely recommend this museum, and make sure you ask for a tour of the museum, as you get much more out of it then!

Brings to life the reality of apartheid. We visited the museum the day after we had done a walking tour of District 6. It was a very moving experience to learn how so many people were ousted from the homes they had lived in for generations. The museum brings to life the reality of what took place.

History in the heart of Capetown. Hopefully by now you have already booked a downtown hotel and are shopping and eating at the local places instead of the V&A Waterfront tourism eyesore. If so, you are right in the vicinity of this fantastic museum which addresses a milestone in Capetown History. Add this to the Slave Quarters Museum around the corner and drop in Truth Coffee Works for lunch inbetween, and you have yourself a great day of indepth history that is walkable from any downtown hotel or hostel.

Utterly moving experience. We spent a few hours here and easily could have spent more. It was a really moving experience. Hard to imagine it having happened and really interesting to find out that something similar happened in Malmo

Museum highlights human impact. Failed social planning moving 60,000 people into ghetto. Much of area is still barren 50 years later. Museum is small. Many family pictures and personal stories. Tend to get lost in stories if you do not know local names or the history of the event. Worth a stop. Less than an hour needed. On the yellow tour bus route which ran reliably. Close to the Castle of Cape Hope which is also worth a quick stop.

Never knew this story. Tragic story of a community destroyed by Apartheid. The docents are former residents. The story are sad and the future is unsure. The victims stories enriched my understanding of Cape Town today.

interesting.. We were apart of a conference group which had their own tours & visiting the District 6 Museum was apart of our Township tour. The District Six Museum was opened in 1994 for memories of the 60,000 people who were forcibly removed & the terrible destruction of their houses being torn down by heavy handed bulldozers.District 6 Museum entrance fee is R30 per person. Its located at 25A Bultenkant Street in Cape Town. Opening hours - 9am - 4pm Monday to Saturday. Tours are available with former residents of District 6. Tickets can be brought online.

Excellent community museum teaching you about the past but also looking to the future. This museum explains the forced removal of people from District Six in Cape Town during the 1960s, there are sections which highlight different aspects of the lives of the community (their work, music, hairdressers...!) which really helps you to relate to the community that lived there and their way of life, and the devastation of the removals.They also offer tours guided by an ex-resident of District Six who lived through the removals. I'd highly recommend this. You get to see the local area and get a feel for how it was and how it is now as well as getting a personal insight into what happened.Overall I felt this museum and tour gave an excellent insight into the era of apartheid (even more than a visit to Robben Island) as well as a feeling of positivity to the future as the community came together to share their memories of the District not only with each other but with us too.The cafe there is also amazing, my friend and I got given nicknames by the lovely lady here within a minute of arrival! Bobotie wraps definitely worth a try (delicious Cape Malay food!) as well as the traditional koeksisters wrapped in coconut. Such a friendly place and we left as friends (if not family!).

Must Go!. You have to come to this museum to learn about the lives of people that were uprooted from District 6! Their way of lives, stories and artefacts made the museum interesting. Cater about an hour here if you want to have a good read on most of the banners. Museum is about 10 minutes walk from long street.
Impressive!. It's good to remember al what happened and take care it will never happen agian! A good guide helps a lot. We had one from the township Langa.

A walk through the history of the forced removal of families of District 6. Quite incredible to take a peak into the history of District 6, you learn so much, the make up of the community of the District 6, the community atmosphere that existed, our guide was an ex- resident of District 6 that really bought it all to life. You felt propelled back to a point in time that where just for a moment you became a resident and wanted to fight with the people to keep their homes.

Fascinating Visit. This was a very interesting museum - packed with wonderful information. Fascinating really. As a child I remember the News reports about District 6 being bulldozed and all the people losing their homes.

Interesting history of District Six. The museum tracks the history of District Six, and highlights the destruction of the once vibrant area by the apartheid authorities.Much of the narrative is provided by tracking the lives of specific people in the community.It is possible (for a small fee) to sit and talk to one of the original inhabitants of the community.

Cry, my beloved country.. As an Afrikaans speaking white local tourist who learnt from newspapers and radio news of District Six's forced removals as a very young child, I found this museum filling in the holes of my education. I love the old church it is situated in, I love the combination of old photographs and narratives and the general quietness inside, as if we, as tourists, by being there and observing relive what the original residents experienced.There is a nice tearoom and clean facilities as well, a tourist is always looking for that! Definitely worth a visit for local and overseas visitors. It is situated near the Fugard Theatre so, if you are booked for a matinee performance visit the museum before going to the show. The well known coffee shops TRUTh and HAAS is also in this street.

Informative. The museum tells the story of district six very well and we found it to be more organized than some of the other museums we visited. It's heartbreaking to learn how the residents were treated; however, the signs of reconciliation are hopeful. A great experience.

An interesting yet devastating history story.... Ex -District 6 guides are available to tell their personal stories of how it was to be forcibly removed from their homes. The same homes that had been in their families for generations were bulldozed to the ground. There is all sorts of memorabilia. I felt it an honour to have visited this monument.

A piece of history. This was the first museum we visited in Cape Town and gave us a good understanding of what had happened to District 6. The museum is in a beautiful old church and is filled with stories and belongings of the people most affected by the decision to destroy this area of the city. A very worthwhile museum to visit during your time in Cape Town.

Powerful Impact. Learning the history here was an emotional experience.If you think racism is evident in US it was/is even more prevalent as you will learn from his museum. Lots of untold history that you don't get from books. Take your time and read the postings.
Very informative. Very cool museum that explains what happened in District Six. The cafe also is very good and really cheap.

The Truth shall set you free!. Godbless the families of District Six for not letting the world forget their horrific plight in the hands of pure Evil. This is an intimate museum and you feel the closeness of what was once a vibrant thriving community just literally wiped off the face of the earth! Very Powerful and allows you to process the information at your own pace. Actual District Six family members work at and support this education for the world. Never forget!
You must visit. A small museum packed with information, worth a visit to understand how apartheid impacted on the lives of named people from District Six.
a bit dusty. not very instructive ( we much more preferred the Slave House Museum), with no clear path... More a souvenir place than a museum.

Its was Interesting. I had already been to Nelson's museum in Johannesburg so I had already learned about the history. It's good for what it is - not set up as nice as other museums but you can read stories of people.
A must do. An amazing part of history of which I was aware until visiting Cape Town it is a sobering exhibition and to understand the history of South Africa you must attend

A must do! BUT.... District Six is definitely an interesting start (and a must) to understand the history of Cape town and South Africa through the eyes on the coloured community BUT... it has so much information, is not the best in terms of organisation of information... We decided to do the tour without a guide. A would definitely recommend hiring a guide (ex-resident of District Six). I guess that is the key to a clear understanding of this highly important museum.

An excellent insight into District Six, worth a visit!. This museum is small but very informative and well worth a visit. Lots of very interesting information, pictures, and artefacts, and very informative and interesting staff. Right in the centre of District Six, it's easily accessible by foot or public transport.

Very Sobering. You learn about how these poor people lost their homes and shifted to townships miles away just because the area was needed to build new homes for the whites. How streets were demolished. Definately worth a visit.

Everyone should go here!. The District 6 museum told me a story that I did not previously know. It is albout the clearance of the indigneous (coloured) inhabitants in this district of Cape Town in the early period of apartheid. It was to make space for white workers to live nearer the city.Whole communities were uprooted, and their homes razed to the ground (except the religious buildings, which were a step too far even in those days)The museum is dedicated to the events surrounding District 6, and its people, and tells a heart-rendering story. The museum itself is not large - but its contents are and its story is powerful. It is something that every visitor to South Africa would benefit from seeing.I once went to a concentration camp. That was a mind-numbing experience, and of course not comparable to here. But, at the gates of that camp, there is a statue with a two-word message at the bottom which I believe does apply. The words 'Never Again'

A must for every visitor. This moving museum is dedicated to the families that were transported to the townships during apartheid. Insightful and informative..a real learning opportunity. Don't miss this key element of Cape Town's history...a scar in the beauty of the city and country side.

A must-experience in Cape Town. This was a gut-wrenching visit, but one we can not imagine missing. District Six was a multi-ethnic neighborhood in Cape Town where all of the residents were forcibly evicted as part of apartheid. We *strongly* recommend calling ahead and reserving a tour of the museum with someone who actually lived in the neighborhood (our guide even moved back a couple of years ago). There are not many people left who can offer this kind of living history and you owe it to yourself to hear what they have to say.
Essential to undestanding. Allow at least an hour, preferably more. And try to see it in a wider context of the city's history. Tearoom great, lovely ladies

Very moving exhibition and look back to the past. There are guided tours available, lead by ex residents of district six. We had not planned our visit so it did not co-inside with a tour. Next time I would definitely do a tour, some of which are "walking tours" The exhibition was great, nicely laid out, and easy to follow. Lots of interesting article and information to read, as well as interesting photos of the area from the past.We spent about 45 min in the museum, and left feeling very sombre. Very interesting.

Eye opening . Wow a visit here is a cultural must. The information provided and the background stories are beyond belief. If you want to know more about South Africa put this on your must visit list. Very moving

So interesting. Fabulous insight into the terrible times that Cape Town has weathered through. A really personal exhibition about the experiences that the District 6 community went through. I found it very moving

District Six Museum. Not a big impersonal museum, this one is intimate, and very human - evocative even emotional. Before visiting the museum I knew little to nothing of the District 6 story but even so I found the exhibit to be profoundly moving especially in view of what District 6 later became (essentially empty grassland).
Worth a visit. Very interesting exhibit that shows some of the devastating actions of the apartheid government. Great to see lots of school groups visiting as well.
An interesting museum. So much to see, so much to take in, very interesting, could have stayed longer, many peoples memories.

a good history of the area. This museum is well worth a visit, unfortunately we were too late to take a tour as that would have been very interesting. Nevertheless the man on admissions was very informative. You certainly get a good sense of the social history.

Go meet the people of District Six. This museum was absolutely a highlight of my time in Cape Town, and I really appreciated the opportunity to meet and experience District Six through a guide who actually lived there. Apartheid has had a very real impact on the people of South Africa, and to hear the stories of what happened in District Six and the impact has made a lasting impression I'll never forget. Thank you Ruth for sharing your personal story - It was a pleasure to meet you, and I hope you record your experiences for generations to come.

Interesting. I found this museum very interesting although there was a lot of information to read on the lower floor. It was a bit of a mix of the history of District 6 and also South Africa generally political wise. I didn't see all the museum because I came downstairs and the guy abruptly said 'we are closed' I said 'do you want me to leave?' Yes he said. He was still busy and could of let me finish off but I didn't bother. Its worth a look, but go early so you don't get shoved out the door!

Memorable museum moments. We did a tour with Noor Ebrahim, a district 6 resident, which was enlightening. Although it is a relative small museum you get a very good impression about the history of this district.

Great museum. The museum is small, yet has so much history and information. We had a guided tour from a gentleman who had lived in District Six and gave personal accounts of the time. A must visit, for sure!
Small yet fascinating musem. This small museum is really one of the best museums in Cape Town. It gives you a very good idea of what the District 6 was before being destroyed. It is also very cheap.

Best museum in Cape Town. This museum is really compelling. Not a museum in the traditional sense. More a building which contains loads of testimonials and old photos of what District 6 used to look like.

A Moving Story. This museum tells a powerful story in South Africa's history. There is a certain rawness to the museum, which is inspiring. These are the stories of the time and the emotion of the people comes through clearly. It leaves you questioning many aspects of the apartheid policy and why it was thought to be good public policy. I am pleased that I visited this museum.Thanks for your vote if you found this review helpful.

Should be compulsary ?. We visited the museum as part of a full day tour of District 6 and townships.The museum is small and quite low tech with lots of display boards and written testimonials and photographs of Life under apartheid , we had a guide which really brought the history to life and added richness to the experience .I left feeling very positive despite feeling guilty about the English colonial history . If the Mandela story and the rebirth of RSA was a work of fiction you wouldn't believe it ! Happily its all true and its wonderful .We would not have missed this part of the trip for anything

Sensitively curated, fascinating and heartbreaking.. Friendly and unobstrusive staff, memories which are imaginatively collated and collected and displayed. A lovely café as well. Must see in Cape Town.

Small but powerful. The museum is a former chapel used by the locals of District 6. Because of its size, there aren't that many things inside the museum which tell the story but definitely worth doing if you want to understand the story of District 6. You are able to get guided tours from former residents which I strongly advise.

This is my heritage. I've always wanted to show off my heritage to my significant other, and when I got the chance, I did just that. Time has wiped out so many aspects of who we are but thanks to the D6 museum, I can go and see my grandpa in one of the Christmas choir photos. I can see the Christmas band my great grandfather formed. My family's history is there, alive, and preserved.How do I feel? Choked up, proud, sad, determined...because this is my children's heritage, and without D6, it will not survive.

Moving! A terrible story well told.. The photos, letters and other memorabilia inna rather small place really sends a strong message of the injustice and inequities that prevailed during the apartheid regime.

History told by the people who lived it. Entrance is 30 zar, for 15 extra you get a guided tour. The guides are local people who lived in the district before they were driven out and they houses were demolished. Very interesting.

Reason Behind District Six. Easy walking distance from any hotel near the Green Market area. If you plan to visit the museum save at least two hours to take in all the information that led up to the removal of the people who once lived in District Six. The museum has many original artifacts from the people who were affected. You will see how their life was changed forever. Some of the employees working in the museum lived in this area and can tell you their own story.

Ok museum in a district filled with sadness (take a tour to make it a 5* experience). This is a small museum and, alone, it only hints at the sadness of what happened in District 6. However, if you take a guided tour with one of the people who was personally affected by the forced removals of people from their homes, it takes on a personal meaning -- I was left with tears in my eyes, it was just so touching. I recommend visiting here if you want to understand a bit about the Old South Africa and what apartheid meant for those who were forced to move from their homes.

Heart breaking exhibit but could be better organized. This museum has so much potential to be incredibly powerful and moving. But it was hard to follow and the information wasn't presented in a way to get people really engaged with the heart breaking and overwhelming story they were trying to get across.

Spend some time here. We visited this museum as part of a township tour so our time here was limited. Very interesting & sad, many stories of courage & hope. Historical memorabilia, photos, newspaper articles and hand written accounts from former residents of District 6. Quite overwhelming.

Amazing. Excellent-Get the guided tour-worth the 5 euros! So much history through the pictures, the music, the literature, the recipes! Anyone interested even just slightly in the history of modern day South Africa must go. Give yourself a good 1-2 hours.

A must see. I learned about this museum from a free walking tour I had done around Historical Cape Town.This museum contains lots of information about life in District 6 and the forced removals. Get full insight of life here from the guides available at the museum. It is hard to believe what South Africans experienced under Apartheid. This is definitely a must see.
Interesting and eye opening. Glad we took time to visit to get insight into the history of what happened here. We must not forget. Take tour for some extra insight. Highly recommend a visit

not to be missed. Excellent museum, full of history. We really appreciated this place and the memories shared by the people who lived during such horrible times. You can spend a long time exploring this museum and learning about the people in District Six.

Sad, but a must see. One of the must see's if you're in Cape Town for the first time. The story told here isn't extremely well known outside of South Africa. Informative, well put together. Make sure that you take time to at least chat with the employees, or better yet, hire one to take you around and tell you their story. I thoroughly enjoyed chatting with Noor.

Out and About in Cape Town. A smallish museum with lots of information about the history of District Six, forced removals, happy times, sad times.. Ons can feel the pain in some of the material presented, but also the joy that the folks experienced despite the opressive system of apartheid. One cannot even relate to the suffering and hardship of the communities. One gets a raw insight in those times. A must see.

Enhanced our understanding. Not to be missed if you want to understand recent political evolution. Some haunting old images. Clearly part of the local education syllabus, too; when we were there there were a number of school groups.

Not to be missed to understand the effects of apartheid. The museum is set in a church and you can feel the community behind that helped create the museum with photos and objects donated by the inhabitants of District Six. It is very informative and about something that most of us would not have heard of. Very heart-breaking too especially the book with handwritten names and addresses of people from District Six who came to the museum.
A place not to miss.. Excellent small museum detailing the lives of the local people over the decades. Many photographs of families depicting their way of life.
Interesting. Very well kept museum. Interesting artefacts and history. Small but you can spend hours roaming around. Staff is very friendly and helpful.

Important to Understanding Apartheid. This is not a glitzy, polished museum but it conveys the history and the agony of the demolishing of this neighborhood and the displacement of families, on the "whim" of the white majority. A must see - take some time to read and begin to understand

Very helpful history for understanding Cape Town and the existing townships lying adjacent to the town.. In attempting to understand the recent past of Cape Town during Apartheid and the removal of people from this entire district for relocation to an outlying township, District Six Museum is a very good stop. Incorporated are signs and memorabilia from the District that have been incorporated into a tapestry of memories by former residents. Some of it may be difficult to comprehend for the younger set, but it is always good to try to remember.
Interesting history. A small museum which took me a little while to find. You don't need long there and the history is really interesting and important in the evolution of Cape Town - worth visiting.

Not sure what to make of it!!!. I went to the District Six Musuem to see if I could find traces of my Great Grandfather, I saw a photo of him and his daughter in the pictures which were hanging from the roof, however i was most disappointed with the staff members as when I tried to get information out of them it was as if they did not know anything. I think they only know the basics of District Six. I am not saying that they should know everybody's history but I just feel they could have been more accommodating in terms of maybe giving me some infor as to where I can research more about my family which came from Distric Six. All in all I am not dissapointed with the experience but I just felt I was cheated out of valuable information.

Bittersweet Nostalgia. It was heart breaking to be reminded of all that District Six used to be. I remember it well from my childhood. It was the lifeblood of the city, full of character, music and busy streets. The Museum is small but well worth a visit.

History of struggle, but not just in South Africa. Thisis a small museum, located in a former small church. It describes the destruction of a vibrant community, known as "District Six" during the Apartheid era. It describes the strong sense of community among the many thousands of people who lived in District Six prior to the bulldozers. It also describes the dreams of some how bringing that community back. What struck me the most, however, were the similarities to "urban renewal" projects in the United States at about the same time (1960's 70's). Destruction of vibrant communities in the name of removing so-called "slums", replaced with highways, or massive, inhumane housing projects, often permanently displacing people who had no means of fighting for their rights. While the US didnt have the official policies of apartheid, the usually well-intentioned urban projects had similar effects of displacement and disenfranchisement. This museum opened my eyes to what was happening in South Africa during this period, but also caused me to be more introspective about my own country. A Tiny museum, but, think of the impact.

Good to get the feel of the history. Wow, you do get the sense of past happenings here and how communities were treated. Do visit. It is worth taking time to read the boards fully. there is a cafe but we didn't sample it so cannot advise.

Worth a Vist. If in Cape Town this museum showing a community evolution during the apartheid period is a must. Details of the resident community are explained via photos and artifacts of interest to all.

Enlightening, Real Look at Overcoming Injustice!. Touching, informative and realistic view of this neighborhood of families ripped from their homes and true injustice overcome. It is a place you should visit, not like other museums, not so large, but so authentic. We bought Noor's book and we are so happy we visited here, because this is a REAL piece of Cape Town history that should not be missed!

SO EMOTIONAL, I challenge you not to be affected by this place.. Made me ashamed for what people were subjected to but so important to see and experience it. What really broke my heart were the little childrens shoes that remained behind as well as the broken crockery and cutlery. How on earth could they just buldoze the place like that, such a waste, its criminal !

Interesting museum but not curated well. Interesting concept but museum needs some work. This museum documents the history of District Six, a very important area in Cape Town history. If there is a former resident there to guide you, it is very interesting. But unfortunately, no one was available to us the day we visited. There are many, many artifacts from former residents, as well as the map that was used to help people reclaim the land that was taken away from them during apartheid. But it is almost too crowded and unless someone really knows the history, it is a somewhat obtuse museum. I would suggest reading about District six before you go. You can see the entire museum in less than an hour.

More personal look at apartheid . This relatively small museum is definitely worth a visit. We actually went twice (the second was a 25 minute stop on a township tour which wouldn't have been enough on its own). You can pay a little extra for a guided tour and I would highly recommend that. Our guide gave us an impassioned and personal insight into how the policy of forced removals affected her family.
Living history. A must see for all visitors--speak with a former District Six resident while also viewing pictures of the once vibrant area. A sad reminder of poor governmental decision making.

A must see history. If you come to Cape Town you can not leave without visiting this museum. Takes a good hour to learn of this area that was exproriated from the coloured community in the 70s. Good history and understand how it was to live in the district 6.
See this before you visit a township. An excellent way to learn about apartheid from people who have gone through reconciliation and as a preparation for visiting the townships.

A must to book the guided tour. Great experience!. After reading the reviews I decided to book the guided tour, lead by a former resident of District six. I'm so glad I did, because hearing Ruth relate her experiences and stories was what made the visit truly memorable and enriching. She walked us through the exhibits inside the museum, but we spent most of our time walking around the actual district, where she explained the history and culture of the area before the apartheid. The entire visit including the walkaround tour took around 3 hours. Fantastic experience.

District Six Museum. Located in the heart of Cape Town, this museum is for the history-lover. It is also great for school children who are learning about this time in history. For tourists, it offers a glimpse into South African history. It can be enjoyed in a short space of time.

Fascinating, shocking piece of history told by people who lived thru it. Relatively small museum. We paid a tiny bit extra to have a previous resident of district six give us a tour, which really brought it to life, and made it so much more 'real'. Not sure we would have got nearly as much from it without that. A great thing to do. The cafe was great too....cheap and delicious. Highly recommended with the resident tour.

Great experience . Its was great to have a feel of what the black & coloured went through during the dark apartheid days especially the eviction of blacks & coloured people from the home lands. It was heart wrenching.
A moving experience. Attending this museum gave a perspective on how Cape Town evolved and how the people were treated under an oppressive and racist system.

Nice. We had a nice visit to the District Six museum. It really helped bring the story to life. However, it is pretty small (we spent less than half an hour there.) I would recommend doing other things in the area, unless you are really interested in the history of District 6.

Really worthwhile. A most touching and worthwhile experience. Noor, a former resident, showed us around and told stories of life before the end of apartheid. The displays and stories helped those of us with limited real understanding of apartheid to understand and gain an insight into life styles of blacks, coloureds and whites in Cape Town.

History slaps you in the face. This museum is not for the faint hearted. Your guide is someone who has lived the experience and is the history of Cape Town. It is confronting, highly emotive and very very worthwhile. Yes I cried and to this day I think of what we learnt and what some people injured. I'm so glad we visited the museum, it doesn't sugar coat the history but as the guide said "telling our story will make sure it never happens again".

Thought provoking and quiet. I am so glad I made this one of my stops during my 2 days in cape town. Knowing only a little about South Africa's recent history, this museum taught me a lot. A lot of reading is required to get a lot out of this museum with huge panels of history covering the walls of this historic building. This museum was designed by the people who were forcefully evicted from District 6 and their families so the museum has a very personal feel about it - with lots of stories and pictures from families - even family recipes on some of the walls. A few people from District 6 work in the museum and will happily chat to you about their lives and the history. For me it was incredibly interesting and humbling experience - and something I am glad not to have missed.

Depressing. The history is very upsetting and for me was slightly overwhelming. I felt that a sense of positivity could have been draw from the more progressive part of that community in recent times. very informative but not one for the faint hearted (me)

Good narative of South Africa's not so distant past. I visited to learn a little bit more about South Africa's history and it would be helpful to know a bit before you visit the museum. I was not entirely sure what it was about and while there is a lot of information you can read at District Six, I had to struggle a bit to get a clear picture of what the museum covered. So best to do a little internet searching first to familiarize yourself with what District Six was.The museum covers the area called District Six in Cape Town which was where most black and colored people lived before the government declared the area white only in the late 60's and forced everybody to move out of their homes. The museum itself mostly is about the life of the people who were living in this area before they were forced out and worth the visit to get an understanding of life in Cape Town. Most of the exhibits are pictures and written accounts but there are some pieces that have been donated as well. I don't think the museum is that old and is still in the process of collecting items.The museum is an easy walk from the Cape Town train station and near the Castle and Parade grounds.

A real human face to the then and now. As Solomon said, 'there is nothing new under the sun". You will read the stories and find erie similarities in the displacing of families and communities during Apartheid with the actions and events perpetrated upon identified families, groups and communities leading up to the holocaust. If anyone cares to speak with many of the persons affected then, they will find that they are experiencing discrimination all over again today. Never equal, not then, not now. There are so many compelling stories to be found in this museum, one could really spend hours upon hours. If the only thing that we can do is treat our fellow man equally at the end of the day, then I can only pray that at least a few will have that as a their take away lesson. South Africa is a compelling land with a complex history. Dive in at any part of the deep pool and learn a bit about it or a lot. "There's nothing new under the sun."

A must see museum when you visit Cape Town. This is an excellent museum which gets the message of how apartheid affected people through the story of the clearing of district 6 - a happy multicultural area. The story is told through the eyes of and with the help of previous residents. There is a lovely café inside - do try the district 6 kooksister - delicious )

A side of aparthied not well known. District Six was a neighbourhood that was happily multicultural that the authorities cleared of people (re-housed) during the apartheid era and then flattened the houses, shops, and everything else. The government has since promised to rebuild on the original site but it still remains a blank space in Cape Town. Just on the border of the area, a small museum has been set up with photos, exhibits and memorabilia salvaged/donated from the neighbourhood. If you are lucky, a past resident (Noor) will be present to take you through the museum and its exhibits. His story telling of the injustices is eye-opening and very educational.

Informative and engaging. I learned a great deal about apartheid. The displays are well done and clever. If you play a few notes on the piano a previous resident will come and give you the tour. However, the displays are self explanatory, but the personal experiences are an excellent addition.

Great Historical View of the challenges the South African people faced. Noor met our group on Sunday to provide us an overview and interesting discussion on the history of District 6 and the museum. He was supposed to leave in time to take his wife to lunch. I sure hope he made it.

Excellent telling of the sad history of District Six. Very informative and well designed museum which does an excellent job of telling the story of the residents of this area and the sad history of the injustices done to them.

Forced Evacuation. District 6 was a mixture of Black Africans, Colored (mixed blood), Asians (Indian, Indonesian and Chinese), and Whites of Jewish and Islam faiths. Upon the passage of apartheid laws, these peoples were moved out of the urban areas and resettled in the townships where there was no infrastructure to support a community of this size. This meant lack of electricity, potable water and other amenities. District 6 was a vibrant community prior to its dispersal into the hustings. There were dance halls, jazz bands, legitimate theater, and movie houses as well as stores, goods and services. The buildings were torn down and the land was plowed under and the land left barren to this day. The museum tells the story of the District 6 inhabitants in their own words. This museum is a must see.

interesting talk with ex resident. If you are looking for a different kind of museum, this is it. Its not really a interesting museum if you compare it with the “normal kind” they have no museology and everything looks more like a sketchbook of memories. You can look around while talking to an ex resident from district 6 and then things get a lot more interesting. If you are lucky you will get some really nice personal stories.

Small but interesting. The District Six Museum is a strong introduction to apartheid for those less familiar with South Africa's history. The museum itself, while educational and interesting, feels a bit small. Definitely not an all day (or even half day) activity so plan on doing more of trying to map out your trip.

Not forgotten history. District six museum is located in buitenkant street. For a nominal fee one get get valuable information about the type of community that lived at district six. One could read about people's personal life experiences. A small cafe is located at the premises for snacks soup and beverages. I've visited capetown more like 50 times but never thought about checking out this museum. I'm glad I did so this time. Walking distance from the museum is the castle, station etc. personally I would recommend a visit here.
District 6... the New York of Cape Town.. lots of information at this Musuem to absorb. Lovely display...text, books, posters, images as well as tours by local residents. A Must Do.
Historical visit. Well curated museum with meaningful artifacts and compelling stories. Worth the time to contemplate the items and fully listen to the speakers. Well done.

Poignant and inspiring. The District Six Museum should be on every visitors list to do in Cape Town. Not because it is a high powered and modern museum. Not because it has interactive media displays. But because it provides a detailed snapshot of life under apartheid and the very high cost paid as a result. The vibrant, lively and mixed community of the area known as District Six was bulldozed to the ground by the worst of the old, oppressive regime that controlled all life in South Africa. Despite this horrendous and brutal act the lives and personalities of the community that made up the District are vividly conveyed in the words and photographs on display in this small museum. Take the time to visit and you will be richly rewarded and, hopefully, deeply moved.

An important story to tell. This small museum tells the story of an awful period of time in this country's history, where a diverse and vibrant community was simply removed from their homes,mrippimg apart families' lives, in the name of apartheid. The stories told are heart wrenching, and all too real. A worthwhile visit.

Stunning and heart breaking - you must go.. Coming from Australia with our history of how we treated our indigenous people, it was awful to see what had been done to the people of South Africa. Ripping out the heart of functioning communities, businesses and educational institutions benefitting from others who lost their homes and not seeming to care. In a post-apartheid world, we are starting to see reconciliation, this museum documents the recent history and gives hope for the future. There is a walking tour, but we didn't go on it, just spending time in the museum was just over an hour.

A must see. District Six was an area under apartheid that was occupied by 60,000 coloureds and blacks until the government forcibly removed them. The Museum is a time-machine back to that era. It is filled with old news clippings on the walls, pictures of the inhabitants, and the history of District Six. There are several guides to answer questions and presentations for children and adults. I believe, not sure, that the admission price is 10-20 rand. It is well worth the visit. Parking is adequate, but a word of caution about the Museum. It does not allow flash photography, although pictures are allowed. I had just purchased a new camera and couldn't figure out how to turn off the flash. :)

So glad that we visited!. This was not originally on our Cape Town agenda, but we are very glad that we stopped. It gave a great insight into some of the experience of those who were relocated and their stories and lives that were uprooted as a result. It is a bit on the small side but that's just fine. Definitely worth a stop - about 1-2 hours.

UNMISSABLE. This is a fairly small but fascinating museum very moving and informative. Takes you through the whole process of relocation and brings home the reality of apartheid. Thoroughly recommended

Wasn't sure what I was looking at. I would have preferred to learn about District Six in a film documentary rather than an actual museum. The story of displacement is a very moving and interesting one, but the museum itself, two floors of physical displays like maps, newspaper clippings, articles from the people who used to live in District Six, and voice recordings of people talking about what it was like to live there, didn't really tell the story for me. I had the sense that there was this terrible, hit-you-over-the-head story about what it was like for an entire community to be uprooted, but it just wasn't hitting me over the head. It was an interesting visit, but not an exceptional one.
A PERSONAL VIEW, VERY TOUCHING. excellent, very small museum which gives a terrific and very personal view of what life was like there before displacement. very touching.

Meh. First of all, if you choose to visit - its a nondescript building that is in the corner of the street. There is hardly a sign outside to see it by. The museum was mostly personal accounts of people - not a big overview of what occurred. I was expecting more. It was okay, but nothing impressive. It took about 35 minutes.
Experience history. Wonderful, simple and complex museum. Full of warmth and personal stories. A must for anyone looking for an explanation to our history,

District Six, the pulse of the Mother City.. The District Six Museum is the go to place is you want to know about the history of Cape Town, life in the Mother City before apartheid, the impact of apartheid, forced removals, culture, etc.You can take a walk to the museum from the Grand Parade or Cape Castle and it is near a very interesting precenct just below The Gardens. If you want to know the richness of the Cape, then this has to be in your bucket list.

Average!!. kinda boring experience!!!
people genuinely interested should visit!!
took me half an hour to locate it though!!

First class attraction in the vicinity of the old port of Cape Town. Wonderful experience seeing all the background of the area featuring the arrival of immigrants, both back and white into the poorer areas of Cape Town from 1880 to 1920. The place is filled with the most interesting information displayed with great appeal.Next door is an absolutely wonderful casual cafe/restaurant which served delicious cakes made on the premises and coffee, called Haas and lots of beautiful art could be purchased at the same place.
learn about the history of cape town. this place is the core historic source of cape town dark past, it will open yo eyes on what happened in cape town before 1994

A must see. Our guide, Noor, was an absolute wonderful person to educate us about the history of District 6. His personal history, understanding and enthusiasm for telling the stories were infectious!

Touching. Get a guide! The two of us got our own guide at the museum. She gave us her personal story and both the guide and the two of us har tears in our eyes several times. The most touching moments we had!

Lots of Knowledge. The museum has lots if information. I would recommend 2 to 3 hours to be able to do anything meaningful there. There is a lot of text and photos to go though.There are some items on display as well to break the monotony of the text.Its not a place to go have fun but its very rich on history. For some reason all the info made me very angry about apartheid and the injustice at the time.
Sobering Experience. We jumped off the hop on/off bus to visit this museum which is an interesting and humbling experience about the recent history of this country and Cape Town. Thought provoking.

Very moving and informative. Really worth visiting, this is only a small Musuem, housed in an old church, but the story it tells is extremely moving. It is very well done through recorded interview, testimonials, photos, newspaper articles etc. a mock up of the living conditions really sets the scene of how black people were forced to moved from their homes, then the area was raised to the ground for the benefit of white South African people. We were advised by a friend to get one of the volunteers who had first hand experience to do the tour with us but there was no one available, even so we spent well over an hour reading the information and looking at all the photographs that tell the story. The coffee shop was in the process of being revamped but still a welcome sit down and a nice cup of coffee. Very easy to find if you are facing the City Hall where Nelson Mandela made his first speech as a free man. Turn left and walk to the first 'robot' (traffic lights) then turn right up this street. The Muesum is 3 blocks up on your right.

An important piece of history. With a degree in African studies, I was extremely interested in seeing the District Six museum where black and coloured occupants of this area of Cape Town were uprooted from their homes and literally dumped into another area, known as the Cape Flats which are now the city's slum/township area. Go back in time by way of photos and testimonials of Apartheid's victims during this turbulent period of history. Should not be missed by anyone who is remotely interested in part of South African history

Worth a visit. Urban development policies under apartheid led to destruction of thriving urban areas to the detriment of people of color. This museum is a tribute to those who were displaced and their stories. It is worth a visit.
Great way to learn about history. I went there with a class group and found it fascinating! The exhibits were great, and I learned a lot. However, it was small which I liked. It was not overwhelming.

Take a guide to get a personal perspective. The museum is about people and the photos of people are up on the walls. We took a guide who shared her experiences of living in the area and what forced removals did to her family. Having a guide is well worth while.I agree with a previous statement it is not clear where it starts or ends. At the bottom section they need to group the info a bit better, and since it is about people maybe a bit more than stories of the people is needed.

Educational but not Entertaining. It felt like something was missing. Perhaps a short video explaining the history of district six. We weren't even sure where it started and where it ended. Too much reading and not enough artifacts. I hate to rate something like this so low, but it really wasn't worth the effort it took to get there.

Emotional....... We started our morning off visiting this museum. Powerful and emotive. The history of District Six is heartbreaking. Spend time here, read about this district and those that lived there. Powerful stuff......

Important history!. A quite small museum but with a powerful message! During the 70s 60000 inhabitants were forced out of their homes during Apartheid towards their new area, Cape Flats. The coloured people housing that area were looked upon as criminals and not fit for this regime. District Six where then declared a "white only" area. This museum delivers a lot of history in the form of written text, pictures and monuments. A very interesting walk of history! A guide is also available.

Very interesting. Absolutely recommanded when you want to learn more about the history of the country. We visites the museum as a part of the township Tour what is a good way to do it as the guide first shows the district in the city sonyou have a better understanding of the information you get in the museum.

Powerful. Excellent displays outline history of the area during Apartheid, specifically the forced relocation of 60,000 people.. Even more powerful are the hand written notes from former inhabitants of District Six.

The sobering facts about the apartheid governments actions of the past. This is a must visit museum whether you are a South African or from overseas. We have all heard about the forced re-locations in the country but until one sees the before and after pictures of the area you cannot fathom the scale of it. To see and hear first hand from people that were there is a wake up call. Not a big museum but one that goes straight to the heart.

Will Stay With Us Forever. We had been recommended to visit District Six Museum and we are eternally grateful that we did. We had the tour with the wonderful Ruth, who generously shared her personal story and which had both my husband and myself in tears. It is horrendous what happened in South Africa in those not so far off days. To meet Ruth and to see her spirit and resilience, was an incredible honour. Don't miss this museum and do a tour with a guide. Thank you Ruth.
Eyeopener. Well presented piece of history. Small gift shop and snack bar. Clean restrooms. Smallish. Takes about a hour if one reads everything.

Very interesting insight to apartheid. The story of district six explained by a guide who actually lived there and suffered forced removal.
We should never forget what some people have been through and how they now forgive rather than seek revenge, how many of us could do that.

Poignant reminder of the Apartheid period. Most visitors to Cape Town will go on the ubiquitous "open top bus" tour - and well worth it is too - but do not miss going on the loop they offer which takes you around District Six which is just off the main city area. If you do this then you must break your journey at the District Six Museum which is housed in a small, ex-church building.This Museum is STUFFED FULL of artefacts to do with the District Six area and the history of the people who lived there during the Apartheid period....fascinating, poignant, sad......but well worth a visit that will allow you to better understand what happened in South Africa in the past.
spend time reading the entries around the place. It takes some time to get into the right mood and make the most of this visit. The various anecdotes are moving...

Walking tour is a must. Our guide, Mr Brown, was brilliant. Forget about reading the museum exhibits for hours (although they are very informative). The R80 cost of the 1 hour walking tour and museum overview is definitely worth it. Service was also great. We called at 9am and were on the walking tour at 10am. Thank you Mr Brown :-)

Sobering, meaningful. This relatively small museum is packed full of history, emotion and insight. It is a must for any visitor trying to understand Cape Town's Apartheid past.The museum consists mainly of photos and wall posts to read but it shares a huge amount of history and gives one a context of the city. I felt like I was sucked into a little bubble of the past as I read and heard people's first-hand accounts of their experiences of life in District 6 and the forced removals. It was an emotional and sobering experience but ultimately a valuable investment of time during a Cape Town visit.

Worth an hour - especially if you are trying to understand the history. This is a small exhibit and not flashy. But it really brings the message home of how bad things were. This specific terrible action (i.e., relocating 60,000+ black residents and flattening the area) we had never heard of.BTW - Charley's Bakery is close by.

A MUST SEE!. Even though one thinks you know the "history", there is nothing that opens your eyes like a well "designed" museum. Our visit has opened our eyes to the hardship and loss that the people had to endure - being removed from District Six.

Very Insightful. Didn't know anything of this story but after visiting this quaint little museum found this a most interesting but disturbing history. Good luck in the aim to preserve a piece of the land.

Really well presented. The storey of the destruction of District 6 by the government in 1948 is well documented - we just had 15 mins there and would have liked 1 to 2 hours to really take in the detail of the exhibits

Very informative. Well written boards describing the history and events in detail. Very wordy, can imagine quite boring for kids. Loved the upstairs reconstructions of the hairdressers etc. A great place to get a better understanding of the District Six story.

If you only go to one Museum make it this one.. Thgis is a great place and gives a real insite in to how things were in South Africa in the 20th Centry. Its a real eye opener and you get a real education. A nust see if you are in Cape Town

An interesting visit. I went here to a friend memorial event so it was full of struggle activists who had lived in the area, my friends amongst them. I spent 4 hours listening to the tales of the area and the sadness of the great loss of a mixed race community. I grow up in Liverpool which had similar areas and felt some of their loss.I went to the toilet and suddenly found myself in the Rocky Horror Show, it was on in the next door theatre which share the toilets. RHS was also a part of my youth so an interesting visit in many ways

Incredible Story about the removal of a whole class of people from their homes. Fascinating to read newspaper reports and see bits and pieces of the homes that were razed. Unbelievable what people can do to other people who are unlike themselves.

visit is a must. the place is emotionally overwhelming. It's a place where people can understand the horrors of the apartheid years. It's really moving to see the pics and read all the stories. It's worth a visit

Depressing but so worth visiting. This is a museum to show what happened to an inner city area of CT and over 60,000 of its inhabitants were forcibly removed - so sad and so unnecessary for this to have happened. The Museum is in a church near the site and is very poignant. It is so well worth a visit and shows how pointless it all was. If you are interested in this history of SA, then this Museum is well worth a visit.

A mving experience. The museum is well thought out and gave us an impression of the clearance of District 6. It was made more poinant by the gentleman at the desk having been brought up in District 6. Well worth the visit

Helps you understand Cape Town. A small museum, and well worth the visit - very approachable. It is a dark story of a very dark time of man's inhumanity to man. It is poignant and evocative, as promised, and also very moving. It is such valuable information in understanding Cape Town and the Western Cape.To walk afterwards in the still barren lands, now grass and weed-covered, which once housed a vibrant community of misfits and the unwanted, is very moving indeed. It's very inexpensive. Spend the tiny bit extra to get a guide

Only needs to be a quick stop. Unfortunately I was a bit underwhelmed by the District Six museum. It's a small space and most of the exhibits are text with a few accompanying pictures, mainly family photos. The first floor gives a semi-detailed account of what happened, but it's crowded and difficult to take in when even a small group of people enter at the same time. The upstairs area gives more personal accounts of it was like before the families were driven out but it becomes slightly repetitive. In my opinion, this seems like it would be an incredibly moving experience for people with direct ties to District Six while it's merely a quick stop for visitors. I think it's a good stop for anyone, as long as you have a good expectation of what you'll be seeing. The entrance fee is extremely reasonable and I'm glad to contribute to their growth.

Highly informative.. This is an excellent museum to understand the horrors of the Apartheid era. There are many artefacts but I found the poems on the floor particularly moving in understanding the true impact of this regime. It is well worth a visit.

Don't Miss. I have been here often with visiting friends. This simple but powerful museum gives a wonderful insight to the impact of the Group Areas Act in Cape Town and the devastating impact of apartheid in the Western Cape. The demographics of the Western Cape is very different from the rest of South Africa. District Six is emblematic of how the Group Areas Act created many of the townships that comprise the suburbs of Cape Town today. Definitely make sure you take advantage of the tour guides.
District Six Museum. Interesting place to visit to get background of the history of Cape Town. Political views of guides are a bit annoying.

Small Yet Important. District Six was razed during Apartheid and this museum attempts to capture the vibrant and diverse community that was destroyed. There is an old-fashioned, home-grown feeling to the exhibits. There is a map of the old district on the floor and various families have annotated where they lived on this map. This authentic sense of community is palpable. During our stay in Cape Town, we met several people whose parents or grandparents were part of the District Six diaspora; thus, the museum seems to resonate with current times. In its own way, as important as Robben Island.

Cape town. I was really intrested in the district six historie. i went their alone and didn't take a tourguide.Without a tourguide the museum is a little bit chaotic and you dont really understand the line..My advise is take a tourguide then it will be a lot more intresting.

Great Educational. I found it informative and a great place to get back in touch with the routes of South Africa. being South African from birth, im surprised I have been here before. great day out with the madam

opportunity lost. Very disnointed a d confusing place. Terrible museum about an important piece of cape town history. If you don't know anything about it, you won't learn it here, and that's a damn shame.

Interesting feel for the apartheid era. A meaningful visit, worthwhile if you are in the city. Terrible story, but almost too much written information to take in during our short visit. Gives perspective to the very unfortunate recent history of South Africa

Visiting Cape Town? Start with this museum. Get a guide to take you round. They give you a history of events that took place in District Six in their lifetimes. It would be hard to take in so much by reading all the news paper articles posted around the walls.

Very good personal history of apartheid. The museum is compact and presents a very personal story of people who had to move out of District Six with the Apartheid Government's plans to make the centre of Cape Town an all-white centre. There is a lot of information on activities to commemorate the future of the area and how South Africa is moving on since democracy came in 1994. A very uplifting experience.

Interesting Museum. An interesting place to visit. Unique ambience at least in my experience, since this is a converted church. Overall impression was of interesting displays but as others have said, a lot to read, but quick visual impressions were good. It has a small cafe but we didn't use that facility. Glad we included it as part of our city centre tour.

Beautiful museum. We asked for a stop off here before the Langa township tour and we're really glad we did. It's a great community museum put together with love and thought. It gave a insight into Cape Town before the Townships.
An eye opener. This museum is very well done. We spend about an hour there looking at all the things and reading about all the history. We would recommend it.

Need More Info. This museum gave me many more questions than answers. The first couple boards gave a lot of information and pictures, but the museum quickly went into personal accounts of what District 6 was like before it was gutted during apartheid. There were also quite a bit of unsubstantiated claims that left me asking a lot of questions. I wanted to know exactly why certain decisions were made to tear down buildings and not tear down others. Why were some people moved out before others? Why did some people get moved to better places than others? There were also not a lot of facts on the amount of crime and the slumlords of former District 6, but they were eluded to in a few areas. Fascinating subject, but left me hanging.

i think i missed the point... i think I missed to get the point of this museum. I understand the brutality of the apartheid but this place seems to focus only on the sorrow for the some old quarter being tear down. I think Robben island or a township tour make a way better job in explaining what happened. redundant.
Boring. With todays technology you could do so much more with films and animation. This was only text, text and more text with photos.

Very interesting. Only 30 rand entry to see a really interesting collection of photos, maps and memorabelia of what this part of Cape Town was like. Well worth a visit and it is very close to the Castle of Good Hope.
Very informative. Interesting museum which explained the intricacies of apartheid. Went to as part of our township tour
Well worth the money. Very moving and interesting museum. Although it is small, the entrance fee is low and it is worth seeing if you are nearby.

Good insight into the impact of apartheid. This museum gives the human story of the forced removal of the black & cloured population from an area close to the centre of Cape Town where they worked, to townships many miles away. The exhibits are colourful and poignant. Much of District Six remomain open land as it was agreed with the former residents that it would not be developed according to the original plan - a "white only" housing area. The museum is in the old Methodist Church, which had previously been a liquor store!!!
Great museum. Extremely interesting and well laid out. The museum squeezes so much into such a small space and is well worth the entrance fee!

A moving experience. We had a quick 20-minute tour of the District Six Museum when we were on a guided tour that took us out to some of the townships surrounding Cape Town and that was enough to confirm that we had to return for a proper look around. I loved the fact that there was so much information about District Six and so many personal stories from the people that had lived there. I found it very easy to navigate. Once I had seen everything, I revisited the parts that really made an impact. I was at once sad for the uprooted people and amazed at the lack of bitterness. The whole thing was a very moving experience. Highly recommended.
Memorable. This museum is small, but holds so much information about the History of District six, and what happened to the people living there. So Interesting!

One of the must-visit museums in Cape Town. I had read a lot about the museum prior to my visit to CT. This museum tells the story about District Six, a neighbourhood in CT with a very interesting story. I recommend talking to Mr. Noor if he is available or buying his book to learn more about what happened in District Six during apartheid. The museum tells the stories of real people through exhibits of what a home would look like in District Six before it was torn down, photos, streetsigns and other objects the people of District Six brought with them when they had to move out of the neighborhood.

A hidden history revealed. This museum is a gem. It treads a fine line between personal testimonies and historical context, and gets it absolutely right. You are faced with the monstrous absurdity of apartheid, but also by the warmth of the community which it tried to destroy.

Don't miss this. Housed in one of the remaining churches from the original District Six, this museum tells the story of the clearance of this vibrant community because of the colour of the skin of those who lived there. And most of it hasn't even been re-developed even now, despite being close to the centre of the city.Perhaps best to go with a guide to get an overview first (we were with African Eagle tours and this was the first part of their township tour). That's not wholly necessary as the museum does an excellent job of telling the story, but it does make it easier to understand what you're seeing and give some personal stories.The whole thing will certainly affect you emotionally, mostly saddening at what man can do to man, but also uplifting in parts where the hope for the future shines through.

Very moving and informative. Absolutely recommend a visit to the museum. It tells the story of the social upheaval caused by apartheid with the tearing apart of a vibrant and multi racial community. Definitely gave pause for thought and made quite a profound impact on us. Only wish we could have spent more time there.

You must Visit. To get a true understanding of the recent history of Cape Town you must visit the District Six Museum. I would suggest planning to be there about 90 min. It helps to open your eyes on what happened vs just reading a few blurbs about it in a pamphlet. Make sure to put it on your list.

A must visit. The story behind District 6, like many told during the apartheid era is almost unbelievable, but one that is eye opening. It gives further insight into the issues of the country and the city. It's worth taking the time to read as much as you can whilst there.

Make sure to visit this place when in Cape Town. A deeply affecting and memorable experience. This museum tells the story of the appalling "community development" initiative brought in by the government, which forced non-white families in the area to move out of their homes and into barren outlying areas known as the Cape Flats. I can't imagine visiting this place without getting a guided tour, as the museum itself is small and very basic. However, the real power of the place is in the personal stories that the guides can tell you, while explaining the history of the area.

Heartbreaking and important museum. We visited the District Six Museum last year and were glad that we had taken the time to do so. This museum does an important job of reminding us just how badly we can treat other people but also manages to be inspiring.

Need some white guilt? Come on down!. Staying in Cape Town for holiday, you will hear much about apartheid and how the city is still rebuilding and learning to trust one another. This museum commemorates District 6 and the terrible story of masses of people uprooted because of the color of their skin. This section of history is well documented and you more than likely read about it (even in guide books), but this place has vivid pictures of the events, newspaper articles and items from the original district that really brings it home. It is not your typical museum it looks more like your grandmother’s house and is quite small, but the story is the important part and that we need not forget what happened.

Important Museum to visit. From the moment you enter this museum, you are given a feel for what it was like to be white or black in apartheid S. Africa. A must see. An amazing collection of material and information that is organized in an interesting way.

Awesome little museum . This is a very cool little museum. The people working there look good after it and they are more than willing to tell you a few stories about the displays and history of the area.
Fascinating. A wealth of history about SA's recent past brought to life with incredible facts, displays and stories. A really fascinating couple of hours passed by.

Lest the world forgets.... "...remember with shame...[those] forced...to leave their homes because of the colour of their skins."- Thus reads the plaque outside the District Six Museum which memorializes a somber moment in the history of Apartheid South Africa. This is a museum whose displays remind us of a chapter in the story of man's inhumanity to man. But it is also a testament to the honest confrontation of that chapter by contemporary South African society - the building and its contents physical evidence of the spirit of truth and reconciliation that animates the post-apartheid era. It is definitely a museum worth seeing. You may wish to visit as part of a fuller tour devoted to the struggle to overcome apartheid (Inkululeko Tours 1/2 day "walk to Freedom tour was the one we took which included a visit to the District Six Museum).

Eye Opener. This is a very interesting little museum telling the story of one of the most shameful acts of the apartheid regime. The story is brought to life by personal evidence and annecdotes of former residents.The museum itself is essentially in one large room and is laid out in a rather congested and ramshackle way.
