This is an important subject and it would be good if bigger premises could be found to present this subject in a more organised way.

Nostalgic. I grew up during the forced removals and have memories exactly like depicted in the exhibits ... Like being in my grandma's home and playing the kids games in the street. It is good to have a knowledgeable guide and not do it by yourself ... There is so much to know about this Museum for that. Hope you get to understand why we Capetonians are what we are, how we think and experience the richness of our culture.

real life, real history to remind us all of how brutal we can be to each other. Really, any visit to the cape area must include a visit to this worrying yet inspiring living museum. Telling the real stories of district six from harmonious families living together to the horror of the apartheid regime splitting up communities and destroying families and homes. And yet it is also inspiring with numerous testiments from previous residents describing the evacuations and destruction whilst telling how they have moved on to a brighter future. The government and the people still have much do, though. A visit from you will contribute a small amount to this process.

A Peek Into A Portion of Cape Town's History. Cape Town's history is rich and District Six Musuem reflects and informs on a part of that history. Surrounded by the natural beauty of Cape Town and South Africa, this museum shines a light on an ugly side but it also discusses the efforts made to remove the ugly mark in Cape Town's history and move toward reconciliation. A truly worthy place to visit to learn more about the people and history of Cape Town.

Find out more reasons of loving CPT. 30-45 mins journey takes you to walk thru the history of South Africa and Cape Town, you will love the mother city more after exploring the story that you might not getting from the book.
Educational. Either as part of a group you will get a fantastic insight into the history of the people of Cape Town
The stain of apartheid. District 6 is a graphic account of apartheid real estate greed & opportunistic thievery. Leaves an impression. Impassioned lectures and photographs make it real.

History of Apartheid in Capetown. Very interesting museum of articles about the relocation of people and destroying their homes and businesses. We had a very gracious host for are guided tour. Mr. Brown is a survivor of this horrible occurrence. He has finally been able to have compensation and returned to the area where his family was removed. He gave a very detailed and personal account of his and his neighbors experience during this time. This is another must do experience when visiting. Thank you Mr. Brown!!
So interesting. We visited this museum whilst on a City Tour - our driver very kindly stopped and we were so pleased as all the exhibits were worth seeing.
interesting information. The museum is interesting and provides a lot of information on the history of the district it's in. I can't explain why it didn't grab me. My travel partner liked it a lot.

A History of Apartheid and the city. This museum will give you an insight into a part of Cape Town which was destroyed under the guise of urban renewal.Tens of thousands were uprooted from an established community and deposited in far away suburbs where no community spirit existed.Visitors to our city should spend an hour reading some of the life stories of the residents.

Makes you reflect. A poignant reminder of the madness of apartheid and the consequences of it - things you still can see traces of in South African society today. And, in the case of District 6, in the city planning yet today. The museum is a reminder of things that are just 20+ years away. The museum is not very big, but the exhibits and history is interesting. If you don't know very much of the apartheid system, you will be educated. Well worth a visit.

Not to be missed!. If you are interested in history and what happened during Apartheid - please put this museum on your list. It is a small museum located near the District Six area. For R45 you can have a tour by someone that lived in District Six. It is an an extremely moving and sad experience, but one that should not be forgotten. They do close at 4pm- but they also offer sunset walks of District 6.

thought provoking. An interesting little museum highlighting man's inhumanity to man. Many interesting photos and personal stories that make this atrocity all the more shocking. An easy stop on the yellow route tour bus and as compulsory as Robbins island in my view.

Very moving but a must see in Cape Town. We went to the museum not long after it opened at 9am and we were fortunate enough to be able to have a former resident of District Six (a lady called Ruth) show us around and tell us her family's story. You can pay slightly more for a local guide to show you around - which was definitely the way to get the most out of the experience.It is a really moving place to go and see, and when you hear the personal accounts of what happened it really brings home to you what happened not that long ago.A must see in Cape Town.

Eclectic memorabilia. The museum is interesting and gives some insight into the lives and culture of the former residents. They seemed to have had a strong and supportive community in the face of adversity with a fairly unique culture. Clearances of slum and poor quality housing with concomitent dispersion of the residents are not uncommon anywhere and frequently harsh; add the extra dimension of racially based oppression by a misguided post colonial power and it becomes more so.

A very sad but worthwhile visit. If you've an hour or two to spare please go here. It's one of the most heartbreaking but inspiring places I've ever been and I'm so glad I went. The city hop on-hop off yellow route stops nearby so it's easy to get to and the staff are very friendly and knowledgeable. District Six is the biggest scar left from apartied and the museum has photos, exhibits and real stories that clearly describe what happened and how as a designated 'white' area everyone else had to leave the area to townships further out of the city. It was very sad, but it also is a real reminder of just how far South Africa has come in terms of forgiveness, celebrating diversity and building hope.

A very important piece to understand. This museum explores how a diverse and vibrant community was destroyed during the apartheid era. Displacing people from their homes because of the color of their skin is shocking. The problem with our visit is that an ex-resident gave a speech and focused on 3 people out of 18 in our group so we heard almost nothing. We were able to look at the displays, art and posters to gain some knowledge. Strongly suggest that you follow up this visit with a tour of Langa Township.The museum serves to remind us that we must do everything so that history does not repeat itself in such a terrible way.

Tugs at one's heart strings. How could a government displace so many people forceably and in such a callous way? This is a question that perhaps will never be fully answered.The museum is very small, but very interesting indeed. Worth a visit.

Unbelievable. This is one of the best museums in Cape Town, well laid out and not too big that it becomes unnameable. Most of the information and displays have come from ex-residents of D6 and this brings a personal touch to this. A must when in Cape Town.

An important piece of history. District Six Museum gives us a fascinating glimpse into what life was like before and after apartheid was legislated, both politically and personally. The information texts are a little time-consuming to read but I thought it was worth the effort.

Interesting content, messy presentation. Lots of interesting photos, but the information texts felt incomplete and not too coherent. The museum simply contains too much stuff and we ended up with little more information about the incidents of district six than what we had when we walked in.

Very personal look at apartheid history. The location itself is interesting -- a church that played a role in the anti-apartheid movement. Others have talked about the history of District 6 (racially mixed community that was razed by the South African government in the 1960s) and you will certainly learn a lot about that history here. But the most important thing about this museum is the personal aspects that are highlighted: testimony from people whose houses were taken from them and destroyed, remembrances by former residents of the life and spirit of the District 6 community. There is a lot to read, that's true. But even a cursory visit, reading different testimonials as you make your way around the building, would be enlightening. Combine this with a drive around the current area of the old District 6 to see what the government did -- and is trying to do now to rebuild the area. It is too easy to read about the evils of apartheid at a 50,000 foot level and then move on. These stories are so individual and personal that it makes that horrible period come to life. A very rewarding visit!

Emotional visit. My family grew up in District Six so visiting the museum, and seeing the history of the area made me quite emotional. The Museum isn't large but it brings the area back to life with lots of photographs and displays on various aspects like music, decor, fashion, cuisine etc. of the time. Even if you're a tourist with no roots in South Africa, It is well worth the visit to gain some insight into the Cape people and their history

A must visit.. This is a very good museum and a must visit to learn about recent South African history and the apartheid era. A lot of reading and you need lots of time. Visit to learn and appreciate what happened to the black people in South Africa.
enlightening. Enlightening, hadn't known of this event as we are from another continent. Requires time to do quite a lot of reading.

Very interesting. We had some trouble finding the museum but only because the photograph we had was of the side elevation of the building. It is across the road from the local community police station and on the corner Buitenkant Street and Albertus Street. The museum is small but very interesting and informative. It has a small tea room at the rear were the volunteers are very cheerful and helpful.

Must go and learn. I grew up hearing about apartheid and celebrated its demise in 94 with most of the world. But I didn't know much about the lives of the people who lived in and fought it. This museum and what it commemorates is so important to experience. It's not depressing, but it can be shocking to learn how people can be brave and enduring in their principles. Take your kids, too. In an hour, you will learn much about others and a bit about yourself.

Apartheid Made Personal. For those of us who have only a general understanding of South Africa's apartheid period, here's a succinct way to come to an understanding on a more personal level. Prioir to the era of apartheid, District Six was an area close to downtown Cape Town that was inhabited by a diverse and generally harmonious community of people -- black, colored (SA's term for those of mixed race), Asians, whites, Indians, for the most part. When apartheid was instituted, District six was slated for demolition; it's 66,000 inhabitants were forcibly removed in the 1960's, with no compensation for their homes, businesses or other real estate assets. Only today is compensation being worked out as part of SA's attempt to deal with its past. Having earlier had a tour guide who had lived in District Six as a child, our interest was piqued and we made it a point to visit The District Six Museum on our own. WE ARE SO GLAD WE DID! Through photo's, quotes, film, and graphic presentations, the tragedy of apartheid and the death of District Six comes to life before you here. It's a meaningful visit, a valuable lesson, and helps provide a better understanding of what South Africa was and is becoming. Highly recommended!

A vibrant community destroyed by Apartheid. Absolutely riveting installations in an old church with community-provided photographs, signage and vast amounts of ephemera from a beautifully mixed up, mixed race neighborhood thatsponsored many dance and marching bands as well as providing a wide variety of employment. The oral histories were fascinating and heartbreaking to read as neighbors described watching their beloved houses, apartments and schools torn down by the government, and then forcing families to live out of Cape Town in the townships. Another Cape Town must-see for anyone who cares about civil rights and urban history.

Eye opening. Lots of personal stories and photo footage of apartheid make the visit to the museum well worthwhile. Your choice to let the photos speak for themselves or read the background info or both. Either way very touching documentation of this shocking part of South African history.

Deeply moving and disturbing. There's nothing slick or professional about this small museum housed in an old church. The entrace fee is 30 rand per person + an extra 15 rand pp if you want to be taken round by a volunteer guide. We were moved and informed by the stories told by our guide Ruth, herself a previous resident of District 6 who was removed - along with the rest of her large "coloured" family (without choice or compensation) in the late 1960's.66000 people were moved out of the area into segregated townships under the cruel apartheid regime. They were a mixture of every colour and creed who lived together in a cohesive and largely harmonious community, Their homes were bulldozed. At this time only a handful have returned. We met and spoke with Mr Brown, who returned with his family a year ago. His happiness to be home was palpable. The museum is a place of memories and remembrance - a visit is strongly recommended.
opening your eyes about the apartheid regime. I liked the personal story telling about the apartheid and the quarter 66 which existed in cape town. A museum which gets close to your heart!
Informative & Moving. The District Six Museum, though a bit unpolished, is well-worth the time and modest entry fee. The collection of photographs and stories were moving and information.

OK if you're in the area. I found this museum to be far to wordy. When we walked in we were met with a friendly chap who'd lived in the area for years but unfortunately his instructions were to simply read around the room in a certain order and he sent us on our way. The exhibits were simply masses of writing with small images. It was like reading a textbook from the 1900s... just pages and pages of text.The topic is fascinating but unfortunately my attention span just couldn't handle it.It's not kid friendly at all as they'd get very bored very quickly.

Holiday. We visited the museum during our hop on hop off sightseeing bus. This was well worth the visit as a person from the UK I don't have much knowledge of apartheid and here in the museum it explains it all to you. The staff member was pleasant and very informative. District 6 is well worth a visit.

Very informative.. This is a nice museum. They have done away with the idea of old style museum displays and I find it very informative.Best would however be to either go there as part of a township tour to get it in perspective. (And the first hand account)If you just go there, start a conversation with one of the people working there and ask them their experiences. You will be surprised what comes out!!!

Needs bringing up to date. Visiting the District 6 museum is one of the most moving experiences that I've ever had. So sad to see that a community that lived in harmony, was totally destroyed. And to this day 80% of the land cleared has never been built on due to world outcry at what happened there. However, I feel that perhaps the introduction of audio handsets would help visitors to more fully understand what happened here. They are used in museums etc throughout the world. I'm sure visitors would gladly pay in order to understand exactly what took place.

Aparthied. It's amazing to see the lengths that people would go to just to show disharmony. This place highlights the total destruction of a integrated neighborhood that was totally demolished to reinforce a fallacy...that humans can't live together harmoniously.

Ask for a guide. I should have taken my own advice. The events of District Six are disturbing and sad on so many levels. Although you can self guide through the two floors of exhibits, something is lost in the translation. For a fee, you can be guided through the museum exhibits by someone who lived through the experience and can add detail and insight that may otherwise be lost. If you have any interest in what happened in District Six, this is a must see in Cape Town.

Lows and Highs. Very moving in terms of documenting this shameful tale and the personal story told by a very articulate gentleman who lived through it, but needs some revamping to appeal to the younger generation. That audience is critical to not forgetting this pivotal time in the evolution of South Africa and Cape Town from apartheid to the country that accepts refugees from all over the continent.

Times Change. WOW just to see how every person has a story and a unique identity, the then and now comparison and contrast , this museum was very moving , not that big so can spend a few minuets to an hour however the entrance fee is rather high for the value for money before going to the Museum , have a look at Richmond Street how it looks today and then see how it looked back in the day = it makes you think

Poorly presented. The experience of what happened to District Six is typical of the apartheid regime, and immensely sad. The museum itself though is not very stimulating, lots of static displays and poorly labeled photographs. Hence it really only takes about twenty minutes to absorb what is straightforward to access, and leaves you with the feeling that there was probably so much more to learn. A guide would have been very helpful - but did not seem to be offered.

Short and Sweet with languid emotional networking. Best to read up about it as you make your way to visit an area of Cape Town that was another venue of segregation. It is in a neighborhood, the neighborhood where it happened. Much love and energy has gone into this memorial. It is small but full of guts. Some survivors volunteer there so you can get a first hand story to walk away with.

Not what I expected. The museum tends to talk a lot more about specific families rather than the area. There were also quite a few of the interactive pieces that did not work. As a person that now lives in Zonnebloem I am very interested in the area. I dont think the museum really shed too much light on what we see now as compared to what it was before.

small but interresting. small museeum with a lot of pictures, best to have a guide, there is a guide in the museeum, 72 years old and he lived in district six, he was very friendly, tell's e lot (maby to much) but very interresting to lissten to

Interesting but could do better . I was very interested in going and finding out more about such an important issue to me. Bit disappointed. Information overload , no system around just too much stuff. Walked out knowing more which is good but I wanted to know even more. staff satisfactory

Eductional alternative. We visited this museum due to weather closure at Robben Island. It was well presented and educational showing an insight into South African history (if a little upsetting at times). Staff were attentive informative and approachable.
Not as exciting as I hoped. The museum was informative about what the neighborhood was like before it was razed. However, the experience presented didn't overwhelm me.

Very Nice Museum, Good People, Could have used more explanation. As an African studies minor I have a generally good understanding of African history and I found this museum confusing. It has great artifacts from the area but does not necessarily explain the situation and what happened. However the people who work here are so genuine. They explain things if you ask. They sell great food and tell their stories.

Worth the time . It's not the interactive modern museum but it gives the information to stop you in your tracks to ask yourself...... Did I do enough to stop this apartheid? Simple but moving. A must see.

tour guide catastrophe. After being to Germany and experiencing memorials and museums put in a way to educate rather than blame I was very disappointed in this museum. Hosted by a man who lived through it he has 80 years of anger that vibrate through the tour. My UK friend came out more confused about Apartheid and segregation after the host just blamed all white people, spouted his political views, praised himself, told all these inside jokes and degraded Nelson Mandela and his work. The museum itself has alot of interesting artifacts and lots of information that is well presented. I think I would've enjoyed it more if I wasn't so put off by the tour guide . We left when we were asjed for money at the end after already paying our entrance fee.

Worth a visit. Great insight to an action that many foreigners may not know too much about. A lot of great info well presented in a very simple manner. Not flashy, just real info and photos. Easy to walk to from Company Gardens, etc. Not to be missed.

Very Worthwhile. Despite visiting Cape Town several times, I had never visited the District Six Museum and made a point of finding it on my last morning. Got a little lost, but that's always fun in a city, and the sign outside on the pavement wasn't too obvious, but I'm glad I persevered.As previous reviewers have described, it's in an old church with a wide gallery upstairs. It's an amateurish exhibition and I mean that in a very positive way. It's not slick and flashy with interactive electronic screens and the like, but full of basic information presented in a reasonably clear and unfussy manner.I was familiar with the District Six story, so I was more interested in the photos and artifacts upstairs that showed residents before the forced removals. Putting faces to the numbers makes a big difference, and looking at the school children, factory workers, hairdressers, laundresses, musicians etc. helped me realise the true impact of this awful event. I was particularly impressed by an account from one woman who described having to leave a thriving neighbourhood where work, education, entertainment, church and family were all close by. They were all dumped out in the Flats with absolutely no community life or structure, so having to travel by bus or car to get anywhere. Does this sound familiar in UK sink estates and the US Projects?There was a register book of all the District Six addresses that was reserved for comments from ex-residents, and it was fascinating to see the updates and names that had been added comparatively recently. So this is not just a museum for tourists, but for people who have a strong link to one of the most shameful events in South Africa's history. I was very glad to have experienced it and would recommend this to anyone who wants to understand the human impact of racially charged politics and perhaps the reason that Cape Town is still a fascinating and vibrant city.

A Must to Visit. This is hard hitting history, however it does give an excellent overview of life of the people of South Africa during the Apartheid. Heartbreaking really. A beautiful city with a resilience is now apparent is some quarters. Very humbling moments during this visit.

Fascinating museum. Apartheid is a huge topic to cover in one museum: the Apartheid Museum in Jo'burg, for instance, is great but skims over certain topics and could easily be twice as big. District Six Museum just examines one particular episode of apartheid, namely the forced eviction of residents in District Six in Cape Town from the 1960s to the 1980s. It details the history of the area and tells many stories about various residents and their struggle against apartheid. Some of the former residents are on hand to talk about their lives and attempts to recover their property.My only reason for not giving an additional star is that the museum could be more interactive - there is a lot of literature on the walls but no film clips, and it would have been nice to have made it more wheelchair/pram accessible (you have to walk up stairs to enter the museum and there is a second floor but no lift/elevator).

An enlightening insight in apartheid. This small little museum really opened my eyes to the history of South Africa and apartheid. To learn about the events of this area was enlightening and I thought it well worth a visit.
Worth a visit. This museum made me feel very humble. Enjoyed learning about the history. If you are interested in history and the affects it has, you must visit district 6 museum.

can do so much better. inspite of mixed reviews i visited the museum,it is small just two floors,far too much reading material with absolutely no order.we had a guided tour with noor.the five minutes with noor gave me more information than the entire visit,i bought his book as well. we had booked a guided tour and just got 5minutes with guide.i wish he had explained some of the things on the display.the girl at the reception didnt even mention that there is a video also that they show so we missed it,there were people voluntaringly showing the museum...i wish we would have told about this at the reception,i got more information about this from reading rather than visiting...the museum does very little to ensure that you have a good visit...very sad

Bad as the apartheid. The museum is devoted to the apartheid and how people suffered. At least this is the motive of the museum. The museum is really a collection of junk. Nothing that can show the horrors of apartheid and the fight against racism. It is just a waste of time and money. If you are in a hurry simply do not go.

Worth a visit. If you have not already visited the Apartheid Museum in Johannesburg, the District 6 Museum is a must if you are interested in getting a feel for the insanity that was apartheid, particularly how it impacted Cape Town. However, for those of you who have visited the Jo’burg museum, you may be somewhat disappointed by the comparatively small scope of the story that the District 6 Museum has to tell. In spite of the relative smallness of the story, I did, in fact, find my time at the museum to be well spent. The personal stories and reminiscences of how individuals and families were uprooted by the government under apartheid were very moving and poignant.

Well worth a visit. This museum is well worth visiting. It is small and not too tricky to find. It offers great insight into what happened at District 6 and displays detailed information in an interesting way.
Small and interesting. It will only take about 45 minutes to an hour and the entry fee is minimal. Put together very well and interesting. Enjoyed it!

Must see with a guide. District six museum is a small church in Cape Town. Merely looking around does not tell you anything. We were wondering what was so special about the same, when Mr Tahir Levy came to us and said he will tell us the history of District 6 and take us through the museum free (they have such regular tours). The next 45 minutes were amazing and I am so glad we did the entire tour. The history of apartheid, how it was manifested, and the current state of affairs comes to life through the words of someone who has lived through all this. Very highly recommended.....but stay to do the guided tour.

Do some research - or go by tour bus!. Such a sad history, but if you are in Cape Town you will want to know about the importance of District Six. I lot of people have commented that unless you already know a bit about it, you won't learn much from the museum. This is half true - you will learn something new, but without context some of it will be lost. There are books on sale in the museum shop which make for some good retrospective reading after your visit.I arrived at District Six by going on one of those City Sightseeing tour busses with the audio commentary. Leading up to the museum the commentary provided some information about the area and its history, and when you get back on the bus the commentary continues as you travel out of the area. I know some people have a problem with 'being a tourist' and would rather experience other cultures by doing as locals do, but you really do learn a lot from the tour busses, and you cover a large area by doing so. In short - yes the museum is worth a visit, but do some research beforehand.

A Must-See. Many people have mentioned that the museum is small, which is true. It's housed in an old Methodist church that was once a part of the District 6 neighborhood. The church itself is very beautiful and is a stark reminder of the vibrant community that would have worshiped in its walls before they were forcibly removed. Because the museum is small, it's very easy to navigate on your own, although I was visiting with friends from Cape Town and they knew one of the tour guides from playing in bands together. Joe led us around the first floor of the museum, explained some of the exhibits and shared his own memories from growing up in the neighborhood (and playing music there). I was nervous about visiting Cape Town because of the ever-present history of apartheid (I wasn't sure how it would feel to be a tourist there). Visiting the museum helps contextualize not only the apartheid regime but also the way the physical lay-out of the city was purposefully designed to enforce apartheid. As you view District 6 now (there is still very little built on the razed land) and then travel the highways around the City Bowl and out into the Cape Flats, again, you can see the ways in which neighborhoods were manipulated and separated during that time. On a visit to Robben Island the next day, I was lucky enough to chat with a grandmother, mother and daughter. As we were chatting and I mentioned that I had visited the District 6 museum the day before, the grandmother noted that she was married in the church where the museum is now housed. Her family were residents of District 6 before they were forcibly removed. It was really special to have been able to meet her and her family, and I'm thankful for her willingness to share with me.

Important but boring museum. Even tough the story this museum plans to tell is sad and compelling, its actual exhibitions are poor. A lot of text makes you bored. It's worth visiting, but do not expect much.

District Six Mueseum. Popped into district six museum on the off chance and I'm glad I did. What an interesting insight into the history of Cape Town. Lots of photographs and personal recollections from residents of district six which gave a very interesting view of life in Cape Town pre apartheid, well worth a visit.

Sadness of Yesteryear which must be Witnessed. it was a most enlightening experience for both my wife and our pre teens. Being part of the previously disadvantaged community, one is drawn into the empathy and sadness and hurts of the past. Being part of cross cultural tour group made up at the museum, it was most interesting and sometimes disturbing to witness how the different groups interpreted this experience. Be prepared to be emotionally touched. The tour guides were very informative and passionate as they were part of the reality upon which the museum was based on. The tour guides were also well trained to handle the animosity of certain people who were in the group. A must for people visiting Cape Town.

A must see for first time visitors to Cape Town. With eight people in our group, we visited the District Six Museum with our trip guide. His explanations of the exhibit were very insightful. The District Six Museum was established in 1994. The museum is on two levels with many displays of home life, business life and spiritual life in a community that was completely wiped out. Hard to believe this happened in 1966. Visit this museum before you take a tour of any township.

Must go for first timers to South Africa. We had barely heard about District Six and it's importance until our visit to Cape Town. So naturally heading down to the District Six museum and reading everything helped us to have a good initial understanding.Definitely recommended to visit for any first timers to Cape Town and those who would like to learn more about the history. Add this to your other museum visits which is best done on the same day also making use of the Citysightseeing red bus.

Seems like it's missing something. I knew so little about District Six that I was compelled to visit this museum to learn more and to hopefully understand why District Six was such an important piece of South Africa's history.What I found was a small project which did very little to explain the importance of District Six outside of the fact that it was one of the largest areas where people were forcefully removed from their existing premises. I don't want to down play the importance of this museum but I think there needs to be something more to the museum for people to completely understand why District Six is so important.Downstairs seems to explain the boundaries of District Six, along with the timeline.Upstairs has artefacts from the era and explains a little how they are slowly reclaiming their original land.

A window into the past. Housed in a former church, this museum tells of the multi cultural life in this area which was all but flattened in the name of slum clearance and removed the poorer people (mainly blacks and coloured people) from the inner city.It got very noisy when a party of school children arrived.Small refreshment counter.

Go if you are already intrested. Frankly I knew nothing about District six or it's History if I had I am sure this would have been fascinating but I left with little real impression other then that the museum was a sort of community project from a community that felt done down . But with no point of reference I could not even say that I agreed with that. Oddly when I left Cape Town my taxi driver pointed out where district six was and I got it much more then at the Museum, I am not saying this is a bad place to visit but by the high standards of other attractions in Cape Town could be given a miss by the causal visitor
Great History. One of my favourite museums in Cape Town, really great setting in the old church and great history and friendly staff.

Interesting & Informative visit. Spent a fascinating morning at the District Six Museum. A small, personalised museum housed in a beautiful old church. Tickets are easily booked online. If you visit on a week-end there is free parking available behind the museum in front of Charly's bakery (saves you from paying for parking on the street). If you have the time it is worth booking a walking tour of the district which is usualy with an ex-resident, you get a better feel for the area and a more personalised view. A very interesting morning - thank you.

Not very hopeful. First of all, be prepared to walk a fair distance on foot as there is no parking nearby. Secondly, don't fall over the sign on the pavement in your rush to get there. The entrance is kept well-hidden except, one supposes, from tour operators who cram in the busloads of foreign tourists.Then be prepared to be a bit under-whelmed by the mish-mash of displays crammed in the large open space of what once was the nave of a church. There seems to be little effort at organising themes and the prevailing mood is no more than a wish to return to the old days of street gangs, shebeens, drug-lords and despondency.The exhibits themselves are not very inspiring: mainly old street signs, maps, newsprint and faded snapshots to prove how terrible it all was when the shanty-town was eventually torn down. Not much seems to point to a better future and what the community is doing apart from trying to collect grants and hand-outs..Nowhere is the visitor reminded that District 6 was far from unique. Towns are torn down all over the world on a daily basis, many of them for so-called political reasons. The truly remarkable stories are about how communities rebuild themselves successfully. Now that would be a museum worth seeing. Until then may I suggest making more fruitful use of your time?

Interesting with history in pictures. I was apprehensive of visiting the museum as I remember when District 6 happened as a young child. Even although I found the experience sad and moving, I enjoyed the pictures and the way that the museum brings life back into the area and part of South African history, worth a visit, especially to see the beautiful long hand worked message cloth loveingly crafted by the community.

Very interesting, worth a visit. The museum will give you the real story about what happened in District 6 - how Black people were forcibly removed from their homes and businesses, and communities destroyed during the Apartheid era. Also, the recompense they have sought since the end of this.Set in a small church, there's a lot of information to take in - but definitely worth a visit.

Overrated. First we got lost finding the place cause it is tucked away in a small corner and the place itself is also very small and not well advertised on the street. when we came there I found it to expensive for the time that we had been there and the things that we did. We booked a 'tour' guide who took us outside and tell somethings about the history on this part of town. Most of the time I could not hear the guide and the tour wasnt very special. after that we could walk on our own in the museum. Although it was really nice displayed and the history behind it was amazing, I think they could made this place so much better.

the smallest museum I have ever visited.. one hall that contain pictures and items of old south African culture. it did Not add anything to the information that any one has for the history of South Africa. simply,I-personally- would Not recommend it at all.

A brilliant insight into the apartheid problems of South Africa. The local guide who gave an impassioned talk on the re-location of the black community was outstanding and highlights the problems within the country as a whole

Gives you a glimpse of what life was really like in District Six. This museum is a collection of photographs and stories of the people who lived in District Six during the Sixties and who were forcibly removed up until the late Eighties by when the bulldozers had flattened most of it. I'm not sure if they do individual guided tours, but if they do, it would be well worth it. We were lucky to be able to spend a bit of time talking to Noor Ebrahim, one of the original residents of District Six and one of the group of founders of the musuem, and to get an insight into what life was like in those days - both good and bad - and how it compares today.
Definitely worth a visit. This museum is definitely worth a few hours of your time! Its mostly just photos and stories so has a very human element.

Best to go with a guided tour. I made the mistake of visiting this museum without a guide. It was a mistake because it is such a small museum that when a lot of tour guides came over with their groups right after I entered the museum, I was completely distracted and could not focus on anything. So many groups crowding such a small place kills the experience for individual visitors. So, better wait for their guided tours and take one of them. But even without the tours, the information displayed in the museum can be found anywhere else easily.

An unexpected insight into District Six. An easy museum to navigate with well presented facts and good insight into the people that lived in District Six many years ago. My children, aged 10 and 12 years, enjoyed it as well and understood the so-called reasons for the upheaval because of the way it was presented. Having ex-residents available to speak to is great, especially for the tourists as it gives them an added experience.

Definitely worth the visit. I love African history so I thoroughly enjoyed spending time in this museum. I love how it is set up and way the streets are drawn on the floor. All of the personal stories, memories. You can easily spend three hours.

Sobering. Very Sobering.. The Museum is like going into a petrified forest. Everything is well preserved - searing reminders of a horrible season in the Republic of South Africa. I loved how thoughtfully preserved and placed everything was. There is nothing like having something you only heard or read about searing your eyeballs with truth and reality - it was almost too overwhelming. Check out the photos I attached and you'll see why. If you live history, go here. If you hate reality shows but love REALITY, go here. You might need some air afterward, but that's a good sign that you have a heart and a conscience.

District 6 Museum. District 6 Museum is a must to gain some insight into the effects on communities of the apartheid era. The "coloured" community in District 6 (a desirable location) was evicted so that Capetown could be declared "white". The museum is a stop on the "red" tourist bus route and cost (I think) 30 Rand. Two hours spent here will leave a deep impression.

Fascinating. A truly unusual place that is full of atmosphere. Crowds seem to ebb and flow around the walls of photos so just take your time and you will see what you want to eventually. Quite rightly this highlights the lives of the people and families involved in he area, not celebrity figures or politicians who usually get all the attention. Deserves support.

A special place. This is a really special museum, it's really more of a large memory bank, holding the images, words, music of a place that is no more. You need to come and see it for yourself to really understand. Please do, it's worth it

A museum that must be visited.... To have any chance of understanding the modern history of Cape Town and its black/coloured community, this museum has to be ones priority for a visit. The photos show many stories but there are local people on hand to share their lives and their experience with anyone who is interested. An excellent museum and this gave much food for thought...

A sad chapter in history. We visited the District Six Museum with a university study group. The museum guide, Joe Schaffers, brought the story of forced relocation to life for us. I will never forget what I learned that day. Thanks, Joe.

Excellent Museum experience. Incredible and sad story told in this little gem of a museum. Uniquely told and definitely worth joining a tour led by former residents. Recommend stopping off at the Bo Kaap area right afterwards to get a feel for what District Six might once have been like.

Worth a visit!. As we were staying in a hotel in District 6 we loved learning a bit more about the history. We even found where our hotel was on the map that covers the floor of the downstairs of the museum. My husband was taken aback that so much prime real estate in a city could be just scrubland so the visit helped us learn the hows and whys.The books left for old tenants of the houses were also really interesting. One mentioned celebrating Guy Fawkes night which I had only ever heard of being observed in the UK! Certainly worth a visit.
Small but perfectly formed. I cried my way around this museum. If you are in Cape Town this museum is a must. Thanks to all the people who run it.

A shocker if you don't know history. If you ever wondered how the townships started in Cape Town, or if you don't know the history of SA go there and learn. This museum is the answer to so many questions. The apartheid nationalist government thought that the white needed more space in the 1960s, so they totally erased this city district and actually leveled the homes of coloured and black inhabitants to the ground. They were instead moved 40 - 50 kilometers to the east, i.e. the present township of Khayelitsha. This small museum tells the powerful story of displaced people.

Very interesting. Small museum dedicated to the famous district that was destroyed in the 60's. Very interesting and informative. Our visit to District 6 was followed by a tour of Langa Township, equally interesting. Not to be missed.

district six museum. Visit this small but well organized museum to get a full sense of the impact of apartheid laws on the coloured people of Capetown. The extent to which the then-government went to dispossess people of their homes and their dignity remains hard to believe.

A musuem that tells of tragic events less than fifty years ago !. The longer you stop here , and read all the articles , newspapers, letters , posters ,and some very moving personel bits of writing , the more you feel the injustice of what happened ,not so long ago . Its not a big musuem , I think its housed in a old church hall with a gallery , everything on display tells a story ,@ the rear is a small room with a tea bar , & dvd presentation . Allow 2 two hours & be prepared to be very moved .The Red Hop On & Off Bus stops outside look for the red route if boarding elsewhere .
Get a glimse of how they remember it. Small museum but interesting exhibit of District 6, apartheid memorabilia and lots of info. Interesting place.

Must See. Gives a good insight into the chill of apartheid. District6 being bulldozed and the people dispersed. Personal stories, photos and accounts. Art instillations explain the heartache. Very simple museum but full of pain.

Informative & Moving - Be Prepared to Read Lots. OK, if you are expecting a lot of audio and Disney like effects to give you the story of this very famous neighborhood and its history, you will be disappointed. It's worth the visit, but the museum is small and you have to read a lot to really get the gist of what happened. You can see everything thoughtfully, in about an hour or less.
Fast emptiness. Amazingly you will encounter a fast empty space will will not mean much unless you stop by the District Six Museum. Or better in combination with a township tour.
If you have some time to spare!. Not getting too much information out of it - but if you are there stop by. I think in conjunction with a township visit you will get the mist out of it.

this museum is worth a visit. Take an hour or so to visit this personal little museum, try and keep the street names in mind and then take the hop on hop off bus which goes through the area.............it made me realise just how big an area had been cleared. The stories on the walls show you how thriving the communities were..........tales of ordinary people trying to live their lives.

Interesting - educational. Great place to spend an hour or so. The museum itself is quite small, but there's plenty of information to read on. Lots of information and history to absorb. Coming from Canada, I was kind of taken back learning that the history of Cape Town and district 6 only happened not long ago... A very interest place, if you have the hour to spare, definitely come here and take a look.

The effect of apartheid evidenced. This museum about district six and what happened when it was 'cleared' of the residents to make way for houing for whites is fascinating. I had little knowledge of this part of South Africa's history and the excelelnt guide brought this alive . The museum is quite small but has so much to see and to learn. I could have spent much longer there. For a moving account of what happenend to the people of District Six you must visit this museum. The photos and exhibits tell the story. The old street signs are a poignant reminder of a community displaced.

interesting. very interesting to learn more about district 6 and that period of time, some very emotive pieces in here and some other pieces that simply illustrate peoples lives. All in all an interesting hour,
Part of Cape Town and South Africa history. An interesting insight in apartheid and the day to day lives of people living under it. Should be on to do list of everyone who visits Cape Town.

A very personal history. My Canadian friend and I visited this museum as part of the Hop on / Hop off bus' red route. I found the lay-out very interesting, if a bit 'busy' in some places. Lots to read and lots to see. It is not a big museum, but allow enough time. On arrival, the lady at reception told us about the video being shown at the back and sat down to watch it for a while. One of the old residents (who is also a guide and used to be a prominent community member) started talking to us there and we went happily along with him as he told us a few stories. He was not pushy, just sweet and very talkative. After a little while he left us to go to mosque and we continued on our own. I appreciate it that the community is part of the museum; it makes it a very personal experience. The map on the floor showing the previous location of houses of the various families is extremely poignant. The portrayals of community life is very informative as is the date line on the first floor. The shop is great, especially with many books being on sale as well as various memorabilia; not overly expensive either which is refreshing. You can book a tour with a guide, otherwise, just wander around on your own. Well worth a visit.
Very interesting. A lovely museum created by the people affected by the event. It is very touching and made the visit to the site much more poignant.
Excellent overview. A complicated piece of history, well explained. Displays are tied to individuals who lived in the area, and come to life that way.

Do not let anyone appoint himself as your guide!. Fascinating museum, especially as "coloured history" is fairly widely overlooked both in discourses and in teaching. I did not like the man who designated himself our guide - fearmongering and running the country down isn't really what I'm looking for. It left a bad taste in the mouth. Declarations of "all the whites are laving; there will be blood in the streets" didn't add to the experience of the museum. He was extremely bossy, directing us all where to stand. At the end of the tour (we didn't get a chance to read any of the material on the walls), he shook a container at us and insisted that we put money into it.I think that having been left to my own devices to explore and read at my own pace would have been more beneficial, and would have had me feeling more positive. It is a great museum and an important part of history, but was doomed by the self-appointed guide.

Interesting history, but difficult museum. The history of District Six is both horrible and interesting at the same time and it's very good that there is a museum for it so that this is not forgotten. Our only problem with the museum was that it was so "all over the place". There were texts, signs, maps and photos everywhere so it was difficult to really appreciate everything and take it in. Maybe there was a starting point that we missed and then an order to go through the museum in, but in that case we didn't see it.

A moving window on to a lost world. This museum is well worth a visit. It was very moving to reflect on what might have been had mixed communities such as this had not been deliberately destroyed and what it will take for the new South Africa to recreate a truly integrated society or whether that is at all possible.
so intense. one needs to take it easy, read, and look. it is quiet, and not necessarily to get a guide. great place, and worth the time.

interesting and clear exhibits on Apartheid. Upon our visit to Cape Town this was our intro into the Apartheid and what the implications were for the residents in the area. Had bare-bones understanding prior to the museum which had lots of photographs, stories and history laid out in an easy to follow and thoughtful way. So shocking that the events of District 6 were so recent. Absolutely a must-do on a visit to Cape Town!

HISTORY. The manner in which they have depicted the history of District Six is remarkable. I have been to the Museum on 4 occasions and never tier in soaking up another piece of our remarkable history
Must visit. If you come to a South Africa you must know something about its history. This museum is small but you get the story and know more than you did when you came in. It doesn't take long

Gem of Cape Town Troubled Past. With original documents and things from the time when District Six was a lively and dynamic neighbourhood, the museum is a look into the passed that was Cape Town. Small and intimate with great staff.

Wonderfully Thoughtfull. This is a must visit place to see what man can still do to man . It shows how social planning destroyed a vibrant community and left a legacy of despair. The pictures the exhibits and especially the writing are so moving all should be made to visit to ensure that this should never happen again.

Thought provoking!. A humbling experience and a true eye-opener. A must to anyone visiting Cape Town - And it's free! The pictures and artwork on the walls depict a way of life long since gone, and show a community with a real spirit which still exists today. This is demonstrated amply by the Cape Town Carnival, also a real must do if visiting in Cape Town in January.

So interesting!. We were recommended to this museum by people on the bus tour we were on, so we got off and tried it out. We found it very interesting as coming from the UK we had no knowledge of this district and what went on. My teenage kids were totally fascinated by all that happened in this area. Later on our bus tour they mentioned the area and we drove through it and found it so much more informative because we had been to the museum. Its very sensitively laid out and so informative. There is a video film at the back of the museum which was incredible and well worth sitting and listening.

Could be so much better. This small museum tries to tell the moving story of the people forcibly moved from their homes in a Cape Town district to make room for developers and whites only during the 1960's. It's worthy, but it needs a better narrative, and an injection of cash to bring it up to par with its peers in museums of social history. The video area is particularly poor, with a knackered old TV and poor production values. Imagination and money would make this a first-rate museum. I hope it can be done.

A time capsule. The District Six Museum documents the vibrant and multiracial community of the same name that was razed during Apartheid. It also shows the history of the struggle more widely. It is creatively laid out to give the museum goer an in-depth experience, not as such, it is not simply a set of placards with dry facts. Definitely worth a stop.

Very good museum, definitely a must if you ask me!. The District Six museum is small and easy to navigate through. I found it very moving because it shows how individuals and families were affected by apartheid. Both times I was there I had the chance to speak to someone who himself lived through the struggle this museum deals with which made the experience much more personal, sad but personal and unique. I can definitely recommend this museum and as I said it's small, you don't need a lot of time to learn about what's shown. Definitely worth a visit!

Walk Back in Time. A Must Visit if you have an interest in the History of this Rich Culture.Yes there are Scares to Heal but the Story to be Shared here is Worth the Visit.I Leave the Front Door with a Whole New Appreciation.

A real commemorative visit.... This museum honors the residents of District Six who were forcibly removed during the Apartheid era,it reflects the diverse people who lived there:merchants,artisans,&immigrants.It's the street map of former residents' addresses, which brings the human reality home.
A must in Cape Town. Well worth visit museum, as you will see a lot of history in one place. Very educational and must visit while in Cape Town.

Essential to a visit to South Africa. A great museum and experience. Our travel agent had arranged a personal tour by a former resident who works at the museum. This enhanced the visit greatly. Give yourself time to just be in the space and with the exhibits.

A thought provoking trip. I went here with my 2 boys and came away feeling we are better informed of the brutality of the apartheid regime that took place in South Africa. We thoroughly enjoyed wandering around the museum and learning about district 6.This museum is a must visit place and we are very glad we took time out to visit it.

A place for reflection. This an emotive and disturbing museum.We spent an hour here,but needed more time It was included in a tour of the townships, and it helps you to try to understand the true meaning of the Apartheid system. The population were simply removed by the government not en masse but according to their ethnicicity.Black, Malay and Cape coloured were separated even though they had lived as neighbours all their lives, some for forty years. During our visit to S.A. we also visited Jo'burg and the Apartheid Museum there , visit both if you can.

An important topic, but presented in a confusing way. The museum portrays the history of a really important district in South Africa and how it came to be no more. I'm sure to the people of the city - especially those who lived in District Six - the museum must hold a unique significance. However, as a first-time visitor to the country with no prior knowledge of District Six, I found the museum to be a little confusing. It was only after I'd thought about the exhibits afterwards that I could understand what I'd seen, and even then I have lots of unanswered questions. My advice to a prospective visitor is to do some research/reading beforehand to help you get the most out of your trip.

A must stop if you are researching any aspects of the apartheid regime. Coupled with the Apartheid museum in Jo'burg and also trip to the Cape Town township, one really gets a feel for the disturbing events during the Apartheid years. This museum is informative and tries to recreate the area of Cape Town where a whole community once thrived. Its made more interesting by the fact that some people helping run the museum actually witnessed and suffered the cruelty and sadness that is now part of history. Thank you to one and all for sharing it.

Interesting and moving. Not so much a museum but a reflection on a district that Botha decided should be an upperclass white area so he had the whole area systematically bulldozed and relocated the occupants elsewhere. There are dozens of old photographs showing how it looked and the people that lived and worked there. Reflections from former residents. A lot have signed a long cloth along with their thoughts and memories. A lesson in what has been and thankfully will never be again. Worth visiting. there is also a small cafe at the back.

The best part is that a former resident meets with you. On the cold, rain-drenched, blustery day of our visit, we found that the museum itself was closed. Some VIPs had just visited and they were recovering from that, plus preparing new exhibits. Our guide took us to a nearby auxiliary museum area, apologizing and saying that the main place was more moving because of the map on the floor where former residents can mark the sites of their old homes. But I think visitors who did not personally experience the destruction of the vibrant District 6 community, with its harmonious mixture of races and the close ties among the residents, would find the offshoot museum satisfying and informative. This offshoot is more of a community space in which former residents can meet and stage productions for each other. The large room is festooned with banners giving the history of the old district, with a video area where you can sit and watch the same former resident who met with us give his spiel for the camera. I was taken by this dignified older gentleman, who gave his time tom our group and answered questions. There is also a little gift and book shop.

Sunset Walk Through Undiscovered Cape Town. Sunset Walks are held every Thursday at 17h00 or by booking at the museum, through the empty space that used to be District Six. On a barren landscape, a storyteller takes you back to the days of Ma Stette's Shebeen and the jazz and strip bars, the churches and mosques side by side in a part of South Africa that had a beautiful and generous soul. The stories are unforgettable, the pieces of history you pick up along the way are inspiring and heartbreaking. You'll never see Cape Town or drive through the District in the same way again. Highly, highly recommended.

another must see place in Cape Town if you are there for a few days. A very moving museum. I had to visit after hearing about the demolition of District 6 on the HOHO bus. At first I thought there was going to be too much reading but then we got to the photographs and items of the families that were displaced and it all started to register. They really loved their homes, humble as some of them were and to be uprooted like that was horrific.

Not Ancient History. This building is one of few remaining after Apartheid decided to separate nationalities, ethnicities, and religions -- who previously lived and worked peacefully side by side -- by BULLDOZING the entire neighborhood with the intent of making the area "For Whites Only". Imagine, coming home from work and, with NO warning, finding the whole area reduced to rubble!Now, forty years later, the area is being rebuilt and former residents are returning. The museum has actual photos, letters and other memorabilia from a most embarrassing and barbaric time in modern history!

District six museum. What an amazing and emotive place. Telling the incredible history of people who lived in this area and who were moved out against their will. The photos and hand written stories from individuals and families bring the history to life. It's a real down to earth place which gives a gritty feel to its oats history. Go there you will enjoy it !

Worth Visiting. You could spend ages here depending on how much you want to read.  There is lots to get through.  We spent an hour and a half and could have spent longer if we didn't have tickets booked for Robben island.  Other people told us you need only 45 minutes so it depends on how much you like to read things.The receptionist also called a taxi for us which was useful.  The place was under construction when we visited so it was a bit hard to find.
get a good sense of apartheid here. from the plaque outside even before you enter you can tell this museum is a labour of love for those involved with it. Moving stuff, be warned you might get angry.

Small, but tells a bigger story. This is a small museum but tell a powerful story of a displaced people. If you ever wondered how the townships started in Cape Town, this is the place you should go. This museum answers so many of those questions. Here you will find pictures, documents, stories of past residents of District 6. It tells of the human toil of District 6 residents displacement. It will make you reexamine how humans inflict pain and their will on others. Call before going to insure guides are available, it is well worth the extra cost.

Best museum in Cape Town. This museum was 2 blocks from our Hotel and we were amazed at the amount of personal touches and local information. The history of District 6 is something that is hard to fathom in todays world. I highly recommend a stop at this museum. If you take the red hop on hop off tour it is one of the stops on the route. There is a great little café inside as well for coffee and food.

A real eye opener. We have been in Cape town for 2 weeks and went to the district six museum on our last day before going home. We had heard a lot about apartheid in our time there, but it never really sunk in until we went here. This museum showed the reality of it where the government wiped out a busy urban space and literally levelled everything to the ground just to get rid of the coloured and black occupants. A real shocker.

WORTH A VISIT. My husband and I visited this museum on Wednesday the 9th October – the city sight-seeing bus stops right outside it. We browsed the displays, artefacts etc and found it all shocking and very interesting. It definitely gives a strong flavour of the wrongs that happened in South Africa, giving succinct descriptions of how the whites moved the blacks out of areas to make way for white people. Worth a visit.

Poignant reminder of apartheid history. This is a small,very focused museum. It is not flashy, there is no glitz or high tech displays, which is exactly as it should be. This is a somber reminder of a sad period of history. To forget this history is to risk repeating it.
museum. This was fantastic history. We did this before our langa township tour. We had a local take us on the tour of the museum and the township. He lived in the township

Interesting Museum. This is a nice little museum that gives the history of District Six an area of Cape Town that was hard it from apartheid. Based on other reviews we just did the self guided tour and it was great. Takes about an hour to go through and you can get here from the Red Hop On/Hop Off tour buses.

A small, focused glimpse into the Apartheid system. The District Six museum is tightly focused on the forced removal of 60,000 people and the bulldozing of their homes in this diverse Cape Town neighborhood between 1966 and 1982. The area was never rebuilt and is still largely undeveloped. Because of its focus on purely local history--there's a large street map covering the ground floor on which former residents have written their names where their houses were located, for instance, and exhibits include old street name plates, photographs and newspaper stories from the area/period--the museum's smallness and focus becomes a strength. The District Six Museum's tight focus on the local and specific provides a powerful glimpse into the arbitrariness and evil of the Apartheid system as a whole.

Well worth your time; very moving. District Six was a black and colored area of Cape Town that was claimed by the white apartheid government. Houses were bulldozed and families were displaced. It was a very sad time in the history of Cape Town, but something that needs to be remembered. Displays at the District Six Museum include original street signs, many handmade quilts created in the words of families who were forced to leave the area, and a re-created room in memory of residents of District Six.It was emotional for me, but something I am so glad I had an opportunity to do.

Sad story...... ...............told in a friendly way. District 6 was a mixed community of freed slaves, merchants, artisans, labourers and immigrants till the Apartheid regime declared a white area under the Group Areas Act in 1966. 60 000 people were forced by the goverent to the Cape Flats and their houses were tear down by bulldozers. Very interesting museum which is telling a lot about of the dark story of Apartheid.

Poignant. What makes this museum special and interesting is that is so ordinary, it is full of pictures of ordinary people living ordinary lives in a community who just because of the colour of their skins lost their homes and community. This is what brings the history of to life. We could not help thinking of the slum clearance schemes in post war England, the communities hated these schemes, hated being uprooted from their past but it was being done with the hope of giving families a better life. How much worse it must have been in District Six when communities were destroyed for such an awful reason.

Well worth spending the time to attempt to comprehend Apartheid. District Six represent a face of Apartheid that help you see conflict and confusion that continues to evolve after the official end to Apartheid policies in South Africa. Slavery came with the earliest presence of Western influence to this part of Africa and will take many years to move beyond, despite the political changes. This small building is a good touch point to help calibrate ones view of this history. In some ways this was better or maybe a good compliment to the Apartheid Museum in Johannesburg?

Great Historical experience. The District 6 museum is definitely the top museum in Cape Town and a must see. There's an entire history of slavery rooted in South Africa that most people (at least in the States) never learn about. The museum does a great job connecting this history with the development of the community and it's destruction through apartheid mostly through the voices of it's residents. Just keep in mind they close at 4 so give yourself time.

Politically orientated. Interesting place to visit but the guides certainly punt the apartheid past to the fullest. This spoils the experience for everyone. I am a local, but noticed that many overseas tourists turned away muttering that they had had a bit of an overdose about the horrors of the era! As a local, why not rather give tourists a taste of unique and colourful Cape Coloured humour. More friends are made through the humour and a shared laugh than the morbid horror stories of a by-gone era!

Interesting Take on the History of District Six. My husband and I decided to visit the District Six Museum while on the City Sightseeing Bus Tour, as the museum was a stop along the way. The entire history of District Six is very interesting, but I thought the museum left a bit to be desired. In my opinion it was not very well curated and it was not clear to me which exhibit to visit first or essentially where to start and then how to navigate through the rest of the content. The material also seemed to be more focused on sharing the stories of individuals who lived during that time period which is great, but it would have helped to have more background before reading those histories. Much of the print in museum was very small and difficult to read if there was a crowd around that particular exhibit. The physical signs, objects, maps, etc. that are housed in the museum were a highlight for me. The cost of entrance was only about USD 3 so this museum is worth visiting if you have some extra time.

Leaves you with a lot to think about. I knew nothing about the history of District Six until our visit to Cape Town. Only when we visited the museum did we get a sense for what was lost. The museum is in an old building that survived the destruction of the time. The exhibits can be seen in under an hour if pressed for time, but much more time is needed to fully comprehend the enormity of what happened in this once bustling, multiracial neighborhood. There are touching written histories from the people who survived the demolitions, newspaper accounts of the time, and, heartbreakingly, a wooden bench with the sign "For Europeans Only". There was a photographic display of several families who lived in the area, Italians, Blacks, Indians and Malays, with written descriptions of life before and after. Life was never the same, neighbors and friends lost, an entire web of life destroyed. There are copies of identity cards that were required of all South Africans that prominently show one's race, and that was emotionally difficult to see.The museum challenges the way we think about maps and who gets to make them, about race, about community and shared history. I think it could be improved by having survivors there to tell their stories to visitors in person, or by video or invite the recording of oral histories. Shockingly, the land of District 6 was never developed after the destruction. Why? I understand that there was a dispute, but what kind of dispute? Is it being resolved? These are questions that the museum could provide answers to, at least more clearly than I could gather from my visit. Some of the exhibits were difficult to make out, with writing in bas relief on white walls in a small room upstairs so I felt I was missing something.It is an important part of history to know something about, and reflect on what happened there so it never happens again. An important place to visit.

Fantastic. We went here as part of a tour we had done into some of the shanty towns. Amazing to see the history of Capetown, as history not often talked about. Would recommend it to anyone who would like to know the truth!
very interesting. went there with the red city sightseeing bus. very interesting and sad to read about the apartheid days in an original building that was in the middle of it all!

Perfect for All Ages- Highly Recommended. As a college student I was astounded while visiting the District Six Museum because I knew barely ANYTHING about the history of this area which was all explained in detailed stories during our visit. I was SO happy to go here and learn so much more about the history of the world we live in. There were so many beautiful aspects to this attraction and I believe everyone owes it to themselves to spend an afternoon here and learn something.

Celebration as well as commemoration. The wholesale destruction of a thriving community was a terrible thing, but the District Six Museum rises above recrimination - it's a loving portrait of what was lost, and thus all the more powerful an indictment of apartheid. What's disconcerting is to realise how recent these events were. Ex-residents work in the museum and can explain more to you in person; there's a register for families and addresses in which people have made additions and amendments and left their cellphone numbers so they can get back in touch.

Thought provoking. This museum illustrates the life which was terminated by the destruction of District 6. It is not well advertised and quite hard to find - although it's only a short walk from the Company Gardens. It has a homely intimate feel but packs a real emotional punch. It is clearly a community venture and all the better for that after the rather soulless museums elsewhere in Cape Town.

Interesting and evocative. Tells the story of the forced evictions of the coloured community really well. Lots of personal stories. The layout is quirky and informal but the messages are strong. This isn't the place to learn the political history of apartheid but for the human interest angle it is well worth the visit.
Thought provoking museum. A truly understated human story at district six. It really gives you an indepth understanding of how in was in the 60s and 70s in this part of Cape Town.

Illuminating and unique museum. The District 6 museum is an excellent and uplifting tribute, memorial, and depository of information. It is not a Wikipedia page, meant to provide the basic historical information in a staid and textbook-like format. It represents and evokes life and communities during the different periods and show the effects of the forced displacement. The museum is small, and I can imagine it being difficult to enjoy on a very crowded day. Really excellent overall and definitely worth visiting.

Intimate history of a community. Besides telling the heartbreaking tale of displacement of the District 6 families, this museum tells about the vibrant life of the community in happy times. I read the lowest reviews here and I agree with what several said: This museum is not "well-curated." however I think that's what makes it special. It does not have a carefully selected object that makes each point; it has every object that someone wanted to donate. There are beautiful parts (embroidery, a room worthy of a modern art museum, banners, etc.), and there is the clutter of everyday life. The museum feels like I imagine the living community must have been like.DON'T MISS: To the right as you walk in the front door, halfway up the stairs, is the tale of a pigeon keeper. It is a poignant metaphor of District 6.

Important Stop for All Visiting Cape Town. Really great to see all of the stuff they've preserved from this time. Don't miss the video in the back room that explains everything a puts all in perspective. When I was there the man who narrates the video was there. I suspect he's there often. Great to chat with him.
Well set out. It showed the history of Cape Town during Apartheid and made you appreciate the hardship they went through

A Nice Historical Perspective. Spend a couple of hours here to learn about the history of Cape Town, it is interesting to see the street signs from this area that was demolished, read the stories of the inhabitants, and learn the history of Cape Town. It is in an old converted one-room church, so a few hours is enough to get through it.

A gem of a museum. This is small but packs a big punch. There are excellent displays tracing the history of the area which was cleared to make Cape Town "all white" during the apartheid era. There is moving testimony from former residents, poetry and video and a large map where residents have plotted where they lived.There are plans to redevelop the site and there is a lot of community engagement taking place, and the museum is at the heart of that. Hopefully this will result in a positive future for the area.A very moving experience, it reminded me of watching the horrendous news reports of what was happening in South Africa at the time, when I was enjoying a safe life in the UK.

Very Moving. This is quite a small museum but extremely moving. It really puts things into perspective and shows how whole masses of people were removed for no good reason whatsoever and had their lives shattered. It is very well done and for anyone wanting to find out more about Apartheid then it is well worth a visit and is very good value.
touching. very friendly staff who explains to you what he/she knows, did enter without paying cause no one sat there and payed when I left. Plan some time to discover, read and feel!

District 6 Museum. A great museum for lots of reasons - but mainly the horrible things that were done to break up communities in the name of 'progress'. We can look back with shame, but forward with a lot of hope for the new South Africa.

Displaced community remembered. This museum had a great emotional impact, though the exhibits were upbeat, celebrating the lives and culture of the people who were forced out and relocated. Have one of the guides put a more personal touch on what it was like to live in this area.
Moving and educational. A must for any visitor to Cape Town. A simple museum filled with the story of those families 'displaced' by apatheid

Read all about it, then experience it!. I suggest you read what you can about Cape Town's district six. It is one of the most despicable adventures of apartheid in the entire despicable era. This museum, if carefully viewed, will make you feel the pain, the oppression. It will also make you hopeful for a brighter future for South Africa. Be sure to explore the actual district a bit to see the lasting effects of a destroyed mixed neighborhood. It will make you say to yourself the might does not make right.

Get off the bus and visit!. If you are taking the red bus tour around Cape Town, you should really consider getting off (stop #9) and visiting this museum. It is pretty inexpensive - I think we paid R30 a person and well worth it. The displays are static, but interesting. What really made our visit memorable was the chance to talk to a former resident of District 6.
