The museum charges an extra R15 to get a guided tour with a former resident, but at the end of our visit, we had a question and asked this gentlemen and he took the next 15 minutes to talk to us about his experiences, how he watched the government bulldoze his house when he was a boy to the current plans to reintegrate District 6. Before getting back on the bus, make sure you stop at the nearby Charlies Bakery to pick up some delicious baked goods for the second half of your bus tour!
Gave the Story. I didn't know much of the story behind district 6. This helped me see the area from the eyes of those who lived there and experienced the uphevel.

Starting to look a little tired and forlorn. When I last visited this museum in 2002, it was still relatively new and fresh. Now sadly, it looks tired and slightly run-down. I understand that in a country like South Africa with its poverty, unemployment and crime; spending on cultural institutions like this one is way down on the list of priorities. Still, it’s a pity to see this interesting place stagnate. Yes it still looks almost exactly like it did 11 years ago but that’s just the problem. It’s frozen in time. Nothing has changed, nothing has been updated. There are no current exhibitions and from the look of it there hasn’t been one for a while. All the quotes you’ll see on the walls, from former politicians, activists and residents seem to have stopped around 1999.If you look at the museum’s website for example, you’ll see that the last “past event” was a public lecture in Feb 2011 and the latest Annual Report is from 2008. There is nothing under “News and events”.But still, if you’re interested in the history of this country and this city, it’s worth a visit. These guys want people to hear their stories and they need money to fill their coffers. And it costs only R30 to enter (at June 2013) which is the equivalent of $US3. The museum tells the story of a once mixed race part of Cape Town, which was known as District 6. Now don’t ask me about Districts 1-5 and so on: I asked the curator and even he didn’t seem to know, so let’s assume that the districts of the city were numbered and this one was number 6. But it was a particularly vibrant and colourful part of the city, albeit a tad seedy and run-down in later years. It became famous (or notorious) because the apartheid-era authorities decided in the 1970s, in the interests of keeping the inner city white, to dismantle the whole place i.e. bulldoze it into the ground and move the coloured and black inhabitants to outlying areas of the city. Despite protests the scheme went ahead: District 6 was demolished and the residents forcibly moved out. Yet another indignity suffered by black people during the Apartheid years. The exclusive white suburb that was supposed to rise from the ashes of the old District 6 never got off the ground mainly due to the stigma attached to the area because of the way in which it was destroyed.Today, I’m told, that former residents are attempting to reclaim the area and move back to where they once lived. But however that pans out, sadly, the once lively and bustling District 6 is gone forever. Only its memory lives on in this place.The story of D6 is told in old photos, newspaper cuttings, quotes and wall charts with timelines. Generally it’s a bit higgledy-piggledy and there’s a lot of information to read and digest, some of it in very small print which makes it even harder. The best way to deal with it is simply to wander around just reading and looking. There are only two levels which you can cover in less than two hours. Don’t try to follow it in a logical sequence because it doesn’t work like that. The building housing the museum was originally constructed as a wine store, but was for many years used as a church until it was transformed into this museum in 1994. That was when optimism and hope were at their peak in the newly democratic South Africa. There is a little café and a tiny shop selling a few books and postcards but not much else. On the day I visited, the café looked deserted and slightly forlorn.If you’re a tourist in the city, the best way to get here is by taxi but just be aware that it isn’t the most savoury part of town so caution (as always when travelling in South Africa) is recommended. It’s best to leave your valuables, credit cards, travel docs etc at your hotel and just have with you a small amount of cash. After visiting here, you can walk into the city centre in about 15 minutes and have a look around places like the St Georges Mall and Greenmarket Square, but generally the city centre doesn’t have a huge amount to recommend it and always be alert and aware.

Disappointed. I was really looking forward to visiting this museum, however it was really disappointing. I found there was too much information crammed in and the text and pictures were all quite small and difficult to get near to actually read with a crowd of people. It seemed like the displays were not in any kind of order and it was all a bit thrown together and a bit of a mish mash. I didn't really learn anything new. It may be a different experience with the museum guides who used to be residents there; these are only at certain times. I wouldn't say this is a must if you are only in Cape Town for a short time.

Insight to the past.. District 6 Museum could be a museum just about the apartheid era and oppression. But it is so much more. You are able to look into a rich history of the vibrant society which existed right there in the middle of Cape Town. Jazz clubs and jazz singers led an amazing night life. The rich tapestry of the life of the inhabitants is there in photographic evidence showing that the people of District 6 were a resilient community with the focus on community. The street signs on a pole are all that is left of the existence of this vibrant community but what is even more interesting is that when you go outside, the evidence of the clearing of district 6 is right there surrounding you. The inhabitants may have been moved on but they are not forgotten. The cleared land still stands waiting for someone to be brave enough to use it decades after the residents had their houses bulldozed. This museum is highly recommended. It is on the Hop On Hop off tour route also. Don't miss it. Donation entry.
OK. Disappointed by the size and what the museum had to offer. I can't say it was a "must" or a highlight of the day.
Interesting. We were really suprised how much we loved going here and how much we learnt. I would recommend it to anybody to visit and learn about the history of District Six.

Small but very educational. We learned so much in such a small space and a relatively short time. Plan at least 2 hours for this heart wrenching story. You will begin to understand what it was like to live in South Africa in the 1960's. A follow up visit to the crypt under the Anglican Cathedral will round out your learning. Try to read everything you see, and get the feel of the neighbourhood before it was completely disrupted. As always, its hard to understand our inhumanity to each other. There were several family photos and stories that made we want to cry.

Lovely feel. This museum presents a lot of information extremely attractively, really depicting the possible feel of District Six. It is, however, pretty small compared to other museums in the U.S. and Europe, making up for space with density. Lots of great primary sources and definitely worth checking out but probably not worth leaving more than 2 hours or so for. I would recommend a drive through the area of District Six after the museum if possible.
Great museum overall. When in Cape Town one should really visit this museum to get a better appreciation of SA difficult history. Great displays, layout, artifacts etc. We really enjoyed it.

Unique and informative. This is a unique and moving museum that tells the story of the area of District Six outside of Cape Town. It's like a living museum of the community; be sure to talk with Joe if you can to hear his own story of the history of the area.

A moving story of part of the history of the Cape. We had seen the empty fields and hills in Cape Town, and asked our guide to take us to District Six Museum to find out more of the story. The Museum is housed in one of the churches of the area, and tells the story of more than 60 000 black, colored, and white inhabitants of the area who were forcibly moved out from 1960 to 1982 to try and enforce the Apartheid Policy. The stories are told by the former inhabitants along with photos and objects from the time. This is a simple display but tells a very moving story.

less is more. i've lived in the cape town area all my life and have a fair knowledge of the history of district 6. from this background i found the museum to be a wonderful experience and i will return when i have half a day or a day available to really take in the enormous amount of information presented to the visitor.this is, sadly, also my biggest problem with the museum. there is simply too much information thrown at a visitor all at once. with no or very little knowledge of the area's history, i suspect, you will leave without a true sense of the events. an exhibition with a bigger focus on the visual, i.e. photos and video, would be much more accessable to a visitor. should one then have the time there can be an area where you can read more in detail about the inhabitants' personal experiences. in it's current form it is simply overwhelming.

Very Interesting. This is a great museum which details what happened in the sixties when the black and coloured people were forcibly removed from their houses. They have a fantastic map on the floor were people who previously lived in the district have marked where they lived and added little comments. The map is covered in plastic to preserve it and there is also a fantastic ongoing mural where people who lived in the district have shared their thoughts and comments and these have been embroided by community ladies to prevent the writing fading. Very clean and well laid out, worth a visit.

Very informative. I wish I would have gotten the guided tour it would have been a much more enriching experience. I did learn a lot about the plight of the people there and the damage/destruction this caused the community. This is one among many sites that remind us of our past failures.

Very informative, although the organization could use some work. A lot of fabulous information and really interesting stuff going on at this museum. If you're expecting to get a history of apartheid in SAfrica this is not the right museum, but it is an interesting window into a neighborhood of Cape Town. The exhibit is not extremely well designed in the sense that you might be confused as to which way to go, where to start, and where to continue...but it is certainly thought provoking.

a small, but moving, museum. the district six museum is a great stop while you are in cape town. really moving stories and well put together....could use some updating im sure but feels very authentic and you walk away thinking.... wow... it's insane this neighborhood is just off the map...so backwards. help support this museum and please visit.

Never forget. The history behind district 6 is heartbreaking even unbelievable. A must see in cape town .The curator was personally involved in the struggle. I applaud the forgiving messages reconciliation and unity!

Worth the Trip to SEE History. We stopped at District 6 Museum on our Township Tour. I was blown away with the preservation of history and the accounts of this once lively community. Try to schedule a tour of the museum so that you can go back in town and picture what used to be and what is now. Great experience!

Give yourself enough time there, and read up before you go.. Stopped here from the hop-on/hop-off bus, and felt that i didn't get the most out of the time there since i rushed through to try and see everything. When you enter and pay, the man does tell you the general flow that people take to view the museum, but i found that the entire layout was very random, making it difficult to fully absorb everything. Going in with minimal knowledge, I hoped there would be more about apartheid in general, in a broader sense (maybe the Apartheid Museum in Joburg would be better for that?) Still, it was really moving to see the direct impact on the specific community. I really appreciated the newspaper headlines and article clippings, the numerous interview excerpts as well as the "Homing Pigeon's View of Forced Removals" which is found on the wall along the stairwell at the right when you enter (if i remember correctly). The upstairs side exhibits seemed to be slightly disjointed from the downstairs, although i really enjoyed the room that was "filled with the cement". Due to time restriction, I ended up taking photos of most of the text so I could read it later. Definitely give yourself more than an hour's time to visit, minimum. The more you know about the history of apartheid before you go, the more you can concentrate and appreciate the amazing resource of information and history they have there at District Six.

Very informative. It's a small museum but very informative. Well worth a visit. Personally, I felt that they'd tried to squeeze in too much information into a small space, and found it heavy going in places, but nevertheless, still worth the visit.

Unique, but a bit wordy. A friend recommended that we visit the museum...a good stop on a rainy day. Though it was interesting, there was a lot of information to process for a tourist. I liked that the museum is a community project...more of a venue for the people who lived through apartheid to tell their story, a place where their kids and grandkids could learn about what happened. It has a unique, organic, "living" feel to it.
Educational. Did this museum as a school days out. There is hidden an gem of all important South African history! make sure to cut out a few hours on a rainy day to visit this museum.

A moving experience. This is a very important monument to some of the worst excesses of the apartheid regime. Although there is a huge amount of documentation and it is almost impossible to read it all, there is also a large amount of visual material and artefacts which tell the story very vividly. I agree that the design is somewhat confusing and it is at times not easy to follow the timeline. However we found it to be up there with Robben Island as a must visit in Caprtown.

not worth it. it is good, that things should not be forgotten, I read a lot about District Six and Apartheid, so I had rather high expectations. But when I was there I didn ´t get a better feeling for the time and left it disappointed.

Poorly designed. This is essentially a shrine to the displaced population of district 6 exhibiting personal recollections of life in the district and some contemporary artefacts. Whilst the concept is commendable, the design & layout of the exhibits was poor with no start or finish. There was information overload.Overall we found it confusing. It deserves a thorough revamp.
Very moving. Well presented and heart wrenching. I left in tears but enjoyed viewing the area from a whole new perspective afterwards knowing it's history.
Very moving. Always remembering what happened not so long ago. Young and old should visit if the happen o be in Cape Town
Grim but rewarding. A time capsule about a destroyed community giving some idea of the diversity of the area. However, displays are often difficult to read.

Food for thought and reflection about humanity. The inhabitants of district 6 were materially abysmally poor, marginalised and discriminated for the colour of their skin. This small museum depicts their misery, suffering and dispair during and after their displacement, leading to the total demolition of a whole area of the city. Today, the empty area of what was district 6 remains a blot on capetowns landscape...

Fantastic community museum. Much better than the National Museum-run Slave Lodge, this museum has emotion.It's in a great building in the centre of the area it is all about so you get a real sense of place. Full of interesting information displayed in engaging ways.

A must see. Often overlooked, this gem of a museum is a must see for anyone who is seriously looking into the history of South Africa. The Apartheid Museum and Robben Island Park are the most oft-cited attractions to learn about history, however a full understanding cannot even begun to be apprehended without learning the story of the "colored" -- those South Africans neither black nor Afrikaaner who ancestrally straddled both sides without belonging to either. The Cape Flats story within the District Six museum is told from these peoples' perspective and shouldn't be missed. Not well-advertised, it sits adjacent to the Police HQ building in District Six -- any cabbie should know how to get there.
Worth a stop. No need to spend a lot of time here, but it does give you an insight into the worst of apartheid. Take a trip to Robben Island or Soweto to get a more complete picture.
Thought provoking. Excellent visit with a well informed guide. It certainly made me think about some of the things that went on.
important, but lacks structure.. covers the relocation of district six, but lacks a little structure, good to spend max an hour. I stumbled across a tour to the townships here and joined.

A wonderful tribute to the immigrants. This is a fantastic place. Stories of people displaced by the government in District 6 are presented through a variety of media: from hangings and personal effects to books and posters. A human face is put to the people and issues encountered during heart-breaking and repressive times. Resilience is highlighted through the artifacts. Soundscapes, marbles, jigsaw puzzles, poem fragments and photos are very effective means that portray a terrible time. I was encouraged to visit the Jewish Museum to encounter another diverse perspective on the topic.

MUST VISIT TO KNOW WHAT PEOPLE LIVED THROUGH. This is a great museum where you can learn about the life of South Africans during apartheid. You will learn how it happened, what was happening during those years, how people reacted to it and what's happening to solve the problem.
What a history.. Try not to go at the end of the day. There is a lot to read and absorb and I probably didn't give it the full attention I should have.

Average presentation.. Tells the Story good. Not all exhibits interesting.
Plenty time required; min 2 hours. Many Long texts

Interesting history. This small museum tells the story of District 6 in Cape Town. The set up is nice and easy to follow, it is pretty cheap to get in and you get a real history lesson. They could use A/C though on hot days. I was sweating seriously in there. Makes contemplation pretty difficult.

An commemoration of the struggle against Apartheid. A moving, educational museum, an excellent complement to a tour of Robben Island.
One of the residents of district, Noor Ebrahim, may be on hand to autograph a copy of his book.

Eye-opening. This is an excellent venue to learn about the impact of Apartheid on the African people. Allow at least 2 hours. We only had one hour there as part of our organized tour and I would have liked to spend more time reading information and studying the exhibits.

Best CT museum. This place has the saddest and some of the most beautiful South African stories, at the same time. Very organized and a lot to see... they also have a nice little book store and a lovely cafe.

Disappointing Museum. We had saved this almost for the last thing we did in Capetown and had been very much looking forward to it. We found the displays to be hard to follow, repetitive and not particularly well set up. We had earlier visited a special exhibit at the Capetown Jewish Museum which included a history of jewish life in District Six which we found much more informative and interesting in terms of how it was laid out and the multitude of ways in which the material was presented.

Interesting and informative. We found the museum very interesting and good value. We would have liked a little more information up front on the specific issue being addressed as it was only after having spent quite a bit of time in there that we really picked up the threads of the story. But it really challenged our view of the issues and how close they were to current day issues faced by the South African population.

There are two sides to every story. This little collection of artefacts and memories serve to remind people, indeed shock people, into realising how a powerful ruling party can dismiss humanitarian reality at will. 6 was a real community, real houses, businesses, streets and families. Gang mentality existed but the demolition of all of this does seem extreme, although not unique, look at Zimbabwe?It is an worthwhile place to visit but there are many around who will bend your ear forever on the District 6 . Yes, it was unjust but we need to move on.

memorable. Visited this museum and it brought back all the memories of the apartheid years ,the bench with the label "whites only " is laughable now but was a criminal offence to sit on 20 years ago .

In Memory of the Expelled Non-White Persons. Private intiative made this museum possible and show a part a southafrican aparheid history that still is present in the minds and souls of the banished people that lived and worked here. Great material and books available in the museum book shop

Big Disappointment. I belief what makes or breaks your experience from this museum is ones ability to actually be able to have a guided tour of the museum. I have read several reviews on here of people who have glowing reviews of this museum and the common thread is that most of them were able to get a guided tour. My husband and I were unfortunately not able to get a guided tour because the tour guide had left for the day. We found that extremely odd, considering we had arrived at 10:30 a.m. In any event, we were left to our own devices in the museum. There are several rooms, chronological historical boards with lots of information of the history and the social, economic and demographic experience of District Six. But I just found that I was in a department store of information. My husband and I were somewhat 'overwhelmed' with the information and not having the advantage of a tour guide, we just found that is was a 'mish mash' of information and couldn't fully appreciate the museum, the way we feel we would have, had we were able to get a guided tour.We left after about an hour from our arrival. Maybe we didn't give it enough of a chance, but I seriously felt like it was a 'hodge podge' of information and very overwhelming.
Small but interesting. Essential to understand the past and present situation in Cape Town. Take the time to visit this small but well put-together museum.

Makes you very humble. Visited museum following a guided tour of the District Six area, brings the diabolical actions to life, what were the idiots in charge back then thinking of- great work by the local teams to bring life to the museum
Real history. Take a seat on the whites-only bench, and you'll immediately get a feel of what it was like in South Africa before the change

Impressive. We visited the Museum and had a little tour from somebody who actually experienced what District 6 went through. The museum is small, but therefore you can absorb it all and it is very admissible to read and look at. We also bought one of the story books on offer that tells the tale of District 6, written by our tour guide, very good read. It definitely made an impression!

A Disappointment. I was really looking forward to seeing this museum and I'm sad to say that I was disappointed. It didn't give a clear picture of what happened with district 6. If we hadn't been to the Jewish Museum just before this museum I don't think I would've had that good of an understanding. It seems like an under funded museum that considering it's place in history should have a better representation.

Sad story of Apartheid been told. This museum gives a very good impression of Apartheids crueltyA more than hundred year old florishing cosmoplitan district was brutally destroyed by the bulldozers of the regime.A big map of the quarter serves as floor of the museum ,which is filled with prooves and pictures of former inhabitants. Please take a tour with the guide, cause he is the man to tell the storie in depth!

Very impressive! A must see to understabd the city and surrounding. Very impressive and creatively setup. Gives good impressions from different perspectives. Not so big so easily to do for a short visit. Always possible to intensify by reading all the individual stories. Most imprecive story is about the doves...
A must see for history fans. I've been there 3 times, and it stays an eye opener for those of us that weren't born yet in those times. Interesting, sad, thought provoking ...

Thought Provoking. Taken to this museum by a man whose family were cleared from district 6. Horrified that I was an adult in UK when this was happening and not really aware fully of what was going on. Understood a little of what apartheid was about but not the depth that district 6 clearances show. Ir was a sobering thought and uncomfortable to think that such injustice could be inflicted on families as a Government Policy.

A must to get the feel of the place.. Informative both visually and by a video show in the back. I would have liked to have seen more from people who were in mixed marriages / relationships as cannot recall seeing white /black/mixed heritage couples details. Also consider making a room available where the video can be played as sadly distracting when you have young children being taught in the hall.Recommended

Well worth the visit when in Cape Town. The musuem shows the history of an area of Cape Town that is now long gone.District Six is a rather unexciting name for an area where a great diversity of people lived, mainly immigrants that could not afford any better.However, everyone seemed to have got on well with each other as shown in many photographs taken of the people and houses during the years prior to the relocation of the inhabitants and the entire area being destroyed by the authorities of the day.There's a large map on the floor in the main hall and the names of the people who lived at each property written in by hand.There are two floors of exhibits and photos. The musuem is well designed and easily located close to the city centre just around the corner of the town hall.

A reminder of apartheid and South African history. District 6 in Cape Town was once a bustling inner city area of about 60,000 near the city docks, that housed blacks, some mixed race people, Asians and early on, a large Jewish population. However, because of the national law of apartheid, the area was designated for whiles only in 1966, so removal of everyone living there began in 1968. Eventually, almost every house in the district was bulldozed and cleared out. Many of the churches were spared as well as a few homes. After apartheid there has been some construction, but basically, right now, it is a ghost town--a large empty area that is a reminder of apartheid. There are roads through it and some people live there. We went as part of a cultural tour of Cape Town, that included Langha and some shantytowns. It is a significant part of South African history. There is also a District 6 museum in Cape Town and the SA Jewish Museum has a current exhibit on the Jews in Dictrict 6--those who lived there in the first half of the 20th centrury.

Small but very interesting. This gives a very good insight into past times that should never have happened. At the shop there you can buy a book about District 6 called Noor's story and Noor runs it and will sign the book for you.

informative. This was a small museum, but full of fascinating information about a very terrible situation in Cape Town when people were removed from their neighborhoods because of color. Well worth the visit!
Informative SA. The museum is on the hop-on and hop-off bus route. It is a colourful, creative and interactive look at the sad history of a community wiped out by apartheid. Recommended.

Good but could be better. The video, whilst informative was all over the place, and repeated itself frequently. In addition the video was in the classroom with kids having a class which made it hard to hear. It was however a good experience and would still recommend it
Great stop to learn about Apartheid. So many interesting documents and history in the museum from original street signs and storefronts to personal documents - a must see.

A great reflection. I drive through District 6 every day and I'd love for it to remain unchanged. It gives a beautiful view of the city with only religious buildings popping through on the D6 skyline. To change it will to lose this reflection.

Moving and personal insights into a bleak time in SA history. This place is a MUST DO in Cape Town. Being a child of the 70's I grew up understanding about the awful racial segregation in SA. District Six made you understand what it was like for the communities that were destroyed in the name of "urban planning". Prepare to be moved, learn lots and walk away with a deep of understanding of apartheid and the long term damage that it has done to this beautiful country. The museum is full up with personal insights and stories. It also has rooms that recreate some of the living conditions. I feel in love with the display of the street signs. GO GO GO to district six. YOu will love it.

A sobering view of the recent past. This is mostly a photo display of the surrounding neighborhood that used to be a vibrant place full of musicians, blacks, coloureds, restaurants, etc. Apartheid moved almost all of it out to the Cape flats andit is just now that people are starting to come back. Ate lunch at a very old, Portugese, restaurant, Dias nearby.
District Six Museum. The museum depicts the history of the people of District Six so well that I cried for days afterwards thinking of the displaced people of the District.

Overrated. The story of District Six is a good one- it just needs a better publisher. This museum seems to be all about remembering the good ol' times and forgetting that white people still live there happily and shouldn't be randomly kicked out.

Fascinating insight. The museum offers a insight into the lives of those that lived in District six a multicultural area that was re-designated as a white only area in 1963. The staff who work at the museum all lived in District six and are happy to share their stories, we were lucky to meet Tahir who really brought to life what it was like to live in District six. This musem is an important place to visit to understand recent South Africa history.
A Heart wrenching experience. This will definitely take you back in time when apartheid was rife in SA. It makes us appreciate how far we have come as a country. A must see.

Small but still educational. Not really much more to say about it, other then its a must do if you want to learn more about the "forced removals" from their communities imposed on the colored people of South Africa. This museum focuses on the communities (specifically district 6) where people lived before they were forced out.

Great idea, but randomly presented. This is a fabulously and essential educative venue to visit, but the displays and interior are randomly presented leaving visitors confused as to whether residents were actually happy or sad. [In truth, they were both but not at the same time!]There is much to be learnt from this museum, but there appears to be limited sequence to the narrative, with exhibits obscurely mounted.The Museum could take a leaf out of the ordered book of Nelson Mandela House or Soweto's museums.

Perfectly executed. If there was one place to see it would be this place. I love the map on the floor and the complete explanation. What a tradegy the people had to live through, but fortunately you brought this alive for me.

Great information...needs a little updating. Thought the information contained in District Six Museum was extremely interesting and informative. However, you really had to search to find the interesting nuggets of information. It needs to be brought into the 21st Century with more visual aids - video, etc. that can capture the visitor's attention. The only video was nice, but they only had 6 free standing seats to sit in. This could easily be improved at little cost.
Very educational for the kids. Something different to do and very interesting. Planetarium was just as good. Make sure you have enough time to stroll around the museum.

A lot to take in, harrowing overview of a horrific event. Information everywhere and presented as individual stories, timelines, and photographs. There is a lot to read so devote some time to visiting. It is ashame that there aren't first hand accounts recorded in audio format to listen to. We were fortunate to catch the DVD of a first hand account and outline of events; however, without this there is a lot to take on board.

It will be with you for long. An impressive history rich museum. Tiny in size but grand as experience.Take your time, read and learn.Very touching. Leaves a lot to the imagination.And help foreigners understand the city's recent past.

Gives a good appreciation of the nightmare of Apartheid. Interesting museum, but coming from USA we didn't have much background or perspective on what it represented. We had to kind of piece it together to realized that this was a downtrodden part of town (since torn down) where persons of black or mixed races were forced to live without any opportunity for improving their lives. Once we figured that out it made more sense. Suggestion to Museum management: make a display right at the beginning and on the website that makes this very clear. Don't miss this when you visit Cape Town! It's just about 30 meters from the Hop On Hop Off Bus stop #9.
Great place to see the history. Great place to see the history of the apartheid and forced relocation that happened in Cape Town. It explained how the township gangs came to existence.

It will change you. I was unprepared for the emotional impact of this museum--part sacred shrine, part educational treasure. Take the time to read every caption, and to speak with the volunteer tour guides, many of whom are former residents of District 6. Most moving is the way so many citizens actively participate in preserving and honoring the story of this lost community, for example the way prison inmates assist with hand-embroidering comments written in marker on cloth panels. You will come away a changed person if you allow yourself to experience this place fully.

Not worth the time. We were told this was a must see but we were really disappointed. It's badly laid out and doesn't really have a theme - it seemed to be just a collection of newspaper cuttings stuck up on posters and the odd bit of furniture from the 1960's. Definitely worth a miss.
Don't miss District Six. Informative, emotive and tells the real story of the people. It isn't huge so it won't take hours, but do spare a good couple to see it all. Don't miss.

Informative History Lesson. The museum was informative & ultimately heart warming. If you are interested in the chronological timeline up front, start the museum from the left after paying. We started to the right & it seemed to jump around in time. We found the timeline at the end of our visit & wished we had started there. Other than not knowing which way to start, it was a very well laid out experience.
Thought Inspiring. A must see attraction for visitors wishing to understand some of the countries turbulent past and history. Not a very large museum but brought to life my former district residents.

Kind of disappointed. To be fair, my understanding of District Six was limited before I went to the museum (which is one of the reasons why I went), but in all honesty, I felt like it just wasn't very well laid out. I didn't really get a feel for the what actually happened, but perhaps I needed to do more research about District 6 before I went the museum.I'd recommend it, but I definitely wouldn't say this was a 5-star experience. And the fee is definitely not exorbitant.
Sobering and interesting. All very interesting - filled with items and memories - well worth a visit. Makes you ashamed to think what happened here all because of the colour of your skin

Touching. The museum is not that big in the end, but has significant amount of information and personal experiences, stories and pictures within. Definitely worth going, if you are at least a bit interested in the history of cape town, the settlements and politics - and who would not be?

A well executed, rather sad reminder of SA's past. The District Six Museum tells the story of how a vibrant coloured community in a part of the Bo-Kaap designated 'District Six' was relocated and the old neighbourhood flattened because it did not fit in with Apartheid's area profile. Now that might not have been so sad, if it was not that District Six ws rich with culture and history and community spirit, so much so that even now, that spirit has not died. Visit the District Six Museum. You need several hours to do it justice, although it is quite small. It will change your perpective and enrich you. Well done, and so rewarding.

Important museum. We are so glad we went to this museum. It helped to attach faces and images to the stories we'd heard. We did NOT find the information here, though, to be easily accessible--the walls are covered with newspaper articles, long quotes and nothing (that I recall) auditory. If we'd been on a tour it would've helped, I"m sure, but we couldn't match the tour times to our schedule. There are folks who work there who can answer questions (having lived there) but we didn't really have questions, we just wanted to learn more. Most interesting to me was the section on jobs and the 7 steps. And the museum is definitely a way for Dictrict 6 folks to tell their stories--so important to the healing process.
Family Visit to Museuam. Well maintained museum, which really creates the scene during the time. Advisable to all South Africans to visit this museum for a better understanding of our own history.

Must See in Cape Town!. Our group visited the District Six Museum as part of the "Walk to Freedom Tour" we took. Our tour guide gave us an explanation of the events that occurred in District Six prior to arriving at the museum. The museum itself really helped put names and faces to the events, which really brought it home for me. Many of the people that work at the museum were former District Six residents, so they were able to share their personal stories. It was a truly moving experience. I highly recommend visiting this museum, especially if you still don't understand how apartheid impacted this country.

Nice Presnetation. This museum gave an excellent overview of the past history of this neighborhood with the forced removal of thousands of people but also spoke about the recent efforts of revitalization. In a City that unlike Johannesburg does not have a lot of remnants of Apartheid history this is a must see on your visit to Cape Town.

Informative and Moving. I learned so much about the apartheid - separateness - enforcement and its impact on families and whole neighborhoods. Be sure to stop along the stairway to read about the homing pigeons that kept trying to return to their home that no longer existed.

Small Museum. Good for a visit at the end of a Township tour or just a mid day visit. Gives an idea of what District Six looked like. And a couple of people who hang out at the museum used to live there and will talk to you if you want to ask them any questions.

Moving story telling in a compact space. Really liked this intimate museum. A bit tricky to find but well worth it. Ex residents guide you through the harrowing and somewhat senseless tale in heart felt fashion and lots of reclaimed exhibits together with evocative photographs and set piece installations combine to make for a really diverting couple of hours.

recommended visit in understanding the changes in South Africa. I am not sure whether the Apartheid Museum in Johannesburg is the same. However, Distric Six Museum is a recommended visit to understand the history of cape Town.
Very interesting. Very interesting and thought provoking. We didn't get a guided tour which in retrospect would have been better as they are done by people who lived the district.

Creatively curated. This small museum is jam-packed with information. Absorbing it all is made easier by the interesting and varied ways in which it is presented. Highly educational AND enjoyable. Not recommended for children who can't read.

This museum brings personal perpectives to the effects of apartheid. District Six ex-residents have brought their memories and mementos to this one building. The personal stories, poems and artworks tell of a time which we witnessed from thousands of miles away. Very moving.

A Story to Tell. The story is told by the people who lived in District Six. It's heart warming and shocking hearing their own personal accounts of how they coped with the circumstances of the time, families pulling together to help each other survive. Very educational.
Great insight into the lives of d6. A small cosy little museum giving insight into district six ,also most curators lived in district six thus the tours are really informative.
It is a very important place to visit!. This is a very important place to visit (to understand the recent history of South Africa). I'll never forget my visit.
District 6 Museum. This was a watershed moment in the history of South Africa; however, most of what is displayed in the museum can be gained from reading literature on the subject.

Not worth it. The District Six Museum where meant to tell the history behind the forced movement of black people from this neighbourhood. But the museum lets you down on this story. It was more a display of photos of everyday life in the 1950's rather than a story of the forced movement.

Interesting stop. We took the red Line bus than has an stop in this museum
The history of South Africa is sad and some how complicated this museums help me understand in a better way part of its history and what actual people lived during the apartheid
Very interesting and educational
worth more than an hour. Informative and affecting presentation of photos and texts. A small space but a lot to see and think about.

An awesome if heartbreaking view of Cape Town and Apartheid. I lived through most of what the museum lists but, nonetheless, i learned a lot in just 1 hour. The man that seems to run the museum was a wealth of knowledge, having lived in District Six through the forced removals. Unlike Robben Island, this does not feel like a "manufactured" experience for tourists. I highly recomend this for every Capetonian and those tourists that are interested in the history of the city as well as the gorgeous sights

Small but packs a powerful punch. This small museum brings together a variety of medium to tell the story of District Six. We found ourselves reflecting on the events - and where we were at the time and what was in the news at the time. The tragic story of a community ripped apart comes to life here but in a way that conveys the vitality of District Six as much as the tragedy. The large map on the floor - with the notes added about people who lived there made it so real. The photos and signs - the rooms upstairs with words and objects embedded in the walls (If only the walls could talk.) made this museum visit a very memorable event.
Excellent and worth a visit. Very well put together, excellent and worth a visit. In the city, close to the City Hall, Grand Parade and The Castle!
an eye opener. This is a great place to understand what it must have been like during apartheid. Unbelievable that this tragedy occurred in 1984. This museum left a major impression on me.

A More Complete Picture of Cape Town. This museum provides a look at the darker sides of South AFrica's history, an important part of the country's narrative. It is also very active in helping the community move on, expanding it's narrative and vision for its future. Be sure to take a tour, which are often led by former residents of District 6, to hear personal stories. It's quite an impressive place/movement/community that you won't want to miss.

A Moving Personal Account. All the guides at the District 6 Museum are ex-residents of the area and give their own personal accounts of what happened to them and their families against a backdrop of photographs, signs, and other memorabilia lovingly placed around the museum.

This doesn't pull any punches. Excellent. You can get round fairly quckly in an hour and a half, or easily spend more time here. It is not huge - in an old church - but packed with history about District 6 and apartheid. I think it is a must if you are interested in apartheid and townships
Bit of a hotch pot. The subject matter of the Museum is very important and moving and the galleries that deal with it are good, but the other stuff seems a bit of an after thought.
A Must Do. Was a great educational experience. Learned so much about the impact of apartheid in this 6th municipal district of Capetown. It has a rich history,
Thought provoking. I came out of this museum with real food for thought. Opened my eyes to what others have had to go through in their lives. A must on any visit to Cape Town.
Brings current history to life. Unusual to have a 'museum' dedicated mostly to events that happened within the last 50 years - but an important part of the culture of the city.

A worthwhile stop. It was a little tricky to find the entrance but it was well worth the stop. You can do it in just 30 minutes but I recommend a good hour - lots to read and digest. The staff was also extremely helpful and friendly - answering any and all questions.
Gives you the story. Simply explains the story of what occurred. A no frills museum. Convenient to Charly's bakery for some great cakes and coffee.
Disappointing, actually.. We were really excited to visit the museum but I really learned more about the way things were in Saint George's Cathederal.

Very Moving. Interesting Museum, with lots of great photos. Did not know much about District Six before , but I do now. The area must have been very vibrant before it was flattened. While there we were invited to a fund-raising evening later on, which we attended and there were some great characters there in the former residents

needs to be more interactive. i found there was far too much writing and it was very haphazard, there was no real obvious flow to where to start reading. but also had some very interesting bits of information
So much to absorb. You could spend hours looking at photos and reading resident stories. I found it to be so fascinating.

Highly recommend if you can only see 1 museum.. This was the only museum I was able to visit in Cape Town and am glad I went to learn the rich history of District Six. It is true that it's a small museum but is packed with information. I would say it takes about an hour and a half to get a good feeling, more if you want to read and look at everything. I'm glad I made the time to stop by and have recommended to other travelers to do the same.

Small & underwhelming. For all the history district six has this Museum doesn't seem to do it justice. When you first enter there are 4 or 5 spinning boards which tell the story of District Six and are probably the most informative items on display. Everything else seems hokey and doesn't really do enough to illustrate the suffering the people of district six had to endure. I left feeling like we lined more from one of tour drivers me felt as though this could've easily been skipped.

A must if you visit Cape Town. The natural beauty of Cape Town is hypnotic but it would be a shame to leave without visiting some of its museums. This museum delivers a powerful punch -- the exhibits are set up to show first hand accounts from those who lived through it.

Interesting. The cost of entry to this museum was very reasonable but it was disappointing that they had run out of the information leaflets when we were there. It was very interesting to see and read all of the information there and some of the things that happened were shocking. We felt though that it wasn't a first rate museum and could have been expanded and developed a little more.

Very real and "fresh" history of urban "planning" gone terribly wrong.. The former President of S Africa called the District 6 removal, relocation, and razing the most graphic example of the horrors of Apartheid. This museum is staffed and used by many who were victims of this awful event. It is in an old Methodist Church that was not leveled like the homes of all the parishioners. The photos show a multiracial, vibrant but not rich community before it became a rubble field covering hundreds of blocks. Definitely a required visit if you want to understand South Africa today.

District Six Museum. It helped having a guide from the local community, who in his youth had actually lived in District Six. it was a very moving and emotional experience to listen to his account of life in the area and to meet Noor Ebrahim who has recorded his history of the District, and his involvement in it, in the book Noor's Story.

Very interesting!. well done and very informative. You really feel like you have transferred in District six. The photographs, old items, road signs and even a whole room re-makes add to this great collection. Do not miss the little room on the second floor where every day items have been covered with plaster as if time hasn't passed by for a moment.

Small but effective. Fascinating museum and one well worth visiting. It's not very big but has a wealth of information about District Six - I knew very little about it and came out of the Museum far better informed.
Very Interesting and Educational. We learned so much about the government's attempts to separate the blacks from the whites, it is a sad story but one we can all learn from. Highly recommend!

sandie h. Very interesting. Gave information on how people were divided up and moved out of the area during apartheid. Wasn't melodramatic just gave the facts without animosity.I am not a museum person but I wasn;t bored because it wasn't too big

important history. This museum shows the destruction of a vibrant mixed colored community in Cape Town. It is amazing that they have any artifacts at all, considering that the whole area was bulldozed, and in fact remains undeveloped.

Very Interesting Way to Spend an Hour. It is a well constructed and very interesting museum based around the personal experiences of those remove from District Six. Many museums in SA focus on simply 'facts', as where this place is much more about 'how it felt' for those removed from the area. Not as large or as in depth as I'd hoped, but gives a very interesting overview of the history of the area.

Impactful. Small, but visually interesing and sad commentary on one of South Africa's worst moments. There are numerous photographs, a floor map, and a sample room of a typical District 6 house before being torn down and displaced.
A living memory. Liked all the first hand reports of life in district 6 and that work is still going on in the area from the museum

Ok but could be more focused. Some interesting exhibits and photos, but not enough focus on actual stories from individuals and a bit disjointed - seemed to be more about what the museums' aims were, rather than acutal facts and historical information

Educational and moving. Small museum but take your time going through to read the wealth of information about what went on in DistrictSix. The entire community was destroyed by Apartheid policies between 1960 and1975. Labeled a slum it was really a vibrant multiple-cultural community. It's an easy walk from the Green Market area and marked on city maps. We went the day after a visit to Robben island and the two complement each other.

A small but educating place about the history of cape town. A small but educating place about the history of cape town. You won't need much more than 20 minutes but you should go there and give those 20 minutes to look back into the past of cape town.

Museum a powerful reminder. I went to the District Six Museum as part of a township tour, and it was a very moving experience - it puts Cape Town and the history of South Africa into personal terms, and provides a great perspective.

An important cultural visit. The District Six museum was an unplanned visit - if you are a Cape Townian, entrance is often free if you're polite enough to ask. The experience is very personal and beautiful detailed, and is a very worthwhile visit.

see in silence and hear the sound of change. if you know nothing or something of Bloemendal, or the sixth district of Cape Town, visit here. You will get a good idea of what good can happen, what should not happen and when good cannnot happen.

excellent way to understand the apartheid and the history of South Africa. excellent way to understand the apartheid and the history of South AfricaVery creatively way of presenting stories and engage Leave 2-3 hours to explore
An education. For some reason we thought District 6 was a shanty town and were surprised to find that it was proper built neighbourhood that was bull dozed. Very sad times indeed.

What everyone who visits or lives in Capetown should know. This museum needs more attention! It contains such important information - some of it still raw and ongoing - yet the museum is hard for a visitor to find, and some of the exhibits are hard to read. Is more space needed? Why put text down at knee level when most of us cannot crouch or sit down to read it? Also: please add some information about what has happened since the year 2000 about the land in district six. I had to ask and was given a good update, but I'm sure others would also like to know the status of the land claims and what the families have elected to do. All that said, I learned so much by spending a few hours in the museum. Thank you.
An important part of Cape History.. A reminder to all of the serious mistakes of apartheid. Visit to see one devastating example of injustice.

Necessary knowledge.. This museum is an important part of the history of Cape Town. The museum is a collection of stories and clippings about an area repeatedly ravaged by racist policies and subsequent displaced persons. One of such persons was working at the museum the day that we went. Talking with him alone was definitely worth the trip.

Very informative. Nicely done.. District Six, an area once proclaimed to be a "white" group area, resulting in more than 60,000 people giving up their homes and move to townships. This museum therefore tells many stories behind this. A good illustration and very informative. If you have red/blue line ticket, you can also get a small discount for entry fee.

Interesting insight into Cape Town History. The museum itself is not so great but it tells a fascinating history of the District Six suburb which was home to white, black and coloured, Jew, Muslim and Christian, happily living in a vibrant suburb which was declared whites only in the 1966 Group Area Act and demolished

Good Information, Walls of Text. The subject of this museum is important and interesting, but it is hard to get information out of the walls of text that make up the museum. The most interesting parts are the newspapers from the past.

Undeveloped. This area is fairly barren and although it represents a clouded history, has little to attract the tourist yet. The surrounds are still industrial in appearance so there is little to attract. A drive through is adequate.

Wonderful place, jumbled narrative. Such an important place and was looking forward to learning all about the difficult past of Cape Town. Unfortunately the narrative of the museum seemed very jumbled, and difficult to pick up. Wonderful photos from District 6 and exhibits upstairs. I would recommend going on a guided tour.

A sad slice of Cape Town History. Take your children. Learn about a horrible part of S.A and Cape town history. To prevent events from repeating themselves, we need to learn from our collective human history. This place will bring you to tears.

Essential. Must see.. If you visit Cape Town you can't leave without visiting this museum (and the Slave Lodge & Bo Kaap area & museum). This excellent museum gives you a true insight into the people's history and experience of apartheid. The museum is great for kids & teens & adults alike. There are some wonderful exhibits that really allow you to get a real grasp of South African history. District Six was a mixed heritage area that was completely devastated during apartheid - basically 'disappeared'. The museum, amongst other things, curates the memory of the people who lived there, their community and what their lives & experiences were like.

Very nice. Sadly, I had a difficult time finding this place. It surprised me that so few people in the area seemed to know where it was! It is an important museum but apparently doesn't have enough sponsorship to be managed properly. For one thing, they do not have a museum book describing the history of Apartheid in an encapsulated form with pictures of the museum interior. This they must develop. They do have many memoirs but one can get lost in them. Still, it is an important museum and I think it ought to be promoted better.

A sad history. Well worth visiting to see the effect of Apartheid right next to you.Reasonably well laid out but I felt it lacked a cohesiveness to pull the whole story together. More information on the expropriation and years that it sat as this empty quarter, a constant reminder to Cape Town to what happened to its soul.

Tells an important story. Other reviews explain what this museum is about. We found it very moving, particularly talking to a former resident about his experiences. We were struck by how the shift from a mixed-race neighborhood close to jobs was destroyed in his lifetime. This really brought the history of South Africa to life. We were impressed by the ghost house, a full size "model" of a typical house from the neighborhood with holograms of what would have been there originally. Also striking were the photographs near the entrance of the neighborhood at different periods.
Touching. Really interesting and touching. You can get a feelling of the "hard times" and see many interesting stuff. Also, it is really well placed in the centre of town.
Colourful. Excellent views of Cape town and lovely photograph opportunities. The lovely colourful houses are a watercolour artist's dream.

A well-constructed memorial to a sad chapter of Apartheid history. The District Six Museum was quite interesting - it tells the stories of locals who were pushed out of Cape Town and into the Flats Townships when their district was demolished by the Apartheid regime. Sadly, much of that district is still open fields. Hopefully it will be rebuilt one day and a new diverse community can form there!

A homage to old Cape Town's mixed community.. I had an interesting chat to a one-time resident and author of a book on his experiences in this once vibrant and colourful community unfairly displaced by an uncaring Government.

Important and disturbing saga of Cape Town history. My husband and I walked around Cape Town for an entire day during our recent visit to this beautiful city and came upon this very interesting museum. It chronicles the disturbing story of the generally harmonious and racially diverse area of Cape Town called Section Six. Because of the past government's policy of Apartheid the people who lived there were forced to relocate and the area was razed and demolished. The museum operates on an obviously shoe string budget and is very modest. However it effectively reveals an important and deeply shameful story of this dark time in South Africa's history.
Emotive. We took in the museum as part of a Township tour. We had four teenagers in tow and they, as well as us adults, found the place highly informative and very emotional. Recommended.

Don't miss this, for its story. Although it could be done better, there is a powerful story here of the racially mixed and harmonious District 6 that was declared illegal for that reason by the Apartheid government. Everyone was kicked out, and it was flattened. One of the very sad stories of a shameful history.

Worth a visit. We were very glad we spent time at the District Six Museum. It chronicles the effects of apartheid on the city of Cape Town. The collection is modest and understated as is the entire space -- and it is also very effective in capturing and recounting the history. As much as we enjoyed our time and learned a great deal, we felt that the museum could better explain the way in which its organized as one begins the tour. A small leaflet would be beneficial as well. Nonetheless, the museum is a valuable asset and our time there was very beneficial. It's evident that the museum is struggling financially, so we hope that there will continue to be sufficient support to tell this important story.

Must see. Knowing what happened to District Six during apartheid is heartbreaking, but this small museum ensures it is not forgotten. The museum's artifacts, photos, and text are hard to digest, but even if you don't read every panel, you come away with a better understanding of the irrational and destructive nature of the apartheid system.And we had a great meal at Dias, a Portuguese sports bar around the corner.

An informative display. We did the Museum on our own, not as part of a tour, so you can take as much time as you like. We spent about 1 to 1 1/2 hr and thought it a good presentation of what District 6 was like as a bustling alive neighborhood before the bulldozers came in and everyone was removed to the "flats". We had been to Robben Island and read some books about the struggles, so this was a nice visual presentation to bring it to life. Quotations from the many people who had been removed, and their descendants, was impressive.

Poignant and personal. If you are at all interested in South Africa’s history I would say this should be a must see. The museum is set in a church and recounts the lives of the former residents of District Six and the events surrounding their forced displacements out to the townships. The many photos and personal histories are a poignant account of South Africa’s still recent past, it shouldn’t be missed.

Apartheid at ground level. This museum gives a very personalized view of what Apartheid meant for specific families and individuals, how it shaped their history, and what this means in terms of policy for the rest of the country. Probably the best museum in the Cape Town area. Lots of exhibits about what life in District 6 was like before being re-zoned, as well as thoughtful, balanced accounts of the neighborhood's history from founding through the present.

mildly interesting. I was somehow expecting a bit better from this museum. It is small and somewhat cramped museum of two levels with many tourists walking through. As others have said there was not a lot of direction, rather a jumble of images and artifacts on a community uprooted during apartheid. There are tours however we chose to go through on our own. Without condoning the old system in South Africa were were hoping to at least find one 'positive' story regarding the thousands who were forcibly evicted.If you only have a few days in Cape Town there are many more interesting things to do but for those with extra time it is an easy addition.

A genuine museum. The blue City Sightseeing bus passes by District Six, where the open space remains after the forced removal of an entire community. The District Six Museum provides a huge amount of information about District Six before the removal and the process itself. What I found particularly wonderful was the hand written testimonials and notes from those who were involved in District 6. A fascinating Museum and a genuine account of a section of Cape Town's history. Excellent.

Maybe it's just me. Everyone told me this was a must see. I have a knee-jerk negative reaction to the idea of "narrative," being over-steeped in it here in New York. The museum is interesting in that it "documents" a potent period of Cape Town and South African history, but it is not especially well-curated, and there is no "narrative flow" to the layout of the exhibits. That said, this is a place that you "must see" because it is important to say you saw it.

Diverse Cape Town. This is a must see if coming to Cape Town, especially for those interested in the history of the Cape. Tells the story of a vibrant neighbourhood destroyed by apartheid. Intimate yet incredibly informative.
Great. This museum really highlighted just how sad it must have been back in the day. I think it captures the moments and the memories from the day as well as educating people.
Fascinating. It was quite a good insight to the discrimination and injustice suffered by the blacks and other ethnic groups.

Great Inisights. One of my favourite experiences in Cape Town. A must visit while in town. Really brings the history to light and helps to answer some questions about the vast inequality based on racial lines that one continues to see in Cape Town today.

Loved it!. This was great and personal for me. What a wasted period 1949 -1996 , you can really see the mistakes being made in certain Mid East nations and other places that discriminate on a racial basis. South Africa is so much fun it is easy to be glib about the past. I think this was worth the effort. I would like to know more about where the people are now how their lives worked out.

Great Flavor of the Worst of Apartied. Imagine demolishing a working successful multi-ethnic community in a futile attempt to prove the merits of racism. See the thistor of this traced at this moving museum.
moving. provides a great insight into the recent history in South Africa. A great way to spend an afternoon.

Worth a visit. This is not the world's greatest museum, but it has a unique feel about it, as it is a former church and was at a time right in the middle of things. If you want a real feel for the injustices that the people of the Cape endured simply by virtue of the colour of their skin, you need to read the testimony and look at the photos that are on the walls for you to see. It's a little school-like in the way it's done, but you get a feeling that real people recorded their experience for others to learn from. My teenage boys quietly spent an hour with me there- not a word until we left and then dozens of questions, just as a museum visit should be. And if it's a wet day, as it was for me, no better way of passing some time in the middle of the town. Another reviewer said a book would have done the same job; I disagree. I will be surprised though, if this museum does not make you want to read more about the subject.

Strikingly effective museum. This museum packs a punch in a small space and short visit. Effective storytelling, memorable visuals, remarkable history captured with insight, economy and care. Highly recommended

Interesting subject but poor museum. The museum intends to describe the evacuation of District Six from its black residents. The story is very interesting but the museum doesn't gives you the real experience of this piece of history. It is configured in two floors with many pictures and a lot of reading near the pictures. There is nothing interactive or just a movie, or reconstruction or anything else in the sense of leaving you with the experience of what really happened. You just read - something I could do at home.

Very interesting local history museum. Although a small museum, the District Six Museum provides great insight into the rich history of the area and gives context to the multi-faceted issues surrounding apartheid and its aftermath in Cape Town.

A good concept but a reading overload. I really wanted to like this museum and some of the displays were interesting, but overall we found ourselves really giant poster after giant poster of information. I kind of felt like a District Six book would have been the same thing because there wasn't a lot of susbstance to the museum otherwise. Oh well...
Cultural Richness. Very well done. History that many of us did not know. Balanced the tragedy of the act of removal with the cultural richness of the community. Museum employees were wonderful.

Wish I had more time. A lot of information to be founded there. Definitely worth to take 1 hour to visit it. Very touristic place, so a litte bit busy. Panels and pictures are quite small, and there are a lot of details, so it is worth to take your time to visit
Interesting history. There happend alot. and it is what made the country what it is today. a visit to the museum is recomendable, althou not my personal pastime

A Piece of Real History. The hidden truth about the old South Africa. Our guides never mentioned the destruction of this part of town though it's visible from every part of the city.
Don't miss this.

Nice museum but poor layout. This was one of our first tops in Cape Town and we didn't have much prior knowledge of District Six so we found the museum a little overwhelming and hard to follow.
They need a better overview of the story.
a reminder of a wretched policy. although not a great museum, it was a great reminder of what apartheid did to the people of south africa...the reminder of the destruction of a mixed community...
Ok but too much reading. A good place to better understand Cape Town's history. Too much to read though. Need more senses to get involved in the story telling.
Very informative. The amount of information presented was a little overwhelming for such a small space. However, I got a very personal sense of the effect of the relocations on the community.
The story of a neighbourhood destroyed by Apartheid.. Fascinating history of a neighbourhood that was torn apart by Apartheid.
District six. Every site tells a story - every story a heartache with a prayer that someday somewhere people will all get back what they have lost
Sad endings. Visiting the museum leaves a person very vulnerable for what really happened and people being taken out of their residing areas - very sad story but should have a happy ending some time!

Fantastic museum!. Take the big red hop-on hop-off tour bus to get here, but watch the closing hours/days. If you don't have enough time to tour this fantastic museum, talk to the man who works in their gift shop just inside the entrance. He was an original resident of District Six (which is now just a big patch of grass), and he's filled with fascinating stories. Note that there are many public safety officers in the neighborhood who watch that bus stop, so you'll be OK waiting for the next bus.
A little Disappointing. I thought the museum was rather small and limited, considering all the history about oppression of blacks they had to draw from.

No Future if you don't understand your history. What a historic place to visit for all and more so for the kids of Cape Town that need to know what their parents had to endure through difficult times. The museum act as a " Canvas" with historical values, trials and tribulations BUT some good times that Distric Soix offred then.
Recent history of Cape Town and impact of terrible policies. We enjoyed this small museum and it portrayed the history on a personal level.

Very Informative. Gives you a great background on Apartheid and unbelievable the way in which entire areas of the city were cleared to enforce Apartheid's policies. Cape Town seems to have made great strides since then.

A moving and emotional experience. The display in the museum was frugal and could do with investment, but added to the authenticity of the story being told.Some staff that work there lived in District 6 , it was good to speak to them.I throughly enjoyed the quaint little cafe, which was welcoming and sold freshly made samosas and cakes for a quick snack.

insights. While this wasn't life shattering, it was a good education to see how things were during apartheid and how it came to be in the first place. I definitely had some misunderstandings cleared up.

Historical Persecptive. District Six is an iconic area in the history of the city especially regarding the Apartheid past. As long as you communicate well with the tour guide, you will "enjoy" this glance into a past that most South Africans are not proud of. Communication can be difficult as accents are not easy to follow, but ask if you do not understand something and you will be blown away!
Not to be missed.. Wonderful museum with an unique display of artifacts and background pictures of the original, very colourful and vibrant district leading up to and including the apartite era.

Don't miss this!. If you want to get a sense of how individuals were affected by apartheid, particularly by the forced removals from mixed neighborhoods, you MUST visit the District Six Museum. It's full of personal histories and tons of photos donated by the former residents of District Six.

A Suprise. The first time I visited Cape Town, the District 6 Museum was not on my radar.When I returned, a friend suggested that I visit.District 6 is a neighborhood of Cape Town. During the 1940's to 1960's it was a vibrant mixed race neighborhood. Somewhat scruffy, but lots of economic, social and cultural activity. Then the apartheid city counsel declared it a "white-only" neighborhood and dispossesed the Africans, Coloreds and mixed races to the Cape Town Flats slum.District 6 was razed and replaced by apartment blocks in what would be charitably described as neo-soviet architecture. I walked in and the museum is mostly a collection of photographs and newspaper articles. After all, the area was destroyed and there are not many artifacts left. Strolling around was sort of ho-hum and then the enormity of what happened to District 6 hit me like a ton of bricks and I just sat for maybe a 1/2 hour soaking it all in.

Must visit to start to understand the history. Not the best laid out as difficult to work through the story, more of a commemoration and community centre.Must visit to understand and pay respects, particularly before a township tour or trip to Robben Island.
Interesting. Interesting and quite movng. It is small but very effective. Real human stories are depicted all around including that of the cashier's parents.
just ok. nicely decorated and designed museum. The number of interesting objects is rather limited and are not always easy to see between the rest of the stuff.
a part of bad history. a witness of a bad administration but need to realize the reality

A must see when visiting South Africa. What impressed me most about this museum is the way in which the tragic memories of the past are presented along with visions for the future. The use of so many personal narratives ensures the facts and figures don't remain faceless, rather the stories are told with individual emotion and expression. It felt to me like a living museum, one that serves to educate outsiders but also serves as a meeting place for residents of District Six and others affected by forced removals under the apartheid regime.
A must see Museum. Sad to realise this actually happened in a modern country but it seems some bridges are being rebuilt.

museum tour. We visited the museum which helped us gain insight into the times of apartheid. The museum is a moving experience and is very well done. I would have liked to have spent more time at the museum. The displays were very informative.
Good to see. Important for travellers to gain insight into the reality of apartied and this museum does that - well worth it. Easy to get there on the on-off sightseeing buses.

Very moving experience. We visited the museum and did the tour - excellent talk given by Noor who was one of those whose family had been moved. Very moving experience and well laid out museum.
This is a must do in Cape Town especially if you know little about apartheid.

Good information but small. We stopped here at the beginning of our township tour. The museum was okay.. it had good information but it was small and something you could do in about twenty minutes. It's still worth a visit if you have the time.
Get a guide, and get more out of it. A touching moment, a documentation of cruelty only man can create.

A Museum depicting the Apartheid Era. Visitors will be welcomed by ex-residents of the famous District Six. Lots of photographs of the life-style and forced removal of residents from District Six by the Apartheid Regime in the late 60's. The site of the museum has been nominated as a National Heritage Site. It is open daily, but by appointment only on a Sunday.
.
informative. all tho not very big it was very interesting, it taught you all about the history of not only district 6 but south africa in general

Interesting and worth a visit. I liked the history details and the photographs.
The presentation of the information is bright, colourful and easy to read. This museum is also a place for old residents to come and meet up - so s great to learn from them
Part of Cape Town's History. Liked the displays and descriptions. Glad I took the time to learn about this part of Cape Town's history. Didn't like it closed on the weekend or holiday.

Nice staff, small though. It was very hot when we went and there wasn't AC, so it was a little hard to enjoy it. It was smaller than I thought, but very historical. The man who works at the gift shop has a book there, I bought it and he signed it for me....very sweet.
important history. like the inside of a scrapbook, I learned a lot. lots of personal photos and life stories

A must when visiting Cape Town. You cannot understand Cape Town's history (and South Africa) without District 6 as a reference point, and this museum tells its history with passion and careful attention. The destruction of a multicultural community by apartheid is a tragic story, and the area has yet to fully recover. The District 6 Museum is an effort at reconciliation and renewal for the city, and its narrative is well done here.

An eye-opener. Be prepared.... This is an absolute must for people who don't know much about South Africa's history... and don't plan a big day afterward, because if you are an emotional person, you'll need some time to sit with the experience and the information. Truly heart wrenching. You begin to understand, in a small way, what generations went through.

Fascinating insight into Cape Town's past. This is one of the must see museums in Cape Town. I stopped there with City Sightseeing. You only need an hour there but it is packed with interesting information and very well displayed. It gives you a real sense of what life used to be like in Cape Town during apartheid.
Go see it. A fairly interesting reminder of South Africa's past.
Again, eyeopening experience. Excellent museum where you can see a timeline of all the difficulties faced by South Africans during the Apartheid years.
