Hard to find. The Museum is interesting but extremely badly signposted and in a rather grotty part of town. No one local seemed to know where it was. Once we got there it was worth it.

Great Social History of Cape Town. Could not help but be moved by the individual stories. One of the things I loved were the hand made tapestries made by local women showing favourite family recipes. Gift shop take note - you should get these printed on to tea towels for sale - I would have bought a full set.
a must. no flashy gimmicks just true accounts facinating naratives and photographs plain exhibits from real people who had their world turned upside down

CapeTown is beautiful but don"t forget to learn about the history. We went to the museum and one of the founders was there. It brought me to tears to think about the people who were displaced from their homes and now it is a vacant expanse of land. The staff at the museum were so willing to share their experiences and it is a part of the culture and history of CapeTown and the world that you shouldn;t pass up. It makes you realize how lucky you are.

Unfortunately poorly curated and hot. My parents and I went to this museum to get some sense of history regarding South African race relations while we were in Cape Town. While the message the District Six Museum represents is an important issue and topic, this is a poorly-curated museum with almost no context for what it presents. The museum starts off promisingly enough on the ground floor, but as soon as I went upstairs to the main exhibition, I lost the message. For instance, there are old pictures lining the entire museum....but with no dates. That was more than a little annoying when a bunch of pictures from the 50s or 60s are presented without captions and without dates. What am I, as so me one there to learn, supposed to take away? You end up just blowing through what they have there. Another example is a mock sign-up book for people who used to live in Disrict Six...at least, that's what I *think* it was. It was presented with no caption or context. I also felt this museum was a bit biased, which perhaps is understandable. The narrative given was that District Six -- before it was labeled white-only -- was a paradigm of black culture and living. But then newspaper clippings at the end of the museum tour described District Six as a crime-infested slum that had no hope. Where was that side of the story in the museum? When I read that, I naturally second-guessed all the stuff I had just walked through as revisionist history. This museum is trying to make out District Six like it's Harlem, ...and it's not Harlem. Also, the museum (which is basically one large two-story room) has very poor air circulation and was very hot. This distracts from the overall experience and reading when you just walk to the museum and then are hot throughout. A few fans strategically placed would have made it more enjoyable on a physical level. Judging this as a museum and taking out the backstory, I would say this museum needs a lot of work -- and that's sad. I would recommend it mostly because there isn't a similar museum on this topic, but that's the only reason. This is not a museum with Western standards.
Very Interesting. Visited as part of a day touring, found it very interesting and a good insight as to what it must have been like living through those periods.
A very emotional experience. Brought together all the problems of South Africa in a stark and dignified way

Must to visit. the man who is on the entrance, can tell you a lot stories about that season, because he was one of them...
so emmotionaly!!
Very moving. An important stop for any visit to Cape Town to better understand what happened to the people who were displaced during the apartheid era.
An impressive museum tells a sad story.. I was impressed by the powerful story offered by this small museum. Easy accessed by the hop-on bus.

Needs some work but worth a visit. I really wanted to like this museum going into it. We arrived 20 minutes before it closed and I felt rushed-not by them, just by the time. There was a ton to read so bring your glasses. I wish it was a little more interactive or perhaps if they had offered a tour-they might have but didn't see it. I was really excited to see it and left little disappointed. So happy that they have this museum and would love to go back hopefully when they improve things a little.
An Interesting visit. Really enjoyed learning the story of district 6. well worth a visit
Distinctly Different. Definitely worth a stop for this unique part of Capetown's history

Love the ambience!. The Museum really captures in a gripping fashion what transpired at District Six and how the move affected the communities that lived there, but more so, the Museum has invested in development opportunities to relocate the original residents, its an inspiring story of triumph over tribulations.
Honest Political Displays and information. This is what happened and what life was like in District 6.
Mainly open land. This place was demolished under the apartheid government so it has history but not much to see. Pass by it on the open to bus.
EXCELLANT. Wonderful intersting place.Learnt so much more about the Jewish religion ..Its part in Cape Town and also so much about the General history of Cape Town .
Nice when its finished. The best way to see this is on the "Hop-on Hop-off" bus

Fascinating place. A fascinating, informative and different museum to visit if you're interested in an integral part of Cape Town's history. Try to get a guided tour by a former resident - very personalised way to see the museum. Great place for family visits as well...

South African social history museum. Wonderful collection of stories, allowing visitors to experience District Six through the eyes of many people - a difficult time in South Africa's history but dealt with in best image of South African reconciliation. I felt it could be slightly more ordered - it characterised some of the chaotic nature of district six before the bulldozers moved in but made it difficult to find and follow a story
Not to be missed. Museums such as these are a must as they bring home the inequalities of life.
Really Interisting. It was interisting to learn about the history and legacy of the people that were forcefully removed from their homes by the apartheid government, really compelling story

offskirts of down town. not a particularly nice neighbourhood. ONly reason it's fairly safe is it is virtually opposite a large police station. They have revamped the area a bit, but the museum is standard "post-colonial, post apartheid - let's look back at history fare."

A lot going on!. I love my museums and was looking forward to spending time here. I have to say I was very disappointed from the start. Firstly, it's not easy to find because there's another 'district 6' building just down the street which shows exhibitions, I believe. Anyway, took us 20 minutes to find the right place after we accidentally bumped into one of the workers. She did reassure us that they were aware of the confusion of location and were going to address it in due time. Now, to the museum. There is a lot going on visually, which I found to be distracting despite being a visual person. The walls (and floors) had lots of text surrounded by pictures/items and everything seemed crammed into the small, two floors of the building. it lacked a flow, and without a guide, just became overwhelming. It did seem like a wonderful place for those who have close ties to the area, as there were many memorials for them, which was a nice touch. We probably spent a total of 15 minutes before we left in a daze. If you go, try to find a guide or at least take a tour of the area for a more personal touch. I found the website to be more informational and interactive than the museum!
Definately Worth a Visit - Shocking but informative. To help put Apartheid into perspective, it's worth visiting this excellent museum which contains real-life stories from which to learn!
amazing museum. this really helps you understand what happened here

Man's inhumanity to man'. I thought I had posted a review of my visit previously, but now realise that I didn't - I actually visited prior to March 2011 but I cannot record the actual date.I'm not aware if this is a 'must' on the Cape town historical route. I had read about District Six previously and when someone told me about the museum, I felt I had to visit. There is something poignant about 'family' museums, ones that eloquently tell a simply store without too much razzmatazz. The 'ethnic clearing' of this part of Cape Town in the 1970s was nothing short of heinous. It was on a par with forced resettlement in parts of Germany/Poland during WWII.From the street signs preserved on the walls, to the extensive family histories and material belongings on display, it's a very, very sad place to see another (recent, I hasten to add) example of how man can be so cruel to their fellow humans.But there is hope. There are plans to rejuvenate the original area, although I think that has run into some political issues. Indeed, you can still walk the streets on the hillside that overlooks Table Mountain and wonder about a vibrant community that once lived there. (According to Wikipedia, the official area is 'bounded by Sir Lowry Road on the north, Tennant Road to the west, De Waal Drive on the south and Cambridge Street to the east.')As a museum, it's more important to visit and absorb its history than taking the cable car up the mountain ....
District Six. It's changed over the years, not as rough as it use to be. Very quite place to go for a walk.
Such a good snapshot of SA history. The history is amazing and hard, but empowering at the same time

cute, but a little bit boring. The museum itself is informative and nicely done. However after having done a township tour and some reading (rough guide) before the visit, there was not a lot of new things to discover. We left after about 20 minutes but it was a nice experience.

Interesting history. Interesting look into the vibrant history of District Six Museum, leaves you with a sense of loss when you consider the area is now bare and lifeless. There was a gentleman who used to live in District Six employed in the museum telling of his own experiences too, the ultimate interactive museum experience!

Good Intention but Kind of Flat. It's great that they have a museum dedicated to the history of District 6 but it isn't the best museum. It's a self-guided experience, no head phones or tour guides to provide instruction/education along the way. Stopping by the museum from the red line double-decker hop on/off bus is easy to do, it's stops right in front of it. After about an hour inside (max) you'll be ready to jump back on the bus.

I wish it were more organized.. If you don't know much of the history, this museum is not helpful. I would suggest reading up on the history of the area before going to the museum. Otherwise, it is in a beautiful building (former church), and the photos and descriptions of the removals are heartrending.

Understanding a little history. Small but well structured presentation in this. Useum and gives an insight into apartheid in the past and the struggle for freedom. All colours fought for freedom not just the blacks and when you see the history you realise how this exclusive suburb for whites nevertookplace and the site still stands empty today. A good educative visit
Informative on apartheid years. Small but interesting museum telling you how they lived during apartheid and what happened to this area in history. Good info and great history lesson.

Seriously worthwhile. This place is remarkable. It needs time to read all the stories and look at the photos. It is a serious historical record of decades of oppression, and it works, especially given its historical location.

This is a Must Do visit. This small museum set in an old church is an eye opener. It is full of personal stories of district six, and being in our fifties, and remembering apartheid from the other side of the world, it brought things into perspective on a personal level.
Don't miss tis. You can spend hours in this small museum! There is so much to read about.

compact and informative museum charting apartheid in the area, a must see. Well worth visiting for a brief history of the culture and history of the black africans in the area and generally in Cape town. Lots of information on how sucessive governments introduced apartheid and its continued use up until the early 90's.
District Six a waste of time. A wasteland. There is no much that could have been done and should have been done with District Six, given its historical significance.

Cape Town's past (and present). This is a small museum but packed with information presented in interesting and varied formats. Do read the inscription on the wall near the entrance.
There is some street parking nearby and a small coffee shop inside.
take the tissues. Heart filling stories of people displaced from their homes and about the wonderful community they created. This is a very visual museum and definitely worth the visit.

Intresting view of our past. This museum is one of Cape Towns "must see" places. It shows part of an era which has not had that much exposer in my mind, and should have. a visit here takes you back to this time with many visual aids and people who were there at the time, worth seeing.

Sad, but a must visit attraction. I would highly recommend a visit to this museum early in your visit to Cape Town. Gives an excellent (but very sad) background about Apartheid which will help you better appreciate and comprehend the townships, Robben Island, etc.
Very interesting. This museum is very interesting, I had no idea what happened to the people of Cape Town and this explained it in an interesting way in a lovely old building.
Well Worth A Visit. A Very small museum but well worth a visit , shows many of the injustices suffered during the aphartheid era

Excellent historical content. The museum provides an excellent understanding of South Africa's past struggles and was very moving, much more so than Robben Island. To read so much of what is written in the museum is to understand so much of past events and tells it how it was. There was despair and now there is hope. Take your time to read all that is written.
eye of. its all in the eyes of the beholder but i found it difficult to follow a route. What u read and see IS impressive though.
Thought provoking. It doesn't cost much to go in and helps you understand the impact the changes in District Six had on the blacks and coloureds who were moved out

Hope Out of Forgiveness. This museum is a place to really feel the history of this country, and be reminded of what all people, histories, and governments have in common. I took from this experience the same feeling of amazement I developed for South Africa as a whole: so many wonderful people striving to rise above darkness and bring light. Inspiring. Touching. Necessary for those who believe in learning from the mistakes of history so as not to repeat them.

Interesting and Informative, the museum brings history to life. The focus of the "District Six Museum" seems to be on displaying the individual stories, photographs, and sound recordings from before, during, and after the Apartheid era in order to impress upon the viewers the real people involved and affected. This focus on placing individuals within the historical context both helps the visitors to realize how recently the events depicted took place and prevents the visitors from being able to distance themselves from those involved. The museum's displays put the individual stories within the context of historical developments within South Africa, and South African developments within the context of World History.

An obligatory stop to understand more about the city. We included this as a stop on the walking tour from our guidebook. Very simple museum but it really captured the human experience when District Six was razed. The country's history of apartheid is easily ignored when enjoying the stunning views of the mountains and ocean- this museum was a necesary stop.

this is REALLY interesting. it's very easy to forget the the ugly history of such a beautiful city. if you have a social conscience the you will find this small apartheid museum fascinating. its not far out of town and not big, so it's a quick trip. definitely well worth it.

A most moving experience. Amongst all the many attractions of Cape Town, do visit this small and modest museum which reflects gently but so powerfully on South Africa's divided past. It brings home the the day to day dreadfulness of the apartheid system even more than the trip to Robben Island.

Great topic, above average museum. The topic for the District Six Museum is another "must" for understanding the history of South Africa. The Group Areas Act is part of a bygone era. This is definitely a good thing, and I applaud the museum for going to great lengths to keep the memory of District Six alive.However, as a museum I think it has its faults. The District Six museum reminds me of the Checkpoint Charlie Museum in Berlin. I would imagine that private donations and entrance fees cover most of the assistance for the place, and they don't have a group of professional historians to smooth things over and make the museum organized and cohesive. You will find information here that you need, it just may take a while longer than at a "professional" museum. The layout is a bit disorganized, but the trade-off is a bit of authenticity and warmth that you may be missing at a more proficient museum such as the Gold museum.I won't give it a 3/5 on principle, but the disorganization brings it down a notch.

Small is beautiful. An interesting museum with an unknown theme. The message was clear - a destroyed part of Cape Town with a lot of culture. What a bity. How would it be today? The museum it self is small enough to visit in max couple of hours. A lot to see, and even experience.

Get an insight. I was taken here as part of a township tour arranged through the concierge at Park Hotel, Greenmarket Square. I would really have liked to stay there longer, as I did not have enough time to read and see all I wanted to. The township tour was an excellent way to see how many people live. It gave me a greater insight into South Africa today and how bad things were in apartheid days. District Six was demolished because black people were too close to the posh white parts of Cape Town. It commemorates the feelings of the people whose homes were flattened, and community destroyed.

Don't miss it. It's small, a little scruffy, and easy to miss, located in a street that doesn't look wonderful, so don't come late in the evening, and watch your possessions. But it's really well worth visiting, giving you a real feeling for what the place was like before Apartheid, the damage done by relocations, and the feelings of people in coming to terms with it. It will give you a real insight into modern South Africa - I'd say don't miss it!
